column1: summary

Harry Potter star Daniel Radcliffe gains access to a reported 20 million 41.1 million fortune as he turns 18 on Monday. The young actor says he has no plans to fritter his cash away on fast cars, drink and celebrity parties. I dont plan to be one of those people who, as soon as they turn 18, suddenly buy themselves a massive sports car collection or something similar.

At 18, Radcliffe will be able to gamble in a casino, buy a drink in a pub or see the horror film Hostel Part II. Details of how hell mark his landmark birthday are under wraps. His agent and publicist had no comment on his plans.

Radcliffes earnings from the first five Potter films have been held in a trust fund which he has not been able to touch. His latest outing as the boy wizard in Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix is breaking records on both sides of the Atlantic. He will reprise the role in the last two films.
The Londoner has filmed a TV movie called My Boy Jack, about author Rudyard Kipling and his son. He will also appear in December Boys, an Australian film about four boys who escape an orphanage.

The ninth floor of the MiamiDade pretrial detention facility is dubbed the forgotten floor. Soledad OBrien takes users inside a jail where many of the inmates are mentally ill. "I just think Im going to be more sort of fair game," one inmate says of now that he's legally an adult. "It's going to get worse and worse," another inmate says.

Judge Steven Leifman says the arrests often result from confrontations with police. Mentally ill people often wont do what theyre told when police arrive on the scene. confrontation seems to exacerbate their illness and they become more paranoid, delusional, and less likely to follow directions. So, they end up on the ninth floor severely mentally disturbed, but not getting any real help because theyre in jail.
We toured the jail with Leifman. He is well known in Miami as an advocate for justice and the mentally ill. Go inside theforgotten floor . At first, its hard to determine where the people are.

The prisoners are wearing sleeveless robes. Theyre designed to keep the mentally ill patients from injuring themselves. Leifman says about onethird of all people in MiamiDade county jails are mentally ill.

So, he says, the sheer volume is overwhelming the system, and the result is what we see on the ninth floor. We see two, sometimes three men  sometimes in the robes, sometimes naked, lying or sitting in their cells. I am the son of the president. You need to get me out of here!

one man shouts at me. Leifman tells me that these prisonerpatients will often circulate through the system, occasionally stabilizing in a mental hospital, only to return to jail to face their charges. Its brutally unjust, in his mind, and he has become a strong advocate for changing things in Miami.

Leifman says 200 years ago people were considered lunatics and they were locked up in jails. Over the years, he says, there was some public outcry, and the mentally ill were moved out of jails and into hospitals. But many of these mental hospitals were so horrible they were shut down.

In 1955 there were more than half a million people in state mental hospitals. Today that number has been reduced 90 percent, and 40,000 to 50,000 people are in mental hospitals, judge says. Starting in 2008, many inmates who would otherwise have been brought to the forgotten floor will instead be sent to a new mental health facility.

Leifman says the best part is that its a winwin solution. The patients win, the families are relieved, and the state saves money by simply not cycling these prisoners through again and again. And, for Leifman, justice is served.

I probably had a 30, 35foot free fall. The whole bridge is down. I realized there was a school bus right next to me. Me and a couple of other guys went over and started lifting the kids off the bridge.
Dr. John Hink, an emergency room physician, rushed to the scene in 15 minutes. He arrived at the south side of the bridge, stood on the riverbank and saw dozens of people lying dazed.

They were in the middle of the Mississippi River, which was churning fast. Ambulances were also having a hard time driving down to the river to get closer to the scene. Volunteers, EMTs and other officials managed to get 55 people into ambulances in less than two hours.

The rescue effort was controlled and organized, he said the opposite of the lightningquick collapse. Babineau said the rear of his pickup truck was dangling over the edge of a brokenoff section of the bridge. "It just gave a rumble real quick, and it all just gave way," he said.

He said several vehicles slid past him into the water. "I stayed in my car for one or two seconds. I saw a couple cars fall," he said. "Then I got out real quick, ran in front of my truck and I helped a woman off of the bridge with me"
I started grabbing kids and handing them down. It was just complete chaos. He said most of the children were crying or screaming. He and other rescuers set them on the ground and told them to run.
Babineau said he had no rescue training. Melissa Hughes, 32, of Minneapolis, said she was driving home when the western edge of the bridge collapsed under her.
A pickup landed on top of her car, but she was not hurt. "I literally thought I was dead. My truck was completely face down, pointed toward the ground," she said.

It was folded in half, and I cant believe Im alive. Bernie Toivonen told CNNs American Morning that his vehicle was on a part of the bridge that ended up tilted at a 45degree angle. I just put in park, turned the key off and said,Oh, Im alive,  he said.

Doctors remove five small polyps from President Bush's colon. None appeared worrisome, White House spokesman says. All were small, less than a centimeter half an inch in diameter. Bush is in good humor, and will resume his activities at Camp David.

Bush reclaimed presidential power at 921 a.m. after about two hours. Doctors used monitored anesthesia care, so the president was asleep, but not as deeply unconscious as with a true general anesthetic. He spoke to first lady Laura Bush  who is in Midland, Texas, celebrating her mothers birthday.

Cheney spent the morning at his home on Marylands eastern shore, reading and playing with his dogs. He planned to have lunch at Camp David and have briefings with National Security Adviser Stephen Hadley and White House Chief of Staff Josh Bolten. The procedure was supervised by Dr. Richard Tubb, Bushs physician, and conducted by a multidisciplinary team.

The presidents doctor had recommended a repeat procedure in about five years. A colonoscopy is the most sensitive test for colon cancer, rectal cancer and polyps, small clumps of cells that can become cancerous. Small polyps may be removed during the procedure.

The American Cancer Society recommends that people without high risk factors or symptoms begin getting screened for signs of colorectal cancer at age 50. The National Football League has indefinitely suspended Atlanta Falcons quarterback Michael Vick without pay.

A judge will have the final say on a plea deal. Vick admitted to participating in a dogfighting ring as part of a plea agreement. NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell said he would review the status of the suspension after the legal proceedings are over.

Vick also admitted that he and two coconspirators killed dogs that did not fight well. Falcons owner Arthur Blank said Vicks admissions describe actions that are incomprehensible and unacceptable. Goodell said the Falcons could assert any claims or remedies to recover 22 million of Vicks signing bonus.

Vick said he would plead guilty to one count of Conspiracy to Travel in Interstate Commerce in Aid of Unlawful Activities. The charge is punishable by up to five years in prison, a 250,000 fine, full restitution, a special assessment and 3 years of supervised release. Federal prosecutors agreed to ask for the low end of the sentencing guidelines. The defendant will plead guilty because the defendant is in fact guilty of the charged offense.

Most of theBad Newz Kennels operations and gambling monies were provided by Vick. Gambling wins were generally split among coconspirators Tony Taylor, Quanis Phillips and sometimes Purnell Peace. Vick did not gamble by placing side bets on any of the fights.

Vick is scheduled to appear in court Monday. Peace, Phillips and Vick agreed to the killing of 68 dogs that did not perform well intesting sessions at 1915 Moonlight Road. Vick agrees and stipulates that these dogs all died as a result of the collective efforts of the three, according to a statement from Vicks. The three others already have accepted agreements to plead guilty in exchange for reduced sentences.

The judge in the case will have the final say over the plea agreement. The risk for Vick is, if he makes admissions in his federal guilty plea, the state of Virginia could say,Hey, look, you admitted violating Virginia state law as well. It sometimes happens  not often  that the state will follow a federal prosecution by charging its own crimes.

Vick agreed to make restitution for the full amount of the costs associated with the dogs that are being held by the government. Vick also agreed to turn over any documents he has and to submit to polygraph tests. Vick agreed to cooperate with investigators and provide all information he may have on any criminal activity and to testify if necessary.

Prosecutors, with the support of animal rights activists, have asked for permission to euthanize the dogs. The dogs could serve as important evidence in the cases against Vick and his admitted coconspirators. Judge Henry E. Hudson issued an order telling the U.S. Marshals Service to arrest and seize the defendant property.

After Vicks indictment last month, Goodell ordered the quarterback not to report to the Falcons training camp. Blank told the NFL Network on Monday he could not speculate on Vicks future as a Falcon, at least not until he had seen a statement of facts in the case. Youssif held his sisters hand Friday, seemingly unaware that millions of people across the world have been touched by his story.
Youssif turns 6 next Friday. He is wearing a facial mask often used to help burn victims. I was so happy I didnt know what to do with myself, his mother, Zainab, told CNN.
His father said he was on the roof of his house when CNN called him with the news. Like his wife, he couldnt stop smiling. He talked about how he tried in vain to get help for his son in Baghdad.
There were many trips to the Ministry of Health. He says he even put in a request to Iraqs parliament for help. No one has been arrested or held accountable in Youssifs case.

The Childrens Burn Foundation has agreed to pay for the transportation for Youssif and his family to come to the United States. The foundation says it will cover all medical costs from surgeries to housing costs to any social rehabilitation that might be needed for him. You can make a donation at the foundations site by clicking here. Theres a dropdown menu under the general donation area that is marked Y Moussifs fund.

Surgeries will be performed by Dr. Peter Grossman, a plastic surgeon with the affiliated Grossman Burn Center. Officials are still trying to get the appropriate visas for the familys travels. We expect that the treatment will be from between six months to a year with many surgeries.

Youssifs parents said they know its going to be a lengthy and difficult process and that adjusting to their stay in America may not be easy. But none of that matters  getting help for their boy is first and foremost.

The biggest obstacle now is getting the visas to leave, and the serious security risks they face. That is partly due to the tens of thousands of CNN.com users who were so moved by the story and wanted to act. CNN Iraqi staff central to bringing this story together were also overwhelmed with the generosity coming from people outside of their border.
The women are too afraid and ashamed to show their faces or have their real names used. Suha, 37, is a mother of three. She says her husband thinks she is cleaning houses when she leaves home.

People shouldnt criticize women, or talk badly about them, says 37-year-old Suha. A mother of three, she wears light makeup, a gold pendant of Iraq around her neck. I have to do anything that I can to preserve my child, because I am a mother, she says.
Anger and frustration rise in her voice as she speaks. Her clasped hands clench and unclench nervously. No matter what else I may be, no matter how off the path I might be, I am a mother.

At the start I was cleaning homes, but I wasnt making much. No matter how hard I worked it just wasnt enough. My husband died of lung cancer nine months ago and left me with nothing. She has five children, ages 8 to 17.
She was solicited the first time when she was cleaning an office. They took advantage of me, she says softly. At first I rejected it, but then I realized I have to do it.

Or they flag down vehicles. Prostitution is a choice more and more Iraqi women are making just to survive. Violence, increased cost of living, and lack of any sort of government aid leave women like these with few other options.

There is a population of women who have to sell their bodies in order to keep their children alive, says Yanar Mohammed, head and founder of the Organization for Womens Freedom in Iraq. Her team pounds the streets of Baghdad looking for these victims often too humiliated to come forward. "It crushes us to see them, but we have to work on it," she says.

Most of the women that we find at hospitals who have tried to commit suicide have been involved in prostitution, says Basma Rahim. Rahim tells the heartbreaking story of one woman who lives in a room with three of her children. She has sex while her three children are in the room, but she makes them stand in separate corners, she says. The teams aim is to compile information on specific cases and present it to Iraqs political parties.

Karima says when she sees her children with food on the table, she is able to convince herself that its worth it. But she says, I would never allow my daughter to do this. I would rather marry her off at 13 than have her go through this.

Karimas last happy memory is of her late husband, when they were a family and able to shoulder the hardships of life in todays Iraq together. Suha says as a young girl she dreamed of being a doctor, with her mom boasting about her potential in that career.

Tomas Medina Caracas was a member of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia. He had been in the crosshairs of the U.S. Justice Department since 2002. He was killed in an air attack on a guerrilla encampment, the Colombian military said. He is known popularly as El Negro Acacio, according to Interpol.

U.S. officials alleged Medina Caracas managed the rebel groups sales of cocaine to international drug traffickers. He was also indicted in the United States along with two other FARC commanders in November 2002. Officials said the armys Rapid Response Force, backed by elements of the Colombian Air Force, tracked Medina Car Venezuel down at a FARC camp in the jungle in the south of the country. After a bombardment, the troops occupied the camp, and theyve found 14 dead rebels so far.

The death ofEl Negro Acacio was confirmed by various sources, including members of FARC itself. Medina Caracas commanded FARCs 16th Front in the southern departments of Vichada and Guainia. Established in 1964 as the military wing of the Colombian Communist Party, FARC is Colombias oldest, largest, most capable and bestequipped Marxist rebel group.

White House press secretary Tony Snow will step down from his post on September 14. President Bush told reporters Friday that he will sadly accept Snows resignation. Its been a joy to watch him spar with you, Bush said.

Snow said he was leaving to earn more money. He took a big pay cut, he said, when he left his previous jobs as anchor and political analyst for Fox News. Bush: Hell battle cancer and win, and hell be a solid contributor to society.

According to The Washington Post, Snow makes 168,000 as the White House spokesman. His family took out a loan when he started the job, and that loan is now gone. He said he would continue to speak out on issues, and would do some radio, some TV.

Snows cancer was diagnosed for the first time in February 2005. His colon was removed, and after six months of treatment, doctors said the cancer was in remission. Sources told CNN two weeks ago that Snow was planning to leave his job, possibly as early as September.

Bush tapped Snow to replace Scott McClellan in April 2006. Snow had been an anchor for Fox News Sunday and a political analyst for the Fox News Channel. On Thursday, Snow told CNN his health is improving, citing two medical tests this month.

Snow's black hair is expected to grow back in about a month. Snow said on Friday he was to see his oncologist, and they will decide on some minor forms of chemotherapy to start as maintenance treatment.

Niranjan Desai discovered the 20-year-old AT4 antitank rocket launcher tube. The launcher has been turned over to U.S. Army officials at Fort Monmouth, New Jersey. Police say the launcher is no longer operable and not considered a hazard to public safety. There was no indication the launcher had been fired recently, police said, adding there is no indication it was fired recently.

The nearest military base, Fort Dix, is more than 70 miles from Jersey City. The Joint Terrorism Task Force division of the FBI and Jersey City police are investigating the origin of the rocket launcher. A neighbor, Joe Quinn, said the object lying on Desais lawn looked military, was brown, had a handle and strap, and both ends were open, like you could shoot something with it.

An Army official said the device is basically a shoulderfired, directfire weapon. A loaded M136 AT4 antitank weapon has a 40inchlong fiberglasswrapped tube. Its 84 millimeter shapedcharge missile can penetrate 14 inches of armor from a maximum of 985 feet.

President Bush to tell Veterans of Foreign Wars that real problem was U.S. presence. Three decades later, there is a legitimate debate about how we got into the Vietnam War, Bush will say. One unmistakable legacy of Vietnam is that the price of Americas withdrawal was paid by millions of innocent citizens, he will say, according to speech excerpts released Tuesday by the White House. "boat people,reeducation camps andkilling fields" are among the terms Bush will use.

The president will also make the argument that withdrawing from Vietnam emboldened todays terrorists by compromising U.S. credibility. The president will cite a quote from al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden that the American people would rise against the Iraq war the same way they rose against the war in Vietnam, according to the excerpts. Here at home, some can argue our withdrawal from Vietnam carried no price to American credibility, but the terrorists see things differently, Bush will say. The President continues to staythecourse with his failed strategy in Iraq, paid for by the taxpayers, said Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid.

The White House is billing the speech, along with another address next week to the American Legion, as an effort to provide broader context for the debate. It is being closely watched on Capitol Hill, particularly by Republicans nervous about the political fallout from an increasingly unpopular war. President Bush has frequently asked lawmakers  and the American people to withhold judgment on his troop surge in Iraq until the report comes out in September.

Bush will invoke other historical comparisons from Asia, including the U.S. defeat and occupation of Japan after World War II and the Korean War in the 1950s. A recent CNNOpinion Research Corporation poll found that almost twothirds of Americans now oppose the Iraq war, and 72 percent say that even if Petraeus reports progress, it wont change their opinion. 53 percent said they do not trust Petraeus to give an accurate assessment of the situation in Iraq. Earlier this month, Defense Secretary Robert Gates said he would wait for the report before deciding when a drawdown of the 160,000 troops in Iraq might begin.

Many thought it naive to help the Japanese transform themselves into a democracy, Bush will say. Today, in defiance of the critics, Japan... stands as one of the worlds great free societies, he says. Bush will also talk about the Korean War, saying that at the time critics argued that the war was futile, that we never should have sent our troops in.

A second car packed with gas and nails was later found to have been parked just a few hundred yards from the first. The second car was towed away by traffic wardens in the early hours of Friday for violating parking restrictions. Without Americas intervention during the war, millions of South Koreans would now be living under a brutal and repressive regime. A chronology of bombings and attempted bomb attacks in the mainland UK since the 1970s.

Police say two vehicles clearly linked. Four suicide bombers detonate themselves aboard three underground trains and a bus in a morning rush hour attack on July 7, 2005. Al Qaeda claims responsibility in a video statement. Two weeks after the deadly 77 bombings, four men are alleged to have attempted to carry out a second wave of attacks against Londons transport network.

A car bomb explodes outside the BBCs London headquarters, wounding one man. Police blame the Real IRA, a republican splinter group opposed to the IRAs cease fire. April 1999 Three people die when a nail bomb explodes in the Admiral Duncan pub in Londons gay district. Seven men are convicted in May 2007 and sentenced to up to 26 years in prison.

A 23yearold selfdeclared Nazi, David Copeland, is sentenced to six life terms. A massive IRA bomb explodes in a shopping center in central Manchester, injuring more than 200 people. Two boys aged three and 12 are killed and dozens are injured by two bombs left in litter bins in Warrington, northern England.

The IRA admits planting the bombs. April 1992 A huge IRA car bomb in Londons financial district kills three people and wounds 91. February 1991 IRA terrorists launch a mortar attack at Prime Minister John Majors Downing Street offices. September 1989 Eleven people die and 22 are wounded when an IRA bomb explodes at a Royal Marine music school in Deal, southern England.

Libyan agent Abdel Basset alMegrahi, convicted of the attack in 2001, was this week granted the right to mount a fresh appeal. October 1984 Five people die in an IRA bomb attack on a hotel in Brighton, southern England, where Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her cabinet are staying. December 1983 An IRA bomb at Londons Harrods department store kills six people.

Carlos Alberto has joined Bundesliga club Werder Bremen for a club record fee of 7.8 million euros 10.7 million. The 22-year-old enjoyed success at FC Porto under Jose Mourinho. Alberto scored in FC Portos Champions League final victory against Monaco in 2004.

Carlos Alberto started his career with Fluminense, and helped them to lift the Campeonato Carioca in 2002. In January 2004 he moved on to FC Porto, who were coached by José Mourinho, and won the Portuguese title as well as the Champions League. Early in 2005, he moved to Corinthians, where he impressed as they won the Brasileirão. In 2006 Corinthians had a poor season and Carlos Alberto found himself at odds with manager, Emerson Leão. He declared that he would not play for Corinthians again while Leão remained as manager. Since January this year he has been on loan with his first

Bundesliga champions VfB Stuttgart said on Sunday that they would sign a loan agreement with Real Zaragoza on Monday for Ewerthon. On Friday, Ailton returned to Germany where he was the leagues top scorer in 2004, signing a oneyear deal with Duisburg on a transfer from Red Star Belgrade. Vice President Dick Cheney will serve as acting president briefly Saturday while President Bush is anesthetized for a routine colonoscopy.

A colonoscopy is the most sensitive test for colon cancer, rectal cancer and polyps. The procedure will be supervised by Dr. Richard Tubb and conducted by a multidisciplinary team from the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland. Small polyps may be removed during the procedure.
Snow said that was the case when Bush had colonoscopies before becoming president. Snow himself is undergoing chemotherapy for cancer that began in his colon and spread to his liver.

Magnitude 4.2 earthquake shakes San Francisco area Friday at 442 a.m. PT. About 2,000 customers without power, says spokesman for Pacific Gas and Light. Under USGS classification, a magnitude 4. 2 earthquake is considered light. American Cancer Society recommends screening for colorectal cancer at age 50.
The quake was centered about two miles eastnortheast of Oakland, at a depth of 3.6 miles. Oakland is just east of San Francisco, across San Francisco Bay. No injuries or damage has been reported.

An Oakland police dispatcher told CNN the quake set off alarms at peoples homes. The shaking lasted about 50 seconds, said CNN meteorologist Chad Myers. According to the USGS, magnitude 4.2 quakes are felt indoors and may break dishes and windows.

Over the past 25 days, the Mine Safety and Health Administration has exhausted all known options in our attempt to reach the six miners. The thoughts and prayers of the dedicated professionals at MSHA are with the families. President Bush: Last night, a difficult decision was made to end the search.

Labor Secretary Elaine Chao called the ordeal heartbreaking. The grueling aroundtheclock rescue operation has taken a tremendous toll on the many brave rescuers and the local community, Chao said. After drilling seven holes into mine tunnels from the mountaintop above, there has been no sign of the miners.

We basically told the families that at this point in time weve run out of options, Stickler says. There were no public statements Saturday from Bob Murray, president and CEO of Murray Mining. Murray was the outspoken face of the rescue operation for the first three weeks, then largely disappeared from public view. The rescue operation has now lasted nearly four weeks, the rescue team says. The search for the missing is expected to continue into next week.

Federal officials became the spokesmen. No one from Murray Mining was present at Fridays news conference. The men were trapped during a collapse on August 6, and it is not known whether they survived the cavein.

Efforts to reach them were suspended 10 days later when two rescuers and a federal mining official were killed. Murray said last week that the search effort would stop if no signs of life were found at the sixth hole. Under pressure from the families, however, he agreed to try one more time.

Work resumed Friday, this time at the fourth hole. The camera could only descend about 7 feet, he said. "There was quite a bit of mud in there, water coming down the hole," Stickler said of the latest try. "It really couldnt go any farther than seven feet"

Murray said he has already filed paperwork with federal regulators to permanently close and seal the Crandall Canyon mine. Friends and family have identified the six missing miners as Luis Hernandez, Manuel Sanchez, Kerry Allred, Carlos Payan, Brandon Phillips and Don Erickson.

The explosion occurred at 5 p.m. about 20 meters 65 feet from a mosque in Batna, a town about 450 kilometers 280 miles east of Algiers. The bomb went off 15 minutes before the expected arrival of President AbdelAziz Bouteflika. It wasnt clear if the bomb was caused by a suicide bomber or if it was planted.

Algeria faces a continuing Islamic insurgency, according to the CIA. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing. In July, 33 people were killed in apparent suicide bombings in Algiers that were claimed by an al Qaedaaffiliated group. The attack took place in the city of Batna.

Bouteflika said terrorist acts have nothing in common with the noble values of Islam. David Beckham is headed for the Hollywood Hills as he takes his game to U.S. Major League Soccer. CNN looks at how Bekham fulfilled his dream of playing for Manchester United.

Beckham has begun a fiveyear contract with the Los Angeles Galaxy team. On Friday Beckham will meet the press and reveal his new shirt number. CNN will look back at the life of Beckham, the wonderfully talented youngster who fulfilled his dream of playing for Manchester United, his marriage to pop star Victoria, and the trials and tribulations ofPlaying for England. We will also look at Beckhams incredible rise to football stardom, a journey that has seen his skills grace the greatest stages in world soccer.

Beckham is no stranger to exposure. He has teamed with Reggie Bush in an Adidas commercial. He is the face of Motorola and has his own international clothing line. But what does the star couple need to do to become an accepted part of Tinseltowns glitterati? CLICK HERE for all the latest Manchester United news.

The road to major league football in the U.S.A. is a wellworn route. We talk to some of the former greats who came before him and examine what impact these overseas stars had. We also get a rare glimpse inside the David Beckham academy in L.A, find out what drives the kids and who are their heroes.

Virus found in healthy Australian honey bees may be playing a role in the collapse of honey bee colonies across the United States. Colony collapse disorder has killed millions of bees. Up to 90 percent of colonies in some U.S. beekeeping operations have been destroyed. The crops largely dependent upon bees for pollination include oranges, blueberries, apples and almonds.

colony collapse disorder was first reported in the U.S. in 2004. The disorder is marked by hives left with a queen, a few newly hatched adults and plenty of food. The virus identified in the healthy Australian bees is Israeli Acute Paralysis Virus IAPV. For some reason, the Australian bees seem to be resistant to the virus and do not come down with symptoms.

Scientists used genetic analyses of bees collected over the past three years. They found that IAPV was present in bees that had come from colony collapse disorder hives 96 percent of the time. But the study cautioned that collapse disorder is likely caused by several factors. This could explain why bees in Australia may be resistant to colony collapse, the study says.

There are no cases... in Australia at all, entomologist Dave Britton of the Australian Museum said last month. It is a Northern Hemisphere phenomenon. Researchers also say varroa mites affect all hives on the U.S. mainland but are not found in Australia.

One nagging problem has been a general inability to treat or vaccinate bees against viruses of any kind. But in the case of IAPV, there is evidence that some bees carry genetic resistance to the disorder. This is yet one more argument for beekeepers to use honey bee stocks that are genetically disease and pestresistant. Bee researchers will now look for stresses that may combine to kill bees.

Long lines formed before counters opened at the Northern Rock building society. Customers are believed to have already withdrawn about 1 billion 2 billion since the banks woes were revealed. Speculation that the global credit crunch made raising funds through commercial borrowing difficult. Other researchers involved in the study include researchers from Pennsylvania State University, the Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture, the University of Arizona and 454 Life Sciences. and Columbia University.

Shares in Northern Rock dropped up to 30 percent in Friday trading. British Bankers Association has urged customers to calm down. Finance minister Alistair Darling said the Bank of England had stepped in to create a stable banking system. He said people can use their accounts in the usual way.

Northern Rock will be able to carry on its business. Chief executive Adam Applegarth said the bank had yet to draw on the emergency cash. Former football star O.J. Simpson will be held without bail after his arrest on robbery and assault charges.

Simpson is accused of having directed several other men in an alleged armed robbery of sports memorabilia. Las Vegas authorities said they have no information leading them to believe Simpson was carrying a firearm during the alleged incident. Police said Simpson and other men burst into the room and walked out with the memorabilia, including some that was unrelated to Simpson.
A reporter asked Nichols Was O.J. was the boss in that room? Nichols responded, That is what we believe, yes. The alleged victims were identified as Bruce Fromong, a sports memorabilia collector.

Acting on a tip, police met over the weekend at McCarran International Airport with 46-year-old Walter Alexander, of Mesa, Arizona. Alexander was arrested Saturday night on two counts of robbery with a deadly weapon. He was released on his own recognizance and returned to Mesa either Saturday night or early Sunday morning.

Two firearms that police said were used were recovered early Sunday in one of three searches. Investigators would would not divulge where the weapons were found. Nichols dismissed an initial report that the men may have been offduty police. There is no truth to that whatsoever, he said.
Simpson, 60, has acknowledged taking some items that belonged to him, but he has denied that any weapons were involved. Nichols also said that some of the property taken had Simpsons signature.

I believe there were some Joe Montana cleats and some signed baseballs and other stuff. Simpson was acquitted of murder the following year. In 1997, a jury found him liable for the deaths in a civil case brought by the Goldman family.

Simpson was ordered to pay the families a total of 33.5 million for the deaths. Goldman had gone to Nicole Simpsons Los Angeles home to return a pair of glasses the day of the slayings. Goldmans sister, Kim Goldman, said she wasnt surprised by the robbery allegations, since Simpson thinks he can do no wrong.

Simpson recently wrote a book originally titled If I Did It and had planned to publish it himself, but a public outcry led to the cancellation of his book deal. A bankruptcy judge subsequently awarded the Goldmans the rights to the book in light of their inability to collect the wrongful death award.

Anthony Ogadje, 25, and nine other contestants had gone to Shere Hills Lake in Nigerias hilly Plateau State to prepare for the Gulder Ultimate Search. The show sets a variety of physical challenges for participants. Heinekens local unit which is sponsoring the show has suspended the show.

All attempts to revive him by the attendant medical team and the lifeguards, including his fellow contestants, failed. Broadcasting had been due to start on Thursday. In the show, the weakest contestants are evicted one by one until a winner emerges. The prize money is a big attraction in a country where most people live in extreme poverty and benefit little from Nigerias oil wealth.

A former government contract employee was indicted on charges of stealing restricted nuclear energyrelated materials. Sources say the classified materials were taken from the East Tennessee Technology Park. The Ultimate Search, which started in 2004, gets high ratings.

Roy Lynn Oakley, 67, of Roane County, Tennessee, appeared in federal court in Knoxville on Thursday. Oakley was briefly detained for questioning in the case in January, when authorities first learned of the alleged plot to divulge the materials. He voluntarily surrendered Thursday at an FBI field office inKnoxville, sources say. Oakly is a former employee of Bechtel Jacobs, the Department of Energys prime environmental management contractor.

The transfer took place January 26, the indictment alleges. Oakley is also charged with converting the material and restricted data to his own use. Prosecutors said the materials involved have been examined by scientists and posed no threat to people who may have come into contact with them.

Moncier said Oakley had a security clearance, but Moncier did not believe it was a highlevel clearance. The government alleges that in January, Oakley attempted to sell the pieces of scrap to someone he thought was a French agent. He said he questions whether those broken pieces would be considered an appliance under the law.

The equipment was never transmitted to a foreign government or terrorist organization. The materials involved are not the crown jewels, but they should not have been taken from the facility, a source says. A barrier is used to filter uranium during the enrichment process, but a significant number of barriers are needed to do that job, officials say. The suspect apparently did not make contact with any foreign government and is not a foreign agent of any kind, an official familiar with the case says.

A government official with with knowledge of the case said that when authorities learned of Oakleys alleged intentions six months ago, the FBI and Department of Energy launched a joint investigation. East Tennessee Technology Park is an area of the DOEs Oak Ridge reservation where we are currently decontaminating and decommissioning buildings that were last used in 1985. When they were in use, now over 20 years ago, some of the buildings at ETTP housed facilities used for the enrichment of uranium.

A dire shortage of donated organs in rich countries is sending foreigners to poorer places like China, Pakistan, Turkey, Egypt, Colombia and the Philippines. Paul Lee got his liver from an executed Chinese prisoner Karam in Egypt bought a kidney for his sister for 5,300 in Istanbul Hakan is holding out for 30,700 for one of his kidneys. Doctors in Pakistan have been arrested for abducting people, drugging them and stealing their kidneys.

That April, he paid 260,000 yuan 34,380 for a transplant  surgery that saved his life. The hospital has connections with a lot of prisons, Lee told Reuters. The World Health Organization estimates that 21,000 liver transplants are carried out annually.

Demand for kidneys also exceeds supply, and that has given rise to organ trafficking. A donor in South Africa receives 700 for a kidney compared with 30,000 in the United States. A lack of transparency and little protection for donors has spurred calls by international bodies to crack down on, or at least regulate, the trade.

Any transplant procedure involving a living donor carries risks for the donor. complications can include bleeding, infection, even death. In the transplant trade, the recipient need not worry about exposing a living relative to that risk. It is cheaper and your next of kin is not taking the risk and you dont have to care for someone you dont know.

Only 20,000 transplants are carried out in China each year. Of these, 3,000 are liver transplants and 95 percent use livers from dead donors. A transplant operation using the liver of a dead donor costs around 33,000 in China.

In Asia, a cultural obsession with keeping the body of the deceased intact has stymied public organ donation programs. Excluding China, Asia has fewer than 200 livers donated by people ahead of their death each year. Pakistan, where trade in human organs is not illegal, is turning into a kidney bazaar, said the chief executive of Pakistans Kidney Foundation, Jaffar Naqvi. There are no confirmed figures for the number of foreigners coming to the country for new kidneys.

Patients, mostly from Europe, Saudi Arabia and India, pay about 500,000 rupees 8,500 for a new kidney. Donors are paid 300 to 1,000 and often get no medical care after the surgery. In May police arrested nine people, four of them doctors, for abducting people.

Stories of people selling their organs, especially kidneys, are not uncommon in Egypt. More than 30 percent of a population of more than 73 million people live below the poverty line. Such a clause allowing altruistic organ donations will ensure the trade continues with secret payment to donors, Naqvi said. He said a doctor found him a man willing to sell his kidney for 30,000 Egyptian pounds 5,300.

Both his money and the fees of the hospital were deducted from the money thedonor received, said Karam. Doctors usually help in finding people willing to sell their organs from their patients lists. Egyptian law lacks clear punishment for those involved in illegal transplants, making it easy for doctors to repeat the offence.

The union has been pushing for legislation to regulate organ transplants. The draft bill includes heavy fines and a prison sentence for those involved. But the draft law has been languishing in parliament for several years. This is because of differences between doctors and senior Muslim religious leaders.

In Turkey, students, unemployed young men and struggling fathers post adverts on the Internet selling their kidneys. These wouldbe donors say they have had enquiries from Germany, Israel and Turkey with asking prices going up to 50,000 lira 38,760. Hakan, a 27yearold security guard in Istanbul with two young children who also requested only his first name be published, said he received five or six offers from Turkey and Germany.

Hollywood filmmakers are asking about Lindsay Lohan following her legal troubles. Lohan may still get work after her legal problems are settled, but the cost will be high.Ive got two children... theres nothing else I can do for them.

Lohan fans have little to fear because no actor is uninsurable, say underwriting experts. Lohans arrest this week in Los Angeles on suspicion of drunken driving and cocaine possession has left Hollywood wondering if the actress is too risky to cast in a film. For a price, anything can be done, although an insurance carrier can make things so unpalatable that at times the makers of the film just wont be interested, said Ross Miller, partner with insurance brokerage D.R. Reiff  Associates Inc.

A statement was expected early next week on whether the movie, already delayed this spring due to an earlier rehab stint by Lohan, will proceed with or without her. Insurance experts say the industry has long dealt with similar situations, although they may seem more frequent with the recent heavy media scrutiny.

The terms for covering Lohan would likely be serious at this point. Firemans Fund would likely put in higher deductibles, or ask the star to put their salary into escrow to pay for any losses if production was disrupted. Last July, a producer on Lohans last film, Georgia Rule, scolded her publicly for repeatedly showing up late on the set.

Insurance rates for errant actors can range anywhere from 1 percent to 3 percent of a movies production budget, which can range from 5 million to 100 million. Brian Kingman, a managing director with entertainment insurance broker AonAlbert G. Ruben said covering situations like Lohans required a lot of calculation and risk management.

In cases of known drug abuse, minders are sometimes required on set to keep an eye on the actor. Kingman said he had even helped craft policies for actors in the event they risked the possibility of incarceration. I have been successful in finding and creating incarceration coverage for certain actors on probation which can be revoked if they break certain rules, he said.

Allegations that Blackwater USA was complicit in unlawful arms activities are baseless. The State Department has been cooperating with the prosecutors in the Blackwater probe.

Blackwater resumed normal security operations in Iraq on Friday. Blackwater investigating alleged smuggling of weapons into Iraq by a contractor, Krongards statement says. The State Department said Blackwater resumed operations after a brief hiatus following the incident last Sunday.
Youssif has always been a huge SpiderMan fan. Meeting him was my favorite thing, he said. Spidey then gave the boy from a faraway land a gentle hug, embracing him in his iconic blue and red tights.
He showed Youssif a few tricks, like how to shoot a web from his wrist. Other superheroes crowded around to get a closer look.
He didnt take a liking to SpiderMans nemesis. Spidey was just too cool. I want to see him again.
Youssif met SpongeBob, Lassie and a 3year-old orangutan named Archie. The hairy, brownishred primate took to the boy, grabbing his hand and holding it.

The boy giggled inside a play area where spongelike balls shot out of toy guns. He squealed with delight and raced around the room collecting as many balls as he could. He rode a tram through the back stages at Universal Studios.
Fire and smoke filled the air, debris cascaded down and a big rig skidded toward the vehicle. The boy and his family survived the pretend earthquake unscathed.
Youssif pushed his 14monthold sister, Ayaa, in a stroller. Just a day earlier, the mother and father talked about their journey out of Iraq and to the United States.

They also discussed that day nine months ago when masked men grabbed their son outside the family home, doused him in gas and set him on fire. The father sought help for his boy across Baghdad, but no one listened.

He could hear his boys piercing screams from the other side of the hospital. The father knew that speaking to CNN would put his familys lives in jeopardy. The possibility of being killed was better than seeing his son suffer.
We had to do it. They described a life of utter chaos in Baghdad. Neighbors had recently given birth to a baby girl. Shortly afterward, the father was kidnapped and killed.

Under Saddam Hussein, there was more security and stability, they said. The couple said they had heard reports that a young girl was kidnapped and beheaded and her killers sewed a dogs head on the corpse and delivered it to her familys doorstep.

There was running water and electricity most of the time. But still life was tough under the dictator, like the time when Zainabs uncle disappeared and was never heard from again. Iraq finished, he said in what few English words he knows. His homeland wont be enjoying such freedoms anytime soon.
His two children have only seen war. But this week, the family has seen a much different side of America. An outpouring of generosity and a peaceful nation at home.
At Universal Studios, he looked out across the valley below. The sun glistened off treetops and buildings. It was a picturesque sight fit for a Hollywood movie.

Trent D. Thomas was found guilty Wednesday of kidnapping and conspiracy to commit several offenses. Thomas will be demoted to the rank of entrylevel private and will receive a badconduct discharge. The 25-year-old was among seven Marines and a Navy medic who were charged in connection with the death of Hashim Ibrahim Awad, 52. The Marines accused in the case were members of Kilo Company.

Residents of Hamdaniya, including relatives of the victim, gave a different account. Prosecutors accuse the groups squad leader, Sgt. Lawrence G. Hutchins III, of dragging Awad from his home, shooting him in the street and then making it look like he had planned to ambush American troops.

He faces a sentence of life in prison if convicted. Thomas changed his plea from guilty to not guilty in February. He told his attorneys that what happened overseas happened as a result of obedience to orders, and he hasnt done anything wrong, defense attorney Victor Kelley said.

Prince Harry led tributes to Diana, Princess of Wales on the 10th anniversary of her death. He described her as the best mother in the world in a speech at a memorial service. Harry: 'William and I can separate life into two parts'

And then there are the 10 years since our mothers death. When she was alive, we completely took for granted her unrivaled love of life, laughter, fun and folly. She was our guardian, friend and protector.
Behind the media glare, to us, just two loving children, she was quite simply the best mother in the world. She kissed us last thing at night. Her beaming smile greeted us from school.

She encouraged us when we were nervous or unsure. She like our father was determined to provide us with a stable and secure childhood. To lose a parent so suddenly at such a young age is indescribably shocking and sad. But what is far more important to us now, and into the future, is that we remember our mother as she would have wished to be remembered.
We both think of her every day. We speak about her and laugh together at all the memories. Put simply, she made us, and so many other people, happy.

I bow my knees before the Father, from whom every family in heaven and on earth takes its name. I pray that you may have the power to comprehend, with all the saints, what is the breadth and length and height and depth, and to know the love of Christ that surpasses knowledge. Now to Him who by the power at work within us is able to accomplish abundantly far more than all we can ask or imagine, to Him be glory in the church and in Christ Jesus.

The scene is an old peoples home. Two residents are playing Beggar My Neighbor. The question from the royal visitor is unexpected. Afterwards they comment on her large eyes and what life she brought into the room.

Everyone here will have their own memories. I remember meeting Princess Diana for the very first time early in 1981 to discuss details of the wedding service in St Pauls. It must have been a bewildering time for the Princess as well, but even then, at the age of 20, her capacity for empathy and her very strong intuitive power ensured that any tension soon evaporated.

I want to dwell for a moment on her public work, its cost and its meaning. After her marriage, the Princess joined her natural gifts of beauty, empathy and powerful intuition with that extraordinary charge which association with the Royal Family generates. We tend to be suspicious of public figures who wrap themselves in divinity and claim that their will is Gods will. But if noone can articulate in an unignorable way in the public realm the creative energy of the love that we see in Christ, then we shall find ourselves inhabiting a maimed and diminished society.

The Princess was still only 26 in 1987 when she shook the hand of a patient at the opening of the Middlesex Hospitals Aids ward. It was the first in the UK and it is very hard now to credit the degree of fear and prejudice which surrounded Aids in the80s. Those familiar with the field have no doubt that the Princess played a significant part in overcoming a harmful and even a cruel taboo.

She proved the eloquence of embrace and of touch which, of course, have been used by royal healers throughout the centuries. She sought out places of suffering, because they are so very often places of truth where the masks have been removed. She was not afraid to be with the dying and to comfort them in an unsentimental way. And as she said, in her words, the biggest disease today is not leprosy or TB but the feeling of being unwanted.
Bill Deedes accompanied her on some of her visits. His response to the cynics was typically robust. He said she was one who sought above all to help vulnerable people in society.

The role brought great power but, like any member of the Royal Family, she also experienced the weight of expectation and the intensity of the scrutiny. Honoring but managing the role and not allowing it to take over ones personal humanity is a desperately difficult task. As we have heard from Prince Harry, his mother Diana did all that she could to prepare her sons for the work which lies ahead.

The love of Christ described in the lesson read by Prince William contains the essence of the spiritual life. Princess Diana recognized this quality of life in many of those, like John, whose lives she touched. It was a mystery which resonated deeply with her and for which she reached out.

10 years after her tragic death, there are regular reports of fury at this or that incident. Let this service mark the point at which we let her rest in peace and dwell on her memory with thanksgiving and compassion. Let us also, echoing the words of Prince Harry, look to the future and pray for all those who serve our country as members of the Royal Family.

French foreign minister Bernard Kouchner has a reputation for challenging convention and authority. A surprise appointment from the Socialist ranks to Nicolas Sarkozys conservative government, the founder of Medicins Sans Frontiers has always challenged convention. He said that France had to prepare for the possibility of war against Iran over its nuclear program. He also said that the world should be prepared for war with Iran.

Kouchner is a humanitarian as well as a patriot, with a strong commitment to human rights. Unusually for a man of the Left, he supported the USled intervention in Iraq while criticizing the aftermath. But he did so on the grounds of Saddam Husseins denial of human rights, not his possible possession of weapons of mass destruction.

His and President Sarkozys concern for human rights lies behind their eagerness to join Gordon Browns Britain in a new push for action in Darfur. Washington, which has been critical of some European states for their weakness in confronting Teheran, will have been delighted by his warning. How much should be made of his words on Iran remains unclear at this stage.

Kouchner is making clear that France no longer takes the view once expressed by President Chirac that a nucleararmed Iran might be inevitable. On Iran he is, in a way, merely echoing the words of his President who declared in a speech last month that anucleararmed Iran would beunacceptable. Mr Kouchner became the first French Foreign Minister to visit Iraq since 1988, insisting that there could only be a political solution to the countrys problems, not a military one.

In continuing to ratchet up the rhetoric over that threat and to underline the Wests resolution on Irans nuclear enrichment program Mr Kouchner is supplementing his presidents warnings. Neither is saying that military intervention against Iran is imminent or inevitable. Neither has yet confirmed that France would be part of any such military action. Both are stressing the risks which are piling up as a result of Teherans brinkmanship.

Für Elise was originally titled Bagatelle in A minor based on some handwritten notation a Beethoven researcher claimed to have seen on a nowlost copy of the sheet music. Bob Dylan wrote It Aint Me, Babe for Joan Baez.

The 1975 song remains one of the most popular disco hits ever. Written for Billie Jean King, as a thankyou for a tracksuit she gave Elton. Brown University adopted an 867 exchange number for its oncampus phone system. Room No. 5309 became a magnet for every drunk college kid with a 1980s fetish. The holder of 2128675309 put his phone number up for auction on eBay in 2004. Bids approached 100,000 before eBay pulled the item.

Sedaka and King actually dated briefly in high school. Oh, Carol was a then top10 if now somewhat forgettable 1959 pop song. It inspired King to write a rebuttal entitled Oh, Neil. Sedaka was able to successfully milk the song's success.

King and Goffin landed jobs at the legendary Brill Building pop music factory. The duo went on to write charttoppers like Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow and The LocoMotion. It Aint Me, Babe Written for Joan Baez, though it clearly wasnt the nicest gift Dylan could have given her.

In December 1968, Nash and Mitchell moved into a cozy little house in the Laurel Canyon section of Los Angeles. Though commonly left out of the hippy pantheon, Laurel Canyon was sort of a communehome away from San Francisco society for CSNY, Jim Morrison, the Eagles, Frank Zappa, and more.

Our House was directly inspired by a lazy Sunday in the NashMitchell household. The couple went out to brunch, hit an antiques store, and then returned to find the house just a bit chilly. Nash literally lit a fire, while Mitchell placed the flowers in the vase that she bought that day. The whole tableau seemed so ridiculously domestic to Nash that he immediately sat down and spent the rest of the day writing about it.

The cost to try to influence the 2008 election could exceed 3 billion. Just about every candidate running for an office from dogcatcher to president is spending the money. The costs to produce a TV commercial are no longer prohibitive for local and state candidates. In 2006, 2.3 billion was spent on political and issueadvocacy TV commercials.

Interest groups have spent 6.2 million on TV ads so far this year for state and local ballot measures. Subjects ranged from the Iraq war to telecommunications reform. Television ads on health care alone total 60 million.

CMAG estimates more than 3 million of the 270 million spent to air issueadvocacy ads this year has gone for commercials in competitive House and Senate races. Up to now, the political commercials have been largely focused on the early states of Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina. With 17 Democratic and Republican candidates running for president, more than 800 million will be spent on TV ads in the battle for the White House.

Romney has aired his commercials more than 11,000 times this year at a cost of nearly 8.6 million. This is a record for the number of airings at this point in a presidential election cycle. In contrast, one of Romneys chief rivals, former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani, has spent nothing on television ads.

Giuliani enjoys widespread national name recognition, while Romney does not. In the race for the Democratic nomination, Barack Obama has spent more than 2.3 million on television commercials. Hillary Clinton has spent 1 million less and leads in both national and early state polls. Bill Richardson has probably benefited the most in the Democratic contest.

Romney is leading polls in the early voting states of Iowa and New Hampshire. An American Research Group poll of South Carolina Republicans in August showed Romney registering at 9 percent. A month later, and with 350,000 worth of commercials aired in the two weeks leading up to the next poll, Romney was up 17 percentage points.

Romneys latest ad began airing Friday in Iowa, and in it he vows to stop Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons. All of these issues should play well with conservatives who participate in the Iowa caucuses. While only a handful of Democratic candidates and Romney have used the airwaves until now, Tracey said he expects this to change. Before the end of October, I suspect all the frontrunner candidates will be on the air.

In the fight for Congress, CMAG predicts that as much as 639 million could be spent on television advertising. Tracey noted that CMAGs 2008 election cycle forecast does not take into account unforeseen events such as former Florida Rep. Mark Foleys House page scandal.

Voters will be numb after watching hundred and hundreds of ads, says Stuart Rothenberg. After a while, the ads just become lots of chatter, he says. An ad will have to be really good to cut through the noise, he adds. The sheer number of ads probably dilutes their importance.

The OneTwoGo jet crashed in bad weather as it landed at Phukets airport on Sunday. Most of those killed were foreign nationals, and about 36 of the bodies still have yet to be identified. U.S. officials had previously confirmed that four Americans died in the crash, and one survived.

Foreign Secretary David Miliband says eight British nationals are believed to have died. Thailands Public Health Minister Mongkol Na Songkhla said that of the 41 survivors who remain hospitalized, 38 were in stable condition and three in critical condition. Flight 269 was carrying 123 passengers and seven crew members when it left Bangkok for Phuket on Sunday.

Buddhist, Christian and Muslim leaders gathered outside Phukets airport on Tuesday to remember those killed. For some families, DNA testing may be the only way to positively identify their relatives. The investigation into what caused the crash continues, but strong winds and rain are a suspected factor.

U.S. officials are aiding in the investigation because the aircraft was manufactured in the United States. Air traffic controller at Phuket airport said pilots were warned of possible wind shear. Airport officials said that the wind at the time of the crash was 17 kilometers an hour 11 miles an hour with stronger gusts. No planes were delayed or diverted because of the weather conditions.

OneTwoGo is one of about 40 lowcost airlines operating in Asia. The industry will be watching closely for the results of the investigation into the crash. OneTwoGo officials would not speculate on what may have happened. But they did say their aircraft were regularly checked and maintained, and denied some media reports that questioned whether the discount airline employed more inexperienced pilots.

Michael Moore and CNNs Sanjay Gupta argued Tuesday about Guptas report on Moores film Sicko Moore criticized a report Gupta did on CNN Monday on Sicko. He said the facts were fudged, Moore said, referring to Gupta, on CNNs Larry King Live.

Some Democrats appear to be wavering on a highly contentious House resolution labeling Turkeys treatment of Armenians in World War I as genocide.

Turkey is incensed by the resolution calling the killing of Armenians by Ottoman Turks genocide. It threatened to block access to Incirlik Air Base after the resolution passed a House committee vote. The base, in southern Turkey near Syria, is a major resupply center for U.S. operations in Iraq and elsewhere in the Mideast and Asia.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said she would bring the measure to a vote of the full House sometime next month. Majority Leader Steny Hoyer signaled Tuesday that the vote might be put off. Bush administration urged Congress to drop the issue. Some leading Democrats urged Pelosi not to bring it to the floor.

Democratic Reps. Alcee Hastings and John Tanner urge Pelosi to reconsider. More than half of the cargo flown into Iraq and Afghanistan comes through Incirlik Air Base. Pentagon planners are looking at a broad range of options to keep food, fuel and ammunition flowing to U.S. troops in Iraq if Turkey blocks the air base, an official says. The House Armed Services Committee chairman announced his opposition to the resolution last week.

Defense Secretary Robert Gates echoed lawmakers concerns last week. About 70 percent of all air cargo going into Iraq goes through Turkey. 95 percent of the MineResistant AmbushProtective vehicles, or MRAPs, are deployed in Iraq. About a third of the fuel that they consume go through Turkey or comes from Turkey.

The U.S. military issued a warning order a few days ago to ensure that alternative air crews, planes, fuel and routes are lined up. Jordan and Kuwait are among the alternatives the United States is considering. Some fear pursuit of the resolution would also embolden the Turks to attack Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq.

Incirlik offers 10,000 and 9,000foot runways and 57 hardened aircraft shelters. Globalsecurity.org: Incirlik has become a hub for cargo shipments to Iraq. It took over for RheinMain Air Base in Germany because it is closer to Iraq, reducing the strain on troops and aircraft, it says. The U.S. military says it has no immediate plans to pull troops out of Iraq.
Mohammed stops at his cousins grave. "I feel an ache when I think of her. Every time I remember her, I cry," he says. As he spoke, he poured water on a tree he planted next to it.

India has elected its first female president, official results show. Pratibha Patil, 72, is the ruling coalitions nominee for the mainly ceremonial post. Patil easily beat oppositionbacked challenger and vice president, Bhairon Singh Shekhawat, in a vote by the national parliament and state politicians. This a victory of the people, Patil told reporters after official results were announced.

Patil won about two thirds of the electoral college votes. She emerged on the national stage when the Congressled coalition and its communist allies failed to agree on a joint candidate. Supporters hoped Patils candidacy would help bring issues that plague women in India, like dowryrelated violence, into the public spotlight. For the first time we have a woman being elected president of India, Congress party leader Sonia Gandhi, Indias most powerful politician, said.

Patil supporters took to the streets, singing and dancing as others lit fire crackers and beat large brass drums. A woman is murdered, raped or abused every three minutes on average in India. India has had a number of female icons in the past most famously Sonia Gandhis motherinlaw, Indira. But hope Patils presidency would spark only positive talk about womens influence in India evaporated when it emerged the bank for women she helped established was closed in 2003.

The employees union has taken Patil and others to court, claiming loans meant for poor women were given to her brother. She was also accused of trying to shield her brother in a murder inquiry. Prime Minister Manmohan Singh has dismissed accusations against her as mudslinging.

She managed to offend many minority Muslims, and anger some historians. She claimed she had experienced a divine premonition that she was destined for higher office from a long dead spiritual guru. Critics also dug up a comment she was said to have made as Maharashtras health minister in 1975, saying people with hereditary diseases should be sterilized. More than 100 homes in an upscale San Diego community were evacuated after a landslide.

Officials warned for at least two weeks that the ground was shifting beneath the hillside community along Soledad Mountain Road. Mayor Jerry Sanders declared a state of emergency, asking California and the federal government to help the La Jolla community recover from the Wednesday landslide. As of Thursday morning, he had already received offers of aid from legislators, the governors office and the White House.

On Wednesday, a 20footdeep chasm opened beneath the road and homes. Holli Weld said she was walking her son to preschool when the street collapsed. Authorities told KGTV that most residents were at work and only seven people were in their homes.

At least 111 homes were evacuated. Residents will be allowed to return to 75 of those houses by early Thursday morning. The asphalt that should be under my feet was 8 feet in the air, Russell Moore says. "We watched the trees snapping and cracking and more boulders come down to our feet," he says.

Several homes were damaged and at least one was destroyed, according to media reports. Nine homes are red tagged, meaning no one is allowed to enter them, and 27 more are yellow tagged. More than 2,400 customers were briefly left without electricity, but most residents had their power restored by Thursday.

Deputy city engineer Robert Hawk told the UnionTribune that the hillside has slowly been slipping for years because the soil is unstable. Dennis Schmitt found an island nearly two years ago near Greenland. The island was once thought to be a peninsula attached to Greenland by an ice shelf or a glacier. But such a large amount of ice melted, it revealed the distinct island.

Many climatologists and scientists say arctic ice melt and other changes in the Earths climate are the result of an increase in the worlds temperature, a trend widely called global warming. He calls his discovery Warming Island. He told CNNs Anderson Cooper during a visit to the island earlier this year.

Many global warming experts say the phenomenon, if unchecked, is capable of altering the worlds climate and geography. Other scientists and observers, a minority compared to those who believe the warming trend is something ominous, say it is simply the latest shift in the cyclical patterns of a planets life.

The Earths temperature averages about 60 degrees Fahrenheit about 16 degrees Celsius. The average surface temperature has warmed one degree Fahrenheit 0.6 degrees Celsius during the last century. There are several possible reasons for the warming, scientists say.

Greenhouse gases are in the atmosphere naturally and help keep the planets temperature at a comfortable level. The amount of carbon dioxide in the. atmosphere, for instance, has increased by 35 percent since the dawn of the industrial age. The presence of methane is now 151 percent above preindustrial levels, but the rate of increase has slowed in recent decades. Meanwhile, nitrous oxide increased by about 18 percent during the past 200 years.

Many scientists and experts believe the increase is primarily the result of human activities, like the burning of fossil fuels, emissions from vehicles and the clearing of forests. For the last 30 years, theres no way theres anything natural that can explain it, Stephen Schneider, a professor of environmental studies at Stanford University in California, said. A vast bulk of the knowledgeable and honest community... will say the science is settled and humans are at least a majority of the reason behind the warming, he added.

Weve suddenly taken to reading tea leaves, he said. When we saw cooling from 1940 to 1970, we were proclaiming global cooling. Since then, theres been a few tenths of global warming, so were proclaimingglobal warming. He believes the current warming trend is the result of natural variability.

Lindzen says the way glaciers change and move are largely unexplained. Yet, for Schneider, it is a cause for concern and alarm. What were doing is cherry picking any event that occurs and then saying thats occurring due to global warming, he said.
Were already in serious melt, nobody can explain it. The models dont predict it, he said. All we know is that we could be triggering something really nasty.

The IPCC in February 2007 projected that if carbon dioxide levels doubled relative to preindustrial levels, temperatures could rise between 3.6 to 8.1 degrees Fahrenheit 2 to 4.5 degrees Celsius by 2100. Uncertainties, however, plague such forecasts, which are based on computer simulations and models.

The chief operating officer of the National Childrens Museum was arrested Tuesday. He is charged with distributing child pornography over the Internet. Singer is accused of sending images depicting child pornography to people he believed to be a 12-year-old girl. In reality he was communicating with an undercover detective for the New York Police Department.

Singer, 49, was arrested at his home in Falls Church, Virginia, by federal agents. Authorities allege he engaged in several instant messaging chats and email communications with the undercover detective, posing as the woman and her daughter. Some of the pornographic images were sent from Singers computer at the museum, according to an affidavit filed in support of the charges.

Singer is charged with five counts of distributing child pornography in interstate commerce. If convicted on each count, he would face a sentence of up to 140 years in prison. He is identified in the complaint as a spokesman for the National Childrens Museum. He has been employed by the museum for four years, a spokeswoman says. The museum says it was notified by the Department of Homeland Security and ICE of Singers arrest.

The museum, formerly known as the Capital Childrens Museum, has been closed to the public since 2004. It operates from administrative offices, the statement says. "Harming children is against everything we stand for as an organization and as individuals," it says.

Senate approves Michael Mukasey's nomination for attorney general by 5340 to 5340 vote. Mukaseys views on waterboarding threatened to derail the approval of President Bushs nominee to lead the Justice Department. He would replace longtime ally Alberto Gonzales, who resigned in September.

Wine Library TV host Gary Vaynerchuk discusses four spooky wine varieties for Halloween show. Of a wild and gamey red from Rioja, Spain, he says, Hit a deer on the road. Throw a bunch of cherries on it. Take out your knife, cut the deer.

About 40,000 Internet viewers  many of them 20somethings  have a daily appointment with Wine Library TV. The lowbudget video blog is produced five days a week from a nondescript office in the threelevel wine retail operation that Vaynerchuks family owns in Springfield, New Jersey. Yet he stuffs his patter with sports and popculture references.

The mission of wine sites like Wine Library TV, say several of the people behind these new outlets, is to demystify wine and in some cases, sell it, too. Using the language, attitude and new media that appeal to a young, techsavvy generation, they advocate trusting ones own palate rather than obeying powerful wine critics. Some of the sites also provide opportunities for average wine drinkers to share their opinions.

CellarTracker.com, an online wine community, appeals to more established wine collectors. The site provides free software designed by Eric LeVine, a fortuitously named former Microsoft software developer.

Corkd.com already had 40,000 users when Vaynerchuk purchased the site last year. The free service allows users to catalog and review wines. Instead of having friends as on Facebook, members identify drinking buddies and check out what theyre drinking. The site counts 6 million bottles in their virtual cellars.

In the growing presence of wine fans on the Internet  newbies as well as connoisseurs. Vaynerchuk sees a movement. Theyre part of forums, they meet up offline, he says. Its about bringing people together. Its all thats right about wine.

On a recent rainy afternoon, Vaynerchuk barreled, unrehearsed and unscripted, through a 20minute show in a single take. He wrapped up Wine Library TV episode No. 337 with what has become his signature line.

The article quotes Orville Tranby, a local community leader in Cooperstown. He says that some residents have told him face to face that such facilities might attract Hispanic immigrants who could change the local culture.

A local library employee came up with the radical idea of a bilingual story time. Townspeople wanted no part of that. They demanded that all books purchased by the library, or even donated, be in Englishonly.

The perception that the country is becoming more Hispanic, that Spanish is replacing English, and that Hispanic immigrants are weakening American identity. A leader of the vigilante Minuteman movement moronically called it the colonization of the United States. This sort of rhetoric is all about fear  that those who thrive in the dominant culture are losing their primacy, that the mainstream is being polluted by foreigners. It conjures up the alarm bells that Benjamin Franklin set off about German immigrants in the late 18th century.

It popped up in the mid19th century amid worries that Chinese immigrants were unassimilable. And it helped welcome the 20th century when Massachusetts Sen. Henry Cabot Lodge warned that immigrants read the Irish were diluting the quality of U.S. citizenship. Where have we heard that before? And when will we hear it again?

The SOTG was conducting an operation to clear an identified Taliban bomb making facility in Uruzgan province, when the soldier was hit by small arms fire. 18-year-old shot eight people inside his high school in southern Finland, before turning the gun on himself. Police confirmed the dead numbered two girls, five boys and the schools headmistress. The shooting appeared to have been planned out in graphic videos posted on Internet filesharing site YouTube, police said.

Police identify the shooter as Pekka Eric Auvinen. He took his own life, police say. Ten other people were taken to a hospital with minor injuries. It was the first school shooting in Finland since 1989.

Auvinen published a manifesto online demanding war on the weakminded masses. YouTube appeared to have removed 89 videos linked to his account, many of them featuring Nazi imagery. Finnish media reported someone posted a message two weeks ago, warning of a bloodbath at the school.

A video posted earlier Wednesday, by Sturmgeist89, was titled Jokela High School Massacre  1172007. The video showed a picture of the school, which then disintegrated to reveal two images of Auvinen against a red background, pointing a gun at the screen. Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, the students behind the 1999 Columbine High School massacre, also cited that groups lyrics.

Another short video clip, called Just Testing My Gun, showed Auvinen loading and cocking a handgun. He fired and hit several pieces of fruit in a wooded area the camera then showed a closeup of the destroyed fruit, and then a fullscreen shot of him again. The site indicated that the youth appeared to be fascinated with killing.

Many showed victims being wheeled away or people running for their lives. Throughout all of this, the single word DIE constantly flashed across the screen. In the rambling text posted on the site, Auvinen said that he is a cynical existentialist, antihuman humanist, antisocial socialDarwinist and godlike atheist.

Police say they were fired at when they arrived at the school. They described the scene as chaotic, with some of the 460 students, ranging in age from 12 to 18, breaking windows in an attempt to escape. When the polices special SWAT unit entered the high school they found the gunman unconscious and in critical condition in the lower lobby of the building. Police assume he tried to take his own life as no officers fired at him.

Several bodies were also found in the same location, where the shooting is believed to have begun. Police also said that the gun Auvinen used, which was fully licensed, had been purchased less than a month ago on October 19. He had a recommendation from a shooting club when he obtained the gun, police added.

Finland, which enjoys a strong tradition of hunting, has a high proportion of gun ownership. Two million firearms owned in a nation of only five million. Teacher Kim Kiuru described how the headmistress used the public address system to tell pupils to stay in classrooms. He said he locked his classroom door, then waited in the corridor for more news.
