Warren Jeffs, the leader and socalled prophet of the 10,000member Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, is now awaiting sentencing. Jeffs was convicted on two counts of being an accomplice to rape. Documents indicate that Jeffs confessed to immorality with a sister and a daughter more than 30 years ago. On January 28, the report said, he attempted to hang himself in his cell.

In the days following the suicide attempt, while he was on suicide watch, Jeffs on separate occasions threw himself against the wall and banged his head on the wall. Jail transcripts show that Jeffs suicide attempt came three days after a visit with his brother.

The day before that, Jeffs told a follower in a phone conversation that he was covered with immorality with a sister and a daughter when I was younger. Jeffs defense attorneys, who argued against the release of the documents, said in a motion opposing the unsealing of the statements that Jeffs recanted them the following month.

Jeffs, 51, was convicted in September of being an accomplice to rape. He was accused of using his religious influence over his followers to coerce a 14yearold girl into marriage to her 19yearold cousin. He faces a sentence of up to life in prison when he is sentenced November 20.

Jeffs was on the FBIs 10 most wanted fugitives list when he was arrested in August 2006 outside Las Vegas, Nevada. Critics say that inside the FLDS, marriages are arranged for girls as young as 13. If male followers are excommunicated, critics claim, wives and children can be reassigned.

Two of his followers who spoke to CNN said they do not believe he made the statements. He is a perfectly priestly man, said a woman who identified herself as Cathy. Her husband, Patrick, told CNN, Its hogwash.

Lewis Hamilton spun out of the Chinese Grand Prix in Shanghai. The Briton saw his 12-point title lead cut to four by Fernando Alonso. The world title race goes to a cliffhanger finale in Brazil on October 21. Hamilton can still clinch the crown with third place in the closing race.

The Spaniard finished second behind Ferraris Kimi Raikkonen, who also kept his title hopes alive by moving within seven points of Hamilton. The young Briton started the race in pole position and at one stage led Raikkenson by more than eight seconds as he again showed superb skills in the wet conditions. However, the 22-year-old stayed out on the drying track too long in his wet tires, which deteriorated at an alarming rate. Hamilton spun out onto the gravel to end his chances with 25 laps to go.

Raikkones teammate Felipe Massa was third, while fourth place was claimed by Toro Rossos Sebastien Vettel. Hamilton was last week reprimanded for causing an accident in Japan behind the safety car while Hamilton was cleared of any wrongdoing. Jenson Button was fifth in a Honda ahead of Vettels teammate Vitantonio Liuzzi. Nick Heidfeld was seventh for BMW Sauber and David Coulthard of Scotland took the final point for Red Bull.

We were having a great race and we didnt know if it was going to rain or not. The tyres were getting worse and worse and you could almost see the canvas underneath. But I am over it and we look forward to Brazil.

McLaren boss Ron Dennis refused to blame his driver or his team for the spinoff. It has been a very competitive season between our drivers and it will go on for another Grand Prix. I dont think we did anything dramatically wrong and neither did Lewis.

Alonso is seeking to become the third driver to win three world titles. The Spaniard qualified for the race in fourth place on the grid. He said: "The circuit was considerably drier than the pit lane entrance. Thats what made the difference"

The result was good today and the eight points are a help for sure. I think the championship will still be very difficult because I know it will not be easy to take four points from Lewis. I need something dramatic if I want to win. With a normal race it will be impossible.

CNN will be hosting three events looking at modern strategies in todays business arena. The CNN Boardroom Master classes will take place in the homes of the worlds largest stock markets. Sheikh Mohammed bin Isa Al Khalifa is the chief executive of the Economic Development Board. He is concerned the nuclear dispute with Iran is deterring potential investors. The governments pushing ahead with economic reforms to reduce the Kingdoms dependence on oil. But with crude prices near 100 a barrel, John Defterios asked whether the appetite for change had diminished.

The reforms are being done for aspirational reasons rather than necessity. Traditionally its been a financial center, but you have Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Dubai even Abu Dhabi emerging in financial services. How do you redefine it to sustain a lead?

Bahrain's strengths have been and will continue to be its human capital, the people that have led the financial sector and the long standing regulations that have been established in Bahrain. We feel that the distraction caused by the Iranian nuclear issue is holding investment back in the region as a whole, and increasing the security threat. Nobody is debating the right to peaceful nuclear power, but we all have that need and we all need a peaceful resolution to this.

Gulf Cooperation Council has resolved its historical issue with Iran, but is now looking forward to the future. "This is such a important issue affecting security worldwide, that we feel it is important and at a level high enough that we need all powers involved," says Bahrain's foreign minister. "We are well beyond that, but going forward...

Sheikh Mohammed bin Isa Al Khalifa is chief executive of the Economic Development Board. The board is responsible for stimulating and supporting growth of the Bahraini economy. He was appointed in June 2005, following 10 years working directly for His Highness Sheikh Salman bin Hamad al Khalifa, Crown Prince of Bahrain.

From 1995 to 1999, he was director of the Crown Princes office. Sheikh Mohammed is married with two sons and one daughter. A keen motor sports enthusiast, he is a former vice president of the Bahrain Motor Club. He was born on April 14, 1969, in Manama, Bahrain.

In 1992, he received a bachelors degree in economic theory from the American University, Washington DC. Two years later, he got a postgraduate diploma in business studies from the London School of Economics. He is a graduate of the Bahrain Economic Development Board and the University of Bahrain.

Two suspected car bombs struck Algiers within 10 minutes of each other. Official government count is at least 26, but hospital sources say 76 people were killed. Interior minister blames a militant Islamic group with ties to al Qaeda for the attacks. In a posting on an Islamist Web site, the group al Qaeda Islamic Maghreb claimed responsibility.

The Web site is known to carry messages, claims and videos from al Qaeda and other militant groups. It said two trucks were filled with no less than 800 kg 1,763 pounds of explosives. At least 10 U.N. staffers were among those killed, according to a U.S. spokeswoman. The group called the operation another successful conquest and a second epic.

The offices of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees were leveled by a blast that struck about 930 a.m. U.N. SecretaryGeneral Ban Kimoon condemned what he called an abjectly cowardly strike against civilian officials serving humanitys highest ideals. Rescuers are working into the night trying to get to the trapped U.S. workers.

Most of those killed in the coordinated attacks were victims of the first suspected car bombing. That blast struck a bus outside the targeted building, killing many of those on board. One man said he heard the first blast then the second exploded in front of him. He said he has sent senior advisers and other top U.N. officials to head to Algiers.

I saw the trees falling and the glass shattering in front of me. I had to run away from the car, he said. Zerhouni said the attack was the work of the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat GSPC. That group also uses the name al Qaeda Islamic Maghreb after merging with al Qaeda.

Algerian guerrillas and al Qaeda in North Africa have merged. The goal is to destabilize countries like Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia. The Constitutional Council and Supreme Court were on a list of GSPC targets. Algeria is still recovering from more than a decade of violence that began after the military government called a halt to elections which an Islamist party was poised to win. Tens of thousands of people died in the unrest.

Lionel Messi scored for the sixth game in a row as Barcelona defeated bigspending Atletico Madrid 30. Arjen Robben: "We are now top for the next two weeks and can build on that when we return"

The Valenciabased club are bottom of the table with only a point from seven matches. Next week they have something completely new to contend with. Fuji Speedway has yet to see a single F1 team put in a single lap. The new circuit is expected to be completed by the end of the year or early 2015.

Fuji Speedway was the setting for the 1982 arcade game Pole Position released by Namco in Japan and Atari in the rest of the world. The most notable aspect of the circuit is the vision of Mount Fuji, Japans tallest mountain, looming in the distance. The move to this picturesque location is not without its controversies.

The Japanese Grand Prix will be held at Fuji this year and the next. Suzuka will return to the calendar for 2009 on the condition that the circuit makes some approved modifications. Behind the scenes is a political battleground  both circuits are owned by car manufacturers with F1 connections. Honda owns Suzuka, Toyota owns Fuji. The redesign of the Fuji track was carried out by Hermann Tilke in 2003. Toyota is a relative newcomer to F1 but, having this year surpassed General Motors as the worlds number one automobile manufacturer.

Tilke, a German architect redesigned a number of F1 circuits in the 1990s. He has since designed many new grand prix tracks including Malaysia, Istanbul, Bahrain and Shanghai. Computeraided design CAD is as much a part of the design of a circuit these days as it is of the hightech cars. Every bend, every straight and every camber is fastidiously analyzed on screen before an ounce of dirt is shifted.

BMW Saubers simulation experts received CAD data from the Japanese race organizers late last year. The circuit was analyzed and broken up into between 500 and 800 segments. The radius of each individual segment was measured, allowing the engineers to exactly calculate the optimum racing line.

The slightest change in angle of a gradient can have significant effects on the downforce and aerodynamic profile of a car. We need to have as accurate as possible a picture of downforce levels, gearbox ratios and brake specification in advance, says Willy Rampf, Technical Director of the BMW Sauber F1 Team.

Once you know that, you look into which gear ratios suit the track with the given level of downforce. Getting a bit closer to the weekend, you start running race simulations in order to predict the optimum race strategy. This prediction takes into account estimates of relevant characteristics of the new track, like the degradation of the two Bridgestone tire compounds. If you have more fuel in the car, this affects your lap time, but we can accurately predict how much time is lost with every extra kilogram of fuel carried.

The teams have to find a balance between getting the most speed into the straight, and the best grip decelerating into the bends. Our aim is to ensure that the lap times and top speed calculated using the simulation software do not vary by more than one percent from the actual values, says Rampf. Not that everything can be predicted I think we are quite accurate but the ultimate response to that is very difficult to say for sure because it very much depends on what happens in the race.

Celtic have been fined 50,800 by UEFA and AC Milans Dida has been banned for two matches. The incident occurred when the Scottish side beat Milan 21 in Glasgow. Milan have pledged to appeal against the punishment, which as it stands means he will miss the clubs Champions League games against Shakhtar Donetsk. Celtic chief executive Peter Lawwell said As a club we feel this penalty is proportionate to the incident in question and a fair outcome. White House is blasting Congressional Democrats for not sending a bill that would fund veterans care programs to the presidents desk by Veterans Day.

Democrats added 3.7 billion to what the president budgeted for veterans programs. The president has threatened to veto the bill because of the added spending. The House passed a healthlaboreducation bill 269142 last week with the veterans funding attached, but the Senate later voted to strip out the funding.

Perino accused the Democrats of trying to hold hostage our veterans to extra domestic spending or increases in taxes. The president wants clean legislation, a clean bill to fund the veterans, Perino said. On Saturday, the Democratic congressional leadership sent a letter to President Bush saying they welcomed a dialogue on spending. The leadership said last years Congress, which was still under Republican control, had never passed a separate bill funding veterans programs.

Congress also sent to the president legislation that would fund veterans care at the levels requested by the president through December 14. The current funding level is still below the 3.9 billion extra that we passed, said Nadeam Elshami, spokesman Pelosi. We are committed to getting the extra funding that the Congress already voted on the presidents desk for his signature.

The Democrats decided not to send the president this bill, Perino said. That has to be laid at their feet. Muddy but unhurt, three University of Texas students emerged from a cramped cave complex in Austin, Texas, after a daylong search.

Two women and one man were reported missing early Sunday after a trip into Airmans Cave. They were found about halfway down the 12,000footlong cave. The cave has few spaces big enough for an adult to stand upright and is explored primarily by experienced spelunkers.

A friend called 911 to report them missing at 5 a.m. Sunday. The group had told friends to call 911 if they were not back by midnight Sunday. Authorities did not know Sunday evening why the students were in the cave for so long.

There are so many ways to go, he said. Gen. Than Shwe and his deputies are a friendless regime, Bush said. They should step aside to make way for a unified Burma Myanmar governed by legitimate leaders, she said. The former U.S. first lady made a rare foray into foreign policy.

The rest of the armed forces should not fear this transition  there is room for a professional military in a democratic Burma, Bush said. Bush called on Myanmars military leaders to release Aun Sung Suu Kyi and other opposition leaders so they can meet with and plan for a transition to democracy. Meanwhile, the world watches  and waits, Bush warns.

Myanmar state media has reported that 2,000 people were detained during the demonstrations and the crackdown against them. The official death toll from Myanmars leadership is at 10, but there are reports that hundreds were killed and thousands arrested in the wake of the demonstrations that peaked late September. The time for a free Burma is now.

U.N. SecretaryGeneral Ban Kimoon called Laura Bush to update her on the efforts of his special envoy to Myanmar, Ibrahim Gambari. Gambari met last week with the military junta leadership as well as with Nobel Peace Prize winner Suu Kyi, who is under house arrest in Yangon. The U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Zalmay Khalilzad, told reporters that Laura Bush and her husbands administration believe that there is a need to start preparing for transition.

Bush accuses Democratic leaders of wasting money and plotting tax increases. Congress should cut spending and send me a responsible measure, he says. The bill would have funded the departments of Labor, Education, and Health and Human Services. It also would have funding projects such as a prison museum, a sailing school and a program to teach Portuguese.  President Bush said the bill was laden with 10 billion in pork.

The bill includes about 150 billion to run those departments. The bill also includes more than 450 billion in mandatory spending on Medicare and Medicaid. While polls show Bushs popularity remains at nearrecord lows, Congress ranks even lower as a whole. The president has taken numerous opportunities to mock the spending habits of the Democratic leadership and force confrontations over the appropriations bills.

The committees chairman, Rep. David Obey, called Bushs veto not responsible and not credible. This is a bipartisan bill supported by over 50 Republicans, Obey said in a statement issued after the veto. It is clear the only reason the president vetoed this bill is pure politics, he said.

Tuesday's veto is the fifth cast since Democrats took control of Congress in 2006. Congress has overridden one of those, voting last week to authorize 23 billion in water projects nationwide over the presidents objections. Democrats will schedule another override vote this week, an aide to House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer said.

Bush signed a 470 billion Pentagon spending bill that covers the Defense Departments normal operations. Democrats split 50 billion in spending for the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan off into a bridge fund to which they plan to attach demands for Bush to withdraw U.S. combat troops. The measure sets up another confrontation with the White House. Bush also demanded Congress reform the alternative minimum tax.

Congress should eliminate the tax increases in the bill and send the AMT relief to my desk as soon as possible. The elimination of the tax would cause an estimated 800 billion to be lost over 10 years. To replace that, Rangels bill would add a 4 percent surtax on individual incomes over 100,000.

Bush: Raising taxes is one of the most unwise things Congress could possibly do. Bush acknowledged the difficulties Americans face from high fuel prices, a challenged housing market and uncertainty in financial markets stemming from the collapse of the subprime mortgage market. England seeking to become the first nation to defend the World Cup title. Jonny Wilkinson again had problems with the match balls during the semifinal. We didnt say it last week but a nonmatch ball got onto the field in Marseille which Jonny kicked, director of rugby Rob Andrew said. He didnt think about it while he was kicking it. Colorado man terrorized by threats after testifying against his daughters abusive boyfriend. Keith Reynolds was convicted for witness intimidation after threatening witnesses in his domestic assault case. Man has spent 10,000 on a security system, hired a bodyguard for his sons wedding and never leaves home without a.45caliber handgun strapped to his chest. The state did nothing to protect him after the 1999 conviction of Keith Reynolds for domestic abuse.

A report in the Denver Post pointed out major problems protecting witnesses in the state of Colorado. Paul Logli, chairman of National District Attorneys Association, told Congress this year that witness intimidation has become almost epidemic. When asked if prosecutors had made the family aware of Colorados witness protection program, the witness in the Reynolds case said, All they told us was maybe we should move.

After Reynolds conviction, the witness and his wife saw strange cars parked outside their home. They received phone calls during which the only sound on the other end of the line was a gun being cocked. The couple received a death threat from Reynolds himself through the mail.

Reynolds was then sentenced to ten years in a maximum security prison for witness intimidation. No national statistics on crimes against witnesses exist, and minimal research has been conducted on the subject. Colorado has 50,000 allocated to its witness protection budget.

The city of Denver spent almost 100,000 on landscaping last year. The state, on average, spends about 1,000 per witness. The federal program spends in excess of 40 million per year on witness protection.

The Rev. Leon Kelly says Colorado's witness protection program is a joke. Kelly says the state does not provide enough incentive for witnesses to come forward. Colorado Department of Public Safety: Witness protection is a way to ensure the immediate safety of the witnesses, not a long-term relocation at the publics expense.

Rhonda Fields says failures in the witness protection program may have contributed to her sons murder. Javad Fields was a college graduate who was engaged to be married. He was shot twice in the head by men he considered friends.

Javad Fields witnessed the murder of his best friend and subsequently testified against three men suspected in the killing. Rhonda Fields says her son was never told about a witness protection program.

Javads mother does not think it was her sons responsibility to ask for protection. I think its the authorities responsibility to notify witnesses of the dangers that are involved with being a witness.

Fields case illustrates glaring weaknesses in the witness protection program. Prosecutors filed an order for protection requesting Javad Fields personal information be kept secret. It wasnt signed by a judge until one year later, after defense lawyers had already given the suspects Fields' personal information. District Attorney Carol Chambers maintains the program has improved.

Previously unseen footage of Diana has been shown to the jury at the inquest into her death. Images taken from a security camera at the Ritz Hotel in Paris show the 36yearold smiling as she and her lover Dodi Fayed step into an elevator. Further footage shows Fayed visiting a jewelers shop, images that could lend support to claims that he was buying an engagement ring.

Lord Justice Scott Baker told the jury at the inquest into the deaths of the princess and her lover Dodi Fayed that scientific evidence might be unable to demonstrate one way or the other whether she was in the early stages of pregnancy. But he said they would hear intimate details of her personal life. Baker said Diana may have been on the contraceptive pill and evidence she was poised to get engaged to Dodi on the night she died was contradictory.

The jury is set to hear scene setting evidence, including CCTV and a tourist video. The inquest to establish cause of death is expected to be a sixmonth process. Fayeds father, Mohammed Al Fayed, has contended that Diana and his son were murdered because the royal family could not accept that an Egyptian Muslim could eventually be stepfather to the future king of England.

Baker told the jury of Al Fayeds allegations, but again reminded them that they were responsible for deciding the facts of the case. You have to decide four important, but limited factual questions. The first three questions are unlikely to give rise to any difficulty. The fourth is a rather wider question and is directed towards the means by which they died.

Diana, 36, and Dodi Fayed were killed on August 31, 1997 when the MercedesBenz they were traveling in hit a pillar in the Pont de lAlma tunnel in Paris. They were being pursued at the time by the paparazzi after leaving the Ritz Hotel. Driver Henri Paul, who was also killed, was drunk and driving at high speed.

Web site for the inquest has posted previously unpublished pictures taken by paparazzi of the limo before and immediately after the accident. One is a closeup  looking into the front of the vehicle that shows Diana, Fayed, Paul and ReesJones minutes before the crash. Republicans react with surprise and recrimination Sunday to blistering criticism of the Iraq war from retired Lt. Gen. Ricardo Sanchez.

Sanchez was coalition commander in 2003 and 2004. He said the Bush administration, the State Department and Congress all share blame. Sanchez also said such dereliction of duty by a military officer would mean immediate dismissal or court martial. South Carolina Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham said he and GOP presidential candidate Sen. John McCain had visited Sanchez several times.

Sanchez's own record in Iraq is blemished. Abu Ghraib got out of control under his watch. But Graham said that finally, with the commitment of nearly 30,000 additional U.S. troops since January, We are getting it right.

Sanchez said it had been his duty to obey orders and not object publicly while on active duty. He said he has an obligation to speak out now that he has retired. While the politicians espouse a rhetoric designed to preserve their reputations and their political power, our soldiers die, he said.

One of the reasons few speak out is evidenced by what happened to former Army Chief of Staff Gen. Eric Shinseki, McCain said. Sen. Mitch McConnell, a Republican from Kentucky, told ABCs This Week that Sanchez is simply wrong. My definition of winning is a stable country and an ally in the war on terror, he said.

Zbigniew Brzezinski says the central government in Iraq has been an embarrassment. Graham says he hopes the government of Nuri alMaliki will step up to the plate and do something meaningful by the end of the year. If that does not happen, he said, it will be incumbent upon us, as a nation, to devise a new political strategy.

Even those Iraqis who were happy to see Saddam Hussein toppled from power more than four years ago are not happy with the continuing U.S. presence, Brzezinski says. No one in the world really supports our policy in Iraq, he says. In his Friday speech, Sanchez added that the surge of U.s. troops into Iraq represents a desperate attempt by the administration.

National Security Council spokeswoman Kate Starr did not address the comment. As Gen. Petraeus and Ambassador Crocker said, theres more work to be done but progress is being made in Iraq. And thats what were focused on now.

GOP presidential candidates face off for first time in over a month. Candidates try to differentiate their views on immigration, Iraq war, abortion, gun control. Unlike previous debates, candidates launch attacks on each other instead of Hillary Clinton. Ryan Crocker, U.S. ambassador to Iraq, is the moderator of the CNNYouTube GOP debate.

Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani and former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney traded jabs over illegal immigration. Romney attacked Giulianis record, saying that as mayor, he promoted illegalimmigration. Giuliani shot back, accusing Romney of having a sanctuary mansion at his own home.

In his quest to appeal to the hardline immigration wing of the party, Romney also turned some of his fire on the same topic toward former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee. Romney denied Giulianis allegation, and the two raised their voices as they tried to talk over each other.

Rep. Tom Tancredo, who has anchored his candidacy on securing the borders and cracking down on illegal immigration, seemed delighted with the give and take. Sen. John McCain, freshly back from a visit to Iraq over Thanksgiving and the most hawkish of the candidates, and Rep. Ron Paul, the most antiwar of the candidate, tangled on two occasions over the Iraq war.

Paul said bringing the troops home from Iraq would save a trillion dollars. McCain said its that kind of isolationism that caused World War II. Paul replied The real question you have to ask is why do I get the most money from active duty officers and military personnel?

Keith Kerr, a retired brigadier general, asked candidates if they thought U.S. military personnel were professional enough to work with gay and lesbian troops. CNN later learned that a June media release from the campaign of Democratic frontrunner Clinton listed Kerr as a member of its steering committee.

Kerr told CNN after the debate that he has not worked for the Clinton campaign and was representing no one other than himself. Kerr also said he is a member of the Log Cabin Republicans, a national gay and lesbian Republican grassroots organization. CNN had verified Kerrs military background and that he had not contributed money to any presidential candidate.

A viewer, holding the Bible, asked Do you believe every word of this book? Huckabee, a Baptist minister, said, Sure, I believe the Bible is exactly what it is. Giuliani said he believes the Bible but not literally true in every respect.

Romney stammered a bit when moderator Anderson Cooper asked him if he believed every word. Romney said he was wrong in favoring a womans right to choose  his position when he was elected governor of Massachusetts. Watch the candidates get personal about the Bible.

Paul: "On abortion, I was wrong" His remarks came in response to a 30second video produced for the debate by Thompsons campaign. The video included a clip of Romney expressing support for Roe vs. Wade during a 1994 debate against Sen. Ted Kennedy. When asked what women and doctors should be charged with if abortion was to become illegal, Paul said it was not an issue for the president.

He added that the issue should be left to the states and courts and not federal authorities. On the issues of taxes, Thompson said hed never met a tax he liked. Ive got a taxcut bill on the table. But I dont do pledges to anybody but the American people

Rep. Duncan Hunter said China is cheating on trade... and its in the interest of the United States to stop Chinas cheating. The candidates fielded video questions submitted by the public via the YouTube Web site. The debate was the first time the GOP candidates had faced off on the same stage in over a month.

None of the 1,000plus Iraqi detainees freed in recent weeks have broken a pledge not to return to the insurgency. Maj. Gen. Doug Stone described the detention system as open and transparent. He said it makes the detainees better citizens and helps break the cycle of violence and poverty in the country. CNNs political team viewed nearly 5,000 videos for the GOP debate. About 2,000 more than they saw for the Democrats debate.

U.S. detention centers are political sore points for Sunnis, who make up 83 percent of the detainees. The main Sunni political coalition cited the centers as one reason for quitting the government during the summer. Stone said detainees get free medical care equal to what he gets as a general, food and water made to Islamic standards, educational opportunities, jobs skills and contact with families. Last month, the U.Sled coalition launched Operation Lions Paw in which between 50 and 70 detainees would be released daily.

I am pleased to tell you that in the more 1,000 that have gone through this program and taken the pledge, not one has returned to threaten Iraqi or coalition forces. Stone said the releases would continue at the same pace beyond Ramadan. There are no secrets that go on in detention, Stone said.

Each detainee has a chance to take classes up to a sixthgrade level, and high school classes are being planned. By the time of their release, detainees grow in terms of working in an intersectarian environment, Stone says.

The average stay for a detainee is 300 days, but some have been detained for two years or longer. A review board interviews detainees to decide if they are a threat to security. If they are deemed not to be, they are offered freedom in exchange for taking the pledge.

Only 280 detainees are foreigners, mostly from Syria, Egypt, Iran, Sudan and Saudi Arabia. Charles and Diane Winkler had asked the court to intervene and either revoke Mary Winklers visitation rights or allow them to proceed only under supervision of a counselor. Mary Winkler was convicted of killing her minister husband Matthew Winkler.

The children  Patricia, Mary Alice and Brianna have been living with their grandparents since their mother was arrested last year. Winkler has not seen the children in 15 months, her attorney said. A jury convicted Winkler earlier this year of voluntary manslaughter in the shotgun death of Matthew Winkler.

Winkler received a threeyear sentence, but a judge required her to serve only 210 days. Charles and Diane Winkler have filed a 2 million wrongful death suit against her for their sons slaying. At the time of their fathers death in March 2006, Patricia was 8, Mary Alice was 6 and Brianna was 1.

The termination issue has not been decided in court. The court may want to determine what, if any, bond Winkler has with her children before making a decision. In September, a lower court granted Winkler visitation with her daughters pending the outcome of the custody battle.

A subsequent appeal by the grandparents was denied, leading to their Supreme Court appeal. The Winklers said if their former daughterinlaw got visitation with the children at all, it should be under the supervision of a professional counselor. They said the children exhibit fear and confusion toward their mother and her role in their fathers death.

The Winklers say the children have experienced urination accidents, sleeping problems, graphic nightmares and sleepwalking. They say the lower court erred by failing to appoint the guardian ad litem until after the September hearing. Turner, however, said she believes terminating Winklers parental rights would not be in the childrens best interest.

Winkler fled with the girls to the Alabama coast, where she was arrested. She said during a September appearance on the Oprah Winfrey Show that she never expected to get away with killing her husband. Pakistans president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, has been under pressure to lift a state of emergency.

GEOTV and ARY Digital offer a variety of programming, including news, entertainment, sports and music. Both networks had been banned from Pakistans cable television system. This latest action prevents the two Pakistani networks from broadcasting worldwide via satellite.
The action was not wholly unexpected, but surprising nevertheless, Aslan said. Dubai is a media city which seemed to be a haven and a sanctuary, he said. "We were ready for it to a certain extent"

The government has made numerous demands of the network, although none of them official, Aslan said. Musharrafs emergency order put several restrictions on the media, preventing journalists from expressing opinions prejudicial to the ideology... or integrity of Pakistan.

Journalists are also restricted from covering suicide bombings and militant activity. Musharraf has denied that his restrictions bar criticism, saying they only ask for responsibility in reporting. Last week, Pakistan expelled three print journalists for using language in an editorial.

Some smaller television channels have complied with the governments restrictions. GEO and ARY have refused. Most of the other channels have kowtowed in order to survive. Musharraf has said the emergency order improves stability and will foster peaceful parliamentary elections.

Opposition leaders accuse Musharraf of declaring emergency rule to keep his hold on power. Blast sends thick plume of smoke over a section of Jacksonville, Florida. Fire Department spokesman: "There is no other way to describe it. Literally, its a hellish inferno"

Fourteen people were hospitalized after the blast at the T2 Lab on Faye Road, in an industrial area on the waterfront in north Jacksonville. Six of those injured were transported to Shands Hospital in Jacksonville, hospital spokeswoman Kelly Brockmeier says. Officials initially ordered an evacuation of nearby businesses, but by 4 p.m. the order had been lifted.

A Shands official said the hospital incident command system had been activated. The billowing black smoke could be seen from the citys downtown. A woman who answered the T2 Labs 24hour facility emergency phone said the plant manufactures ecotane, a gasoline additive that reduces tailpipe emissions.

They described a hissing noise and then a sound wave, she said. Antonio Padrigan was trying to get in touch with his son, who works in a plant. He was shook up when he called me, but I cant get through to him anymore, Padrigan said.

Carlton Higginbotham, 63, was working at home on Townsend Boulevard in Jacksonville when a loud boom shook his house. It was a gunshottype explosion it wasnt a rumble, he said. The cloud that came out of it was white, some would say mushroomshaped, Higgin botham said.

Nasser al Ansari is the CEO of Qatari Diar, a stateowned real estate investment company. The company is famous for its purchase of Londons Chelsea Barracks. Al Ansari was responsible for high profile projects such as New Doha International Airport and the promotion of private sector investment through public sector privatization.

Nasser al Ansari is the CEO of Qatari Diar. Al Ansari was at the office of the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs as technical advisor. He joins us on MME to talk about the vision for Qatar, how Qatari diar fits into it and its investments outside Gulf in Morocco, Sudan, Syria, Egypt and Europe.

But now we are fortunate with a high level of education and the reformations in government policies in this region. We now understand how to utilize this wealth and economical growth. I dont think most people know that you sit on one of the largest natural gas fields in the world. This must give you great cushion to expand the Qatari Diar model.

We are investing a lot in real estate, not just in Qatar but worldwide. Its almost foreign policy strategy to invest in the poorer countries in the region. I think with the knowledge and knowhow that we have gained in this area of expertise, we would like to export it to other countries.

JD Its quite a radical departure say from the International Monetary Fund or World Bank giving loans or grants for development. This is turning the world upside down in your region, it is not? NA Yes, I would like to assure you at Qatari Diar we are not in the business of lending.

I mean we want to make sure that the investment we are making is there for the longterm. Qatari Diar has a policy its a longterm policy not shortterm. We would like to showcase the strength of the people of Qatar. We want to pull the flag of the state of Qatar even across the Atlantic and we are determined to do so.

Death Penalty Information Center DPIC: 42 people have been put to death this year. That figure is down 57 percent from what it was in 1999, when 98 inmates were executed. Supreme Court will hold oral arguments January 7 about the constitutionality of lethal injection protocols.

The Supreme Court is to hold oral arguments January 7 about whether lethal injection protocols in 36 of the 37 states with the death penalty are constitutional. The justices placed a moratorium on executions in late September, when they decided to review a Kentucky case. Stays of executions have been issued in several states until the larger constitutional issues are addressed.

If the high court finds the procedures unconstitutional, it could take years before deathpenalty states would meet legal standards necessary to resume lethal injection. Even if the method is declared acceptable, it would be months before new execution dates could be set.

Texas continues to lead the nation, with 62 percent of executions nationwide this year. Overall, 86 percent this year were in the South. The death penalty has been in a period of decline for many years.

Death penalty supporters acknowledge that states outside the South have been reluctant to impose the punishment. I think the main problem is that the death penalty is not being imposed often enough in those urban jurisdictions, said Kent Scheidegger of the Sacramentobased Criminal Justice Legal Foundation. New Jerseys legislature voted last week to outlaw death penalty  the first state to do so in 42 years.

Jon Corzine signed the measure into law Monday. At the same time, he commuted the sentences of the eight men on the states death row. Similar bills in Nebraska, New Mexico and Montana failed this year.

The Supreme Court on January 4 will decide whether to review an appeal from Louisiana inmate Patrick Kennedy. Kennedy was sentenced to death in 2003 for raping his 8yearold stepdaughter. The justices in 1976 banned capital punishment for rape, but 19 years later, Louisiana passed a law allowing execution for the sexual violation of a child under 12.

Zenit finish top of the table with 61 points, two points ahead of secondplaced Spartak Moscow. Zenit went ahead in the 15th minute when Radek Sirls shot from the edge of the box deflected off a Ramenskoye defender and beat goalkeeper Antonin Kinski. After the interval, the hosts poured forward seeking an equalizer and created several chances but Zenit held firm.

Roman Pavyuchenko and Soares Welliton scored for Spartak. Radoslav Kovac scored an own goal for Dynamo Moscow. Rostov and Krasnodar were relegated from the Premier League. Click here for all the latest from the Russian Premier League this season.

Celtic held 11-0 by managerless Hibernian in Scottish Premier League. Gordon Strachans team head the table by three points from Glasgow rivals Rangers. Rangers have three games in hand ahead of Sunday's trip to Aberdeen. David Murphy scored the only goal of the game in the 20th minute at Celtic Park. The Englishman's shot from the edge of the box went in off the crossbar.

Jiri Jarosik rescues Celtic from first home SPL defeat this season. Hibernian held on despite having to play the final few minutes with 10 men. The victory lifted the visitors up into fifth place, while Celtic have taken just six points from the last five games.Murphys only other goal this season came in Hibs 10 win at Rangers on October 6. He has scored just once in the SPL so far this season, in a 1-1 draw with St Johnstone.

Strachan is hoping to sign Brazilian defender Coelho next month. The Scotland boss is unhappy with the number of chances his side have missed. Strachan said: "We could have definitely done something with every one of them. Its not been great to look at, and we need to cut it out"

Thirdplaced Motherwell missed the chance to move above Rangers. Falkirk climbed to ninth with two goals in the second half to Michael Higdon and then another from Patrick Clegg on 65 minutes. Fourthplaced Dundee United failed to take advantage, losing 21 at home to bottom club Gretna whose only two wins this season have come against the Tangerines.

Inverness Caledonian Thistle beat Hearts 2-1. Graham Bayne scored an injury time winner to lift Caley into the top six. Secondbottom St Mirren drew 0-0 at home to fellow strugglers Kilmarnock. Gretna are seven points ahead of second bottom side St Mirran after a 1-1 draw with St Johnstone. The game was a repeat of last weekend's shock 32-1 victory against Celtic.

Churchgoers in six states have held prayer sessions along the side of Interstate 35. The highway runs through six U.S. states, from southern Texas to northern Minnesota. CNN traveled to Texas, the southernmost state in the I35 corridor, to do a story about a prayer campaign called Light the Highway. The campaign is called "Light the Highway"

Churchgoers in all six states recently finished 35 days of praying alongside Interstate 35. Some of the faithful believe that in order to fulfill the prophecy of I35 being the holy highway, it needs some intensive prayer first. They prayed that adult businesses along the corridor would see the light and perhaps close down.

Cindy Jacobs says she received a revelation to start this campaign. She says she cant be sure Interstate 35 really is what is mentioned in the Bible. They prayed for safety and freedom from crime for people who lived along the interstate.

Jacobs also points out that perhaps there is a link between the area near this highway and tragedies that have happened in history. Thats why prayer certainly cant hurt, she adds. At an adult gogo club, the owner tells us he resents people trying to impose their will on others. And he says his club holds fundraisers, food drives and toy drives to help the community.

Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez is on a campaign to make Venezuelans cut back on drinking and smoking. But on the side of the road, the prayerful arent going to change their minds. Holy highways and nude clubs, they believe, are not a combination God has in mind.

Taxes on whiskey, brandy, cognac and other drinks that dont come from cane sugar have been raised 1.79 3,838 bolivares per liter. Its unfair because, in the end, the consumer is the one who pays, says Fernando Fernandez, a liquor exporter. They say theyre going to stop eating so that they can continue drinking, says one woman who lives in Venezuela.

Chavez has described whiskey as a drink for rich people, not for revolutionaries. The moves represent the first steps toward transforming each Venezuelan into what Chavez calls the new man. Chavez has cited the life of revolutionary socialist icon Ernesto Che Guevara as an example of how to lead a more pure life.

Also effective Monday, stores near schools, churches and cultural centers will not be granted licenses to sell alcohol. Taxes on cigarette imports have also increased, from 50 percent to 70 percent of the total price. Some people said they dont understand the motivations for the increase, but predicted their consumption would not change.
The Venezuelan is not going to stop drinking or smoking, said one person. Chavez also plans to increase taxes on luxury items such as Hummers. There is no Hummer dealership in the country.

Obesity is the No. 1 health crisis in the U.S., former President Clinton says. Former President Clinton spoke at CNNs first Fit Nation Summit. Chavez said he wants to focus less on material goals for Venezuelas 27 million people, 38 percent of whom live in poverty.

Twothirds of adult Americans are overweight or obese the same is true for onethird of U.S. children. Obesity carries increased risk of myriad health problems, including hypertension, diabetes, heart disease and arthritis. Clinton and CNNs chief medical correspondent, Dr. Sanjay Gupta, gathered with experts from across the country Wednesday to explore solutions to Americas obesity crisis. They addressed such proposed solutions as healthy school lunches, elimination of trans fats, the need for healthier food in urban communities.

Clinton: Motivating Americans, especially kids, wont be easy. Kids need to know its important, but fitness cant be boring, he said. Clinton has been tackling the obesity issue over the past few years with his Alliance for a Healthier Generation.

Trans fats have been shown to raise LDL or bad cholesterol in people and lower their HDL, or good cholesterol. Michael Jacobson, director of the Center for Science in the Public Interest, is a strong advocate against trans fats in foods. He says the Food and Drug Administration should ban trans fats altogether.

The panel took questions from an audience of 150 people  mostly obesity experts or those who work in industries that deal with obesity. Gupta was inspired to launch Fit Nation, an ongoing, multiplatform, grassroots initiative against obesity. Over the past three years, Gupta and the CNN Medical Unit have crisscrossed the country.

This year, Gupta traveled from Michigan to California asking the public to pledge to add 1 million hours to their collective lives. Since he began the tour in April, the campaign has surpassed its goal. Gupta said he hopes that legislators and administrators who can make a difference in policy and perhaps change attitudes about obesity will hear the solutions discussed at the summit.

Yuvraj Singh smashed six sixes in one over as England crashed out of crickets World Twenty20 tournament in South Africa. Paul Collingwoods side were eliminated at the Super Eights stage after South Africa earlier beat New Zealand by six wickets in Durban.

Singh reached the fastest 50 in Twenty20 history, needing just 12 deliveries. The lefthanders six consecutive sixes in the 19th over bowled by Stuart Broad. England then lost by 18 runs to the Singhinspired Indians, who kept their semifinal hopes alive ahead of Thursdays mustwin clash with the hosts. Singh is the first player to do so in Twenty 20 matches and just the fourth in all senior cricket.

Virender Sehwag topscored with 68 off 52 balls, putting on 136 for the first wicket with Gautam Gambhir. England battled gamely but could only post 2006 in their 20 overs. Irfan Pathan claimed figures of 337 off four overs, while Rudra Pratap Singh took 228.

If India can beat South Africa, it would create a threeway tie and require net runrates to decide the two teams going through. The Proteas have two wins from two Group E outings after beating New Zealand. South Africa restricted the Black Caps to 1538 from their 20 overs on Wednesday, then reached the target with five deliveries to spare. Justin Kemp was named man of the match after smashing a six off the otherwise economical Mark Gillespie for the winning runs.

Kemp added 28 in four overs with Gibbs 19 before putting on another 65 in eight overs with Mark Boucher. Boucher departed for 23, caught by wicketkeeper Brendon McCullum off Gillespie. The experienced Shaun Pollock then joined Kemp, and struck one six in his unbeaten 16 off 11 deliveries to help guide the Proteas to their second victory.

Morkel ends with figures of 417 off four overs. He had Shane Bond caught by Boucher, and then almost became the first Twenty20 bowler to claim five wickets. His penultimate delivery which clean bowled Gillespie was declared a noball by umpire Billy Doctrove. The man arrested for the videotaped rape of a toddler in Las Vegas will make his initial appearance in court Friday.

Elaine Thomas says she lived in fear after seeing enhanced photos from the videotape on the local news. Stiles, 37, was taken into custody Monday night after a Henderson, Nevada, police officer pulled over the white Buick Century he was driving. Thomas said she screamed when she recognized the photos on television.

The judge in the case will hold an administrative hearing Wednesday, but Stiles will not be present. Stiles was already being sought on an unrelated 2004 charge of felony lewdness with a child under 14. Authorities amended that earlier filing on October 4 to include 20 counts related to the videotaped rape. The child on the videotape was younger than 3 when the abuse occurred.

Henderson Police Officer Mike Dye said he pulled over Stiles car Monday night because it did not have a license plate. Dye became suspicious when the driver gave him an expired California drivers license with a photo that did not look like him.

Stiles, a resident of Pahrump, Nevada, was turned over to Las Vegas Metropolitan Police. He had been sought in connection with the videotape, which shows a girl being sexually assaulted. The tape was given to authorities by Darren Tuck, who told police he had found it in the desert five months before handing it over.

He turned himself in to authorities in Nye County, Nevada, earlier this month. Professionals have evaluated the girl in the videotape since she was found, and she appears to be healthy and fine and happy. The mother had not known her daughter had ever been victimized and was apparently oblivious to efforts to find her until late last month.

Donohue said the mother recognized Stiles, a former animal trainer. The alleged abuse most likely occurred while the mother  a single woman working six days a week was at work, he said. Another former girlfriend of Stiles said this month she thinks she is the reason Stiles came in contact with the girl.

Also living in the apartment were a family friend and her daughter. Todd Allen, Tina Allens son, said he recognized his old apartment from scenes in the video. Eduardo Gonzalez, a petty officer second class with the U.S. Navy, is about to be deployed overseas for a third time.

Eduardo Gonzalez's wife faces deportation to Guatemala. She has not seen her home country since 1989. Eduardo worries about what would happen to his young son, Eduardo Jr., if she is deported. "I like being in uniform and serving my country, but if she goes back Im going to have to give it all up," he said.

Gonzalez, who works on helicopters that bring cargo, supplies and military personnel in and out of Iraq, testified before a House Judiciary Committee panel last month. He urged officials to consider some sort of policy to deal with cases like his, where military members families could be deported while theyre defending their country overseas.

Each is handled casebycase, not by the military, but by immigration authorities. Lt. Col. Margaret Stock, a member of the U.S. Army Reserves, teaches immigration law at West Point. She believes there should be an overall policy dealing with the potential deportation of family members of active duty military members. When youre in a combat zone, you need to be focusing all of your energies on fighting the enemy.

The government is conflicted about how to treat such cases, Stock says. On the one hand, the government is supposed to be providing military families with assistance, housing and other forms of benefits while their spouses are overseas, she says. But the same government is trying to deport the very same people, she adds.

In Gonzalezs case, his wife, Mildred, came to the United States with her mother in 1989 when she was 5 years old. They were granted political asylum because of their status as war refugees from Guatemala. Her mother was granted legal status in July 2004, according to Gonzalez. But six weeks earlier, Gonzalez and Mildred got married, canceling Mildreds ability to apply for legal status through her mother.

A judge in June granted her a oneyear extension to remain in the United States. If her legal status does not change by June 8, 2008, she will have 60 days to voluntarily leave the country or face deportation. Thats just fine, according to Mark Krikorian, the executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies.

Gonzalez: "Theres no justification for that kind of policy" Gonzalez himself entered the country legally, crossing the Mexican border with his family when he was about 10. He joined the Navy as a socalled greencard sailor and became a U.S. citizen in July 2005.

The military does accept some immigrants who arent U.S. citizens. Emmanuel Woko, a member of the Armys 2nd Brigade, 1st Infantry Division, understands just how Gonzalez and his family feel. We didnt come here to break the law. We just want to feel safe and have a home just like everybody else.

His wife and children could be sent back to Nigeria. My heart is bleeding on the thought that my wife could be deported. I am extremely distressed and distracted by the thought. Thats a sentiment echoed by Gonzalez. We are just asking for our families to stay with us.

Heavy rains and flooding have forced hundreds of thousands of people from homes in southern Mexicos state of Tabasco. Officials say about 300,000 people are still trapped by the worst flooding in the region for 50 years. The Grijalva River pushed over its banks through the state capital of Villahermosa on Thursday.

About 700,000 people have seen their homes flooded, with about 300,000 of those still trapped there. One death had been blamed on the floods, which followed weeks of heavy rain in the largely swampy state. Tabasco borders Guatemala to the south and the Gulf of Mexico to the north.

The Grijalva River, one of two large waterways ringing Villahermosa, has risen 6.5 feet 2 meters above its critical level. Authorities said some of the rivers were continuing to rise. The flooding was not related to Tropical Storm Noel, which was pounding the Caribbean.

U.N. calls on NATO to do more to stop the Afghan opium trade. Report shows the export value of this years poppy harvest stood at around 4 billion, a 29 per cent increase over 2006. Afghan villagers tend to opium poppies in Talibancontrolled Helmand province.

Despite Afghan security forces efforts to curb the trade, 660 tons of heroin and morphine were trafficked out of the country in 2007, the report said. Opium has accounted for more than half of Afghanistans gross domestic product in 2007. About a quarter of the earnings from opium go to farmers, according to the U.N.

The rest goes to district officials who collect taxes on the crop, to drug traffickers and to insurgents and warlords who control the trade. Since drugs are funding the insurgency, NATO has a selfinterest in supporting Afghan forces in destroying drug labs, markets and convoys. Destroy the drug trade and you cut off the Talibans main funding source, a U.N. official says. A NATO spokesman says coalition forces are equally concerned by the rapid growth in the narcotics trade.

We share the U.N. concerns, Appathurai told CNN. Drugs not only poison people, but they poison economies and governments, he said. Farming of opium poppies has been almost eradicated in the north and west of the country. NATO forces are providing assistance to Afghan police through training and transport.

U.N. observers have noticed a proliferation of heroin labs in neighboring countries and along trafficking routes. Costa said the labs are dependent on precursor chemicals, like acetic anhydride, that must be smuggled into the region. He called for tighter controls in chemicalproducing countries and stronger intelligencesharing.

Appathurai said the most effective way to curb the drug trade was tackling the insurgency headon. He also said it was important to provide alternative work for poor Afghan farmers to encourage them to give up opium production. You cannot have eradication in isolation.

David Nalbandian beat Roger Federer in the final of the Madrid Masters. The Argentine, ranked 25th in the world, repeated his 2005 upset win over the Swiss star in that years seasonending Masters Cup. Defending champion Federer, playing in his first tournament since winning the U.S. Open six weeks ago, made 38 unforced errors.

Nalbandian won his first title on the ATP Tour since May, 2006. The 25-year-old lost in the Madrid final in 2004. He spent a year without a coach, but has revived his career since teaming up with Hernan Gumy.

Roger and I have a long history and I think that influenced the match. It was an extremely hard first set. But I tightened the teeth and I began to play more strongly. Things came out fine, I played incredible.
He came back strong and played well in the end. He was a better player all in all. I was struggling after the first set to play aggressively, for some reason. He played tough and didnt miss

Juan Roman Riquelme scored twice as Argentina beat Bolivia 30 to notch a third successive victory in the South American qualifiers for the 2010 World Cup. The midfielder followed up his brace of spectacular freekicks in the opening 20 victory against Chile to help put his country five points clear of secondplaced Brazil. Argentina play Peru in Lima on Sunday in their next qualifier.

The 19-year-old scored his first goal at international level five minutes before the interval after starting in a threeman attack with Carlos Tevez and Lionel Messi. Riquelme added the second 11 minutes after the break with a dipping freekick which beat Carlos Arias from 25 yards. And he finished off the scoring in the 73rd minute with a cool sidefoot finish after being set up by Messi.

Sen. Hillary Clinton says troop withdrawal is too little, too late. Colombia beat Venezuela 10, and Paraguay routed Ecuador 51. Ecuador coach Luis Fernando Suarez, a Colombian, quit after his teams loss saying I have taken the irrevocable decision to resign. In an open letter to Bush, Clinton said the troop withdrawal was unacceptable to this Congress, and to the American people.

Bush is expected to endorse the recommendations of Gen. David Petraeus that the troop levels in Iraq be lowered to 130,000 by July. Sen. Barack Obama of Illinois says the president is returning to an earlier, failed policy. We now are still in the same position as we essentially were in June 2006, Obama says. "I strongly urge you to choose this course of action," he says.

Obama presented a new plan for Iraq on Wednesday afternoon in Clinton, Iowa. It calls for an immediate drawdown of combat operations at a pace of one or two brigades every month, to be completed by the end of next year. A brigade comprises between 3,000 and 5,000 soldiers.

Presidential candidate John Edwards calls for an immediate withdrawal of 40,000 to 50,000 troops. Edwards says Democrats have a moral responsibility to use every tool available to them, including a filibuster. Obama recommends a new constitutional convention for Iraq, a new regional diplomatic effort and steps to confront the countrys humanitarian crisis. "There is no military solution in Iraq, and there never was," Obama says in his speech.

Edwards also called Obamas plan for troop withdrawal a copy of the presidents plan. Obama would withdraw only one to two combat brigades a month between now and the end of next year, said Edwards, which for the next several months could essentially mimic the presidents own plans to withdraw 30,000 troops by next summer. Democrats lack the votes in Congress to force the president to bring the troops home and are seeking a compromise position.

Democratic leaders are meeting with Republican lawmakers, who want a change in war policy. Privately, Democrats concede that the next president probably will inherit at least a deployment of 100,000 troops in Iraq. Some Democrats appear to be wavering on a highly contentious House resolution labeling Turkeys treatment of Armenians in World War I as genocide.

Turkey is incensed by the resolution calling the killing of Armenians by Ottoman Turks genocide. It threatened to block access to Incirlik Air Base after the resolution passed a House committee vote. The base, in southern Turkey near Syria, is a major resupply center for U.S. operations in Iraq and elsewhere in the Mideast and Asia.

President Bush signed a federal disaster declaration Wednesday, freeing up federal funds for families affected by the wildfires in seven counties in Southern California. FEMA Director David Paulison promised on Tuesday a different type of response than the federal government put together for Katrina. Paulison said Katrina was a wakeup call and that this is a new FEMA.

The action follows an emergency declaration by Bush on Tuesday morning for the counties of Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino, San Diego, Santa Barbara, and Ventura. FEMA and other relief and rescue services face significantly different challenges in the fire zone than they did on the Gulf Coast in 2005. The devastation in California is intense but not universal. By contrast, roads in Southern California have remained open for residents to get out and help to get in without delay. Residents there are generally more affluent and are able to use their own vehicles to escape. Many of Katrinas victims were poor and had no means of transportation.

Mental Floss  Everyone goes through a rebellious phase. And, if youre lucky, youll be able to look back on those years and laugh. In modern times, cats frolic among the ruins of ancient Rome. But, hey, it could be worse.

Justa Grata Honoria was a Roman princess who rebelled against her brother's reign. Her wild ways and literally naked ambition set off a chain reaction that culminated in the destruction of the Roman Empire. Smart, conniving, and ruthless, Honoria possessed all the attributes befitting a Roman emperor, except for that pesky Y chromosome. Her afterhours habits caused quite the scandal, but they failed to satiate her need for attention and power.

Honoria was sent to a convent in Constantinople. She spent her years at the nunnery plotting one escape attempt after another. She seduced her brothers royal chamberlain, Eugenius, and together, they plotted to murder Valentinian and seize power.

Honoria offered Attila half of the Western Empire as her dowry. If Attila would rescue her, she would marry him. Of course, Honoria was in no position to rightfully offer any portion of the Roman Empire. She turned to sources outside the empire.

Attila had secretly been planning a move against Rome for years. Wasting no time, he told Valentinian that he planned to marry Honoria, and demanded the dowry hed been promised. Naturally, Valentinian refused, and Attila used his status as a wronged husband to invade Roman territory in 451 C.E.

Like all the other cities before it, Rome would also have been annihilated were it not for the famine and disease that devastated the Huns during the invasion. Rome survived with the unlikely help of another nomadic enemy tribe, the Visigoths, but the Western Empire never recovered. Within a generation, the armies of the Goths, Franks, and Huns had overrun the area.

Not wanting to cause a scandal by having her executed, Valentinian settled on a suitable third option. After years of struggle, Honoria finally suffered the fate she had been dreading all along. She was married off to an elderly Roman senator, and the rest of her life went unrecorded by history. For more mental_floss articles, visit mentalfloss.com.

Sheffield FC was instrumental in developing set rules for the game. The club studied existing rules and laid down a code of laws. By 1862 there were said to be 15 football clubs in and around the Sheffield area. The Football Association which codified the basic rules of the modern game was established in London the following year.

Sheffield FC has never played at a professional level. The club currently competes in the Unibond Leagues First Division South, seven divisions beneath the English Premier League. The sight of the players using their foreheads in addition to their feet reduced the London crowd to hysterics.

Long before they ever made an appearance on the TV show Sex and the City, pointed shoes were favored by Polish nobles.

In 1363 the English attempted to rein in the look by law, assigning shoe spans to social classes. Commoners could sport footwear with toes of up to six inches, while those in the royal ranks were allowed a full two feet in length. In 1977 University of Vermont student Lisa Lindahl was running 30 miles a week and her bra wasnt holding up.
With the help of two classmates, Lindahl sewed together two jock straps and  presto! the sports bra was born. Almost 40,000 sports bras are now sold annually.

Mary Jane was either Buster Browns sweetheart or sister, depending on which source you consult. Gabardine, a waterrepellent fabric invented by Burberry, got its first mention from Shakespeare. The most widely held theory is that the singlestrapped footwear was named for a character in Buster Brown.

The Bard used the word in The Merchant of Venice to refer to a coarse cloak worn as protection from storms. During World War I, British officers on the front lines kept warm and dry in a uniform coat made of the material  the original Burberry trench.

Palm Beach socialite Lilly Pulitzer opened a juice stand in 1959 to pass the time. The citrus concoctions discolored her clothes. She instructed her dressmaker to create a uniform that would camouflage the bright stains. The Lilly design  sleeveless cotton shifts in vibrant prints was born.

The term pump first popped up in 1550 in England, where male servants sported the style. It is said that the noise they made while wearing the loosefitting shoes resembled the sound of a water pump. The word sneaker entered the language in the 1870s the rubber soles made the shoes quiet and therefore sneaky.

The modern usage of stiletto, a Renaissanceera Italian word for an assassins narrowbladed knife, made its debut in 1953. When it rained, the welltodo stayed dry in covered carriages and sedan chairs. For thousands of years, in such places as Egypt, China, Japan, Mesopotamia, and India, umbrellas were used exclusively to shade the heads of dignitaries.

Bikinis first appeared in 1946, but American women thought them immodest. Not until the 1960s were they accepted, possibly helped by the hit song Itsy Bitsy Teenie Weenie Yellow Polka Dot Bikini. Named for the nucleartesting site Bikini Atoll.

It is said that the cuffs were designed to be used as handkerchiefs in combat. But, in fact, French royalty invented the style in the 1500s. Amusingly, the competitive English tried to take credit for the fashion.

Around 1800, thinner, silkier fabrics and slimmer cuts came into vogue. Women could no longer hide the bulging sacks around their midsections. They began carrying their belongings in small pocketbooks instead. In the 16th century, drawers became a common term for both mens and womens underpants.

Made of linen, the items were nofrills and looked more or less interchangeable this being well before Victoria ever had a secret decorative lace trim. Most likely, underwear earned this distinctly unsexy epithet because it describes the way that people put on their unmentionables.

Jared Hutchins says the Beatles made him irritable and angry. Hutchins plays the piano, guitar and harmonica. The rallies, which draw mostly teens, are one part concert, one part Christian revival. "God owns my life, not the Beatles, he said simply.

Hutchins is one of many teenagers who say that some part of popular culture has harmed him. Hutchins said he enjoys a wide range of music from Pink Floyd and Arcade Fire to Christian bands such as Hillsong United. He said he has to be careful of what music he listens to, for the same reason he temporarily turned off the Beatles. Go behindthescenes with CNNs Christiane Amanpour at a BattleCry event.

The rallies seek to stage a reverse revolution against secular popular culture. The audiences are nearly always predominantly teenagers and young adults. From 2006 to 2007, a total of 127,830 people attended the 34 Acquire the Fire rallies. The three BattleCry events held in San Francisco, California Detroit, Michigan and Bristow, Virginia.

Teen Mania founder Ron Luce has waged a crusade against purveyors of popular culture, whom he has condemned as the enemy. Luce: We dont have to be branded by the culture, we are branded by God. Be who God created you to be, Teen Mania followers say. For Hutchins, who said he struggled in his early adolescence to fit in and be cool, the message is exactly right.

More than two decades old, Teen Mania estimates it has reached more than 2 million teens with its message of living completely for Christ. In addition to its live stadium rallies, there are BattleCry shirts and hats, mobile screen savers, books and a television program. There are international mission trips  Hutchins attended one in Tijuana, Mexico, this summer.

He weaves disturbing statistics about teenagers amid his gospel. Todays teenagers are in crisis, he says. Were fighting for those who dont know they have a voice, that are being manipulated by our pop culture, Luce says.

To some, Luces rhetoric is offputting, hateful and divisive. Opponents point to his views on homosexuality  not in Gods plan and abortion  the ending of a precious life. It is this criticism that Luce and his followers confronted headon in March at BattleCry San Francisco. There, in arguably the most liberal city in the United States, protesters rallied against BattleCry on the steps of City Hall.
Ron Luce is a liar! Let me hear you say Christian fascist, another yelled. Luce and the youths, some as young as 11, also raised their voices. Mindy Peterson is a member of Teen Manias Honor Academy.
Afterward, Peterson railed against what she said was the protesters mischaracterization of BattleCry. "These people think that our war is against other people," she said.
While much milder in his terms, Hutchins agrees. Were a generation that is kind of troubled, he said. Luce wants to rescue the hearts of our generation, he added.
Mostly, what were concerned with is Jesus. One afternoon the shells began raining down on our neighborhood in Beirut. The civil war was in full flood.

A Lebanese woman and her son run through west Beirut in 1989 during fighting between rival forces. We ran from school screaming. Out of breath, my knees giving way, it seemed to take forever to reach our local shelter. The memory of that terrifying afternoon receded until recently.

After more than a decade of relative peace and reconstruction, the bombings and assassinations have returned to Beirut. In 1988, I watched the last throes of the civil war firsthand and like millions of Lebanese, sad, frustrated and often fearful. Now I watch from another continent, but I find those same emotions resurfacing.

The conspiracies, the car bombs, the threatening rhetoric and political deadlock are eerily familiar. Then, as now, a presidential election is the setting. The struggle where religion and clan play the main roles threatens to set Lebanon back 20 years.

In 1988, the presidents term was coming to an end and the warring factions were unable to agree on a new candidate. Militias prevented parliament members from reaching the assembly building. Compromise was nowhere in sight.
In his last act as president, Amin Gemayel named fellow Christian and Army Chief Michel Aoun as prime minister. At a stroke, he shattered the convention that a Muslim hold that position.

Aoun famously declared I am prime minister and six ministers in one. War of Liberation against Syria turned into defeat. He turned on fellow Christians of the Lebanese Forces in the War of Elimination.

I tried to explain the chaos, the bewildering array of factions and the horrors of civil war for ordinary civilians. I had seen people killed in front of me children orphaned in seconds, parents burying their infants in oversize white coffins. So when I was offered the opportunity to stay at CNN, I gratefully accepted the chance to escape the anarchy.

Peace came to Lebanon, but it would be five years before I returned. In 1995, I went back and was stunned. I couldnt believe that I could go anywhere without being harassed or kidnapped. No longer did identity  Christian, Muslim or Druze define where Lebanese could go.

Downtown Beirut, once rocked by explosions and bullet holes, was rocking to Lebanese pop music. The dusty sandbags had given way to boutiques carrying the latest European fashions and deluxe hotels. Lovers had returned to Beiruts Corniche, overlooking the Mediterranean, for romantic strolls at sunset.

The agreement that ended the civil war was more a truce than a real settlement. As antiSyrian sentiment grew, so did political tensions. On Valentines Day 2005, the Corniche was once again rocked by an explosion.

On the day of love, Lebanon was thrown back into its most hateful history. It had been widely expected that Hariri would run for office again and demand the withdrawal of Syrian troops. But Hariris death also exposed the fault lines that had broken Lebanon a generation previously.

Even after it withdrew its troops, Syria still had allies in Lebanon. One was Hezbollah, accused of the suicide attacks that had killed scores of U.S. Marines in Beirut. Another was Gen. Michel Aoun, who had defied Syria in 1989, but now made common cause with Hezbollah against his fellow Christians.

The place looked like a morgue. Antigovernment Hezbollah squatters had brought life there to a standstill. As I passed through, business owners stood silent in the sun. I wondered if they sensed my disappointment, my pain at watching Beirut bleed again.

Once again, the term of the president is approaching its end there is no agreement on his successor. Suspicion and fear are the political currency of the day. Will the countrys brief renaissance that so amazed me in 1995 be snuffed out by the old curse of sectarian rivalries? CNNs Joe Sterling, David Ariosto, Saad Abedine and Tracy Doueiry contributed to this report.

Sallie Krawcheck is Chairman and Chief Executive of Citi Global Wealth Management. Dubbed the Mrs Clean of Wall Street, she was credited with restoring investors faith in analyst reports. She joined Citigroup in 2002, and spent some time as Chief Financial Officer before taking up her current role in March 2007.

Sallie Krawcheck has been a regular entrant on Fortunes list of the Worlds Most Powerful Women in Business. John Defterios caught up with Ms Kraw check in Dubai. He asked her for her views on the movement of capital outside the G8 Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Russia, the United Kingdom and the United States.

Over time, youre really going to see... a shift in economic activity on a relative basis from the more developed economies here to the Middle East as well as Asia. Its coming almost as a perfect storm we have a sub prime crisis, a 20 percent fall in the dollar in the last two years. Yes, the investments are going up globally, but the governments here really are investing back in the infrastructure and the economies of this region.

In this window of time, is there a danger that the financial capitals build outside of Wall Street and it undermines its role? I think there is no doubt that New York is losing its status as a financial capital of the world. But you have overlapping regulators in the United States, you have very high taxes in the U.S. and you have the emerging markets coming up.

Some of the wealth funds are now on the radar of both Wall Street and Capitol Hill in Washington. You cant have your cake and eat it too. Some of the things are negative for the United States, some of which are positive for the other regions.

Sovereign funds are very important drivers of global markets and global liquidity. The concern is if, gee these are going to be important going forward, we want to have these involved in our economy and our markets. If we regulate this alone that money will skitter away to another market  to a market outside the United States or Europe for example. Its fascinating because if you look at Qatar or Egypt or Shanghai, the stock markets have almost had like a one way path.

But what are we likely to see here, stair steps up the ladder with some corrections along the way, or an implosion because of the rapid gains? SK I think youve got to separate the idea of whats going on in the real economies and whats going onto in the market places. They move together, but sometimes they separate, they diverge, and they can diverge for a long period of time.

For 30 years its been growing at that kind of rate and really can continue as far as the eye can see. Although there is no ban in the Quran on images of Allah or the Prophet Mohammed, likenesses are considered highly offensive by Muslims. Appearing somber and dazed, Gibbons arrived at the central courthouse in Khartoum for her closed hearing early Thursday.

Gibbons could have faced a sentence of 40 lashes, a fine, or a jail term of up to a year. Foreign Office expressed Britains dissatisfaction with the verdict. Gibbons will be given credit for the four days since her arrest, Foreign Office says. She has 11 days remaining on her sentence. Miliband met with Siddig, who was summoned to the Foreign Office in London.

Around 25 police linked arms and forced journalists and British officials away from the court entrance. He was just yelling at me to jump and stuff, Wylie says. The smoke was pouring out, couldnt really breathe, so I had to make a quick decision. I just kind of leaned out the window and luckily I jumped far enough to make it into the canal.
