Ann Curley has been a type I diabetic for 40 years. She uses a pump attached to a catheter in her body to monitor glucose levels and administer insulin. This is her story of life with diabetes.

Dr. Robert Deputy was the pediatrician who diagnosed me with diabetes. He spoke to me directly, rather than to my mother, and he asked me questions Did I feel thirsty? Did I need to urinate during the night? The answer to both questions was yes.

He asked for a urine sample and the result was immediate. Dr. Deputy told me and my mother that my body wasnt processing sugar properly. I spent several days in the hospital learning how to manage my disease, and then they sent me home.

Dr. Deputy would call our house each afternoon to check on me and see how I was doing. I refused to let my parents give me injections or test my urine. While some diabetics may feel their disease is a burden, I feel that being diagnosed with diabetes was a blessing in disguise.

It forced our family to eat healthily, and it taught me about good nutrition. I know carbohydrate counts in most foods, and I understand dietary concepts that most people dont even care about. Being active is also a way to burn off high blood sugar, so when my urine tested positive for glucose, my older sister Robin was in charge of exercising me. We had countless jumprope contests, bike rides and rollerskating excursions.

Test strips were developed that could be dipped in urine to reveal whether sugar was present in it. But the truth is, testing urine for sugar was a primitive method. By the time sugar gets into the urine, its a signal that the body doesnt have enough insulin to process sugar.

Home blood glucose testing kits became available in the early 1980s. With the kit, the diabetic uses a device to poke a finger and produce a drop of blood. The blood is placed on a test strip that fits into a device that produces a reading.

The 1980s also saw the advent of the insulin pump. This device is the size of a pager and contains a reservoir filled with insulin. The reservoir connects to a tube that infuses the insulin into the body with a tiny plastic shunt. So rather than taking multiple injections to mimic the bodys insulin patterns, the pump drips insulin into. the body to keep blood sugars constant.

The continuous glucose monitor, or CGM, is a small device inserted into the tissue usually the abdomen, hip or leg. It has a tiny sensor that reads the glucose level of the bodys fluids. The data is transmitted to a receiver, and patients can see a constant reading of their blood sugar levels. Some sensors transmit data directly to an insulin pump, so you can use the reading to adjust and finetune the amount of insulin being pumped into the body.

CGM technology is a step toward the ultimate goal of controlling type I diabetes using whats called a closed loop system. The current systems are open looped, meaning the diabetic controls when the doses are given. The goal is to eventually create a pump that is more like a robotic delivery system, and all the patient has to do is wear it. The patient still has to test his or her blood sugar to confirm the sensor is properly calibrated.

Once that technology is perfected, this type of device would be implanted, which would be the next best thing to not having diabetes. Forty years ago, before the advent of all of the cool diabetes technology such as insulin pumps, continuous glucose monitors and blood sugar testing, parents were given a fairly grim prediction for how their child would fare.

I spoke with Dr. Deputy, who recently retired from his pediatric practice, and he seemed to remember me. When I asked him about his dismal prognosis for my survival, he said sadly, At that time, that was what we told parents back then. I think he was relieved that his prognosis was wrong. I know that I certainly am. In fact, I am hoping to live another

Former Wales and British Lions center Ray Gravell has died of a suspected heart attack aged 56. Gravell won 23 caps for Wales and played on the Lions tour of South Africa in 1980. He made his debut for Wales against France in 1975, three years after helping his club side Llanelli to their famous win over the touring All Blacks.

Gravell made 23 appearances for what was then a dominant Wales side. He won Grand Slams in 1976 and 1978, and played all four Tests on the Lions tour of South Africa in 1980. After retiring as a player in 1985, Gravell became president of Llanelli RFC. He also pursued a career as an actor and a respected rugby broadcaster.

In South Carolina, where African Americans make up about half of Democratic primarygoers, voters might not have a problem with McClurkin at all.

Condoleezza Rice says people need to serve where they are needed. Rice was responding to foreign service officers objections to the possibility of directed assignments in Iraq. If the State Department enforces directed assignments, it will be the first time since the Vietnam War era.

One official called the order to serve in Iraq a potential death sentence during the town meeting. The State Department already has begun notifying about 200 people considered prime candidates. Those chosen will be given 10 days to respond, according to last weeks announcement.

Some at the hourlong meeting questioned why they were not told of the policy change directly. I just have no respect for the whole process because youve demonstrated a lack of respect for your own colleagues, one diplomat said.

The secretary of state sent out a cable to State Department employees worldwide encouraging them to serve in Iraq. Others pointed out the risks of such assignments, considering the dangers of a war zone, lack of security and regular rocket attacks on U.S. personnel. Rice, who did not attend the meeting, tried to calm things down by underscoring the State Departments attempts to do everything that we can to try and protect our diplomats.

Ambassador Ryan Crocker has identified the need for additional positions to more effectively accomplish our mission in Iraq. Rice said she has decided to go forward with the identification of officers to serve, should it prove necessary to direct assignments. The commander of the nuclearpowered submarine USS Hampton has been relieved of his command amid an inquiry into misconduct by crew members. None of the misconduct is believed to be connected with the major fires burning in the area.

Michael B. Portland lost his post due to a loss of confidence in his ability to command. William J. Houston will replace Portland. The crew neither maintained inspection records nor conducted the required inspection of chemical levels associated with the cooling system of the ships nuclear reactor.

Portlands demotion brings to 10 the number of people relieved of duty on the submarine in the wake of the misconduct probe. Six personnel have been punished for forging inspection records for the cooling system. One officer and five enlisted personnel received a nonjudicial punishment after other Navy personnel discovered their actions.

The misconduct was discovered September 17 but not made public until after completion of an initial inquiry. A factfinding investigation is under way, and further action against Navy crew members is possible. The Hampton remains in port in San Diego, California. In all, the 900 million vessels crew includes 13 officers and 116 enlisted personnel.

Three years ago, Kelly Pless weighed 220 pounds at her heaviest. She lost 95 pounds through diet and exercise. Pless now weighs 145 pounds and is 5-foot-3.

The 31-year-old graduate student from Sunny Isles Beach, Florida, has struggled with her weight. She started gaining as a teenager and by the time she graduated from high school, she was carrying 215 pounds on her 5 2 frame. Prom, she says, was a nightmare.

After high school, she lost 50 pounds. But because she hadnt done it in a healthy way, her weight crept back up. At 28, she started having trouble breathing and doctors told her the weight was to blame.

I remember feeling like even if I tried, it wasnt something my body was capable of. Despite her doubts, Pless decided to do something. Fortunately she didnt have to look far for inspiration. Her manager at the Kennedy Space Center ran marathons.

Pless believed that if she just focused on eating less and moving more, everything would fall into place. At first, it was hard to start exercising because I was worried people would make fun of me. But then I just told myself, if thats the worst that could happen...

I just got out there and didnt care. Eventually, she started to run or shuffle as she jokingly recalls. She also adopted an eat to live philosophy and satisfied her cravings for sweets by eating lots of fruit.

That was my weak spot. After a few months of cutting those things out, I focused more on portion control. Make sure Im not eating out of boredom or at social events, I try to make sure I'm not overeating, just because everyone else is.

Pless pays close attention to societal pressure, which she believes is the reason many people overeat. Restaurant servings are about three times bigger than a normal portion size, she says. She makes sure she doesnt overeat when dining out simply because the food is there.
Pless has lost 95 pounds and kept it off for 1½ years. As a result, she says, shes healthier and more confident. Pless: "What do I really want to eat? Or, what does my body really want right now?"

Shes also set a new professional goal  to pursue a doctorate in food and exercise psychology so she can help others who are battling obesity and eating disorders. The negative side to weight loss is that people treat people differently.

Pless runs about 40 miles a week while she trains for two marathons she plans to run this winter. The first is in November in Las Vegas, Nevada, and the second is in Miami, Florida, in January. She said she cant imagine taking the break from running that recovering from surgery would require.

The Singapore Airlineowned A380 completed its maiden passenger journey between Singapore and Sydney. It was two years late and billions of dollars over budget, but this week it made history with the first double bed on a commercial jet.

On board were nearly 500 passengers who had bid thousands of dollars for the historical experience. Singapore Airlines CEO, Chew Choon Seng named the jetliner the queen of the skies. Tom Enders, CEO of Airbus said he would like to celebrate his 25th wedding anniversary on one of its double beds.

The A380 is the quietest large passenger jet ever built inside and out. It can carry 40 percent more passengers than other large aircraft and in greater comfort. The wellheeled can luxuriate in a private cabin designed by leading French yacht designer, JeanJacques Coste. And CNNs Richard Quest, who was on board the maiden flight, said there was nothing quite like it.

Travelers can catch a movie on a 23inch widescreen LCD. Laptops can be plugged into an inseat power supply. Business travelers with just a thumb drive can access a suite of office tools on Singapore Airlines inflight entertainment system.

Singapore Airlines has ordered 19 superjumbos for an estimated price tag of 5.7 billion. The first Boeing 747s soon ditched the lounges and bars on the upper decks in favor of seats that could generate cash. Behind the 12 luxury suites there are 399 economy seats, ranked 10abreast on upper and lower decks, as well as 60 business class seats that are the biggest yet at 87 centimeters wide.

One passenger paid 100,000 for the experience, with the majority paying between 1,500 and 5,000. The 1.4 million raised has gone to charities in Singapore, Sydney and a global humanitarian organization. From Sunday 28 October, Singapore Airlines will commence its scheduled service between Singapore and Sydney.

The jetliner will be used on one of the three daily flights between Singapore and Londons Heathrow Airport. The airline has a tough delivery schedule ahead to fulfil its 185 orders to 15 customers. Next year it plans to deliver 13, a further 25 in 2009 and 45 in 2010.

Airports around the world have had to make changes to runways and gates, as well as buy in new vehicles that can tow the giant aircraft. Seventy airports are now ready, Airbus has said. Singapores Changi Airport, home to the Singapore Airlines A380 fleet, was the first, and when its new Terminal 3 opens early next year, 19 gates across the three terminals will be A380ready.

Heathrow's new Terminal 5 will be able to handle four A380s at one time. British Airways, the Terminals sole occupant, recently confirmed an order for 12 superjumbos and it now wants BAA to upgrade a satellite building to be built next to Terminal 5 to accommodate them. As Willie Walsh, BAs CEO told CNN, we want to make sure that development is built with the A380 in mind.

As Richard Quest says, theres no doubt the A380 will sell, but it is going to take a long time to reach the 420 sales which is the amount Airbus needs to make money. But those worries, he adds, are for another day. Thursday was a day for celebration. Total 185 orders 165 firm orders 15 customers.

The U.S. will increase export restrictions on technologies that could pose a danger to national security. China and Iran pose particular export control concerns, the Justice Department says. Representatives of more than a half dozen federal agencies will jointly announce their plans. Officials plan to highlight two recent cases at a news conference Thursday.

In the past week a Pittsburgh company, SparesGlobal Inc., was sentenced for lying about an illegal export. In Utah, two men were charged last week with attempting to illegally export restricted components for F4 and F14 fighter jets. King Abdullah of Saudi Arabias visit to London this week caused a wave of dissent. UK political elite boycotted events. UK foreign secretary pulled out of a meeting with his Saudi counterpart. Saudi King accused British officials of ignoring information that could have averted the terror attacks in London on July 2005.

Saudi Arabia is the UKs largest trading partner in the Middle East. The UK is the second largest foreign investor in the Kingdom. UK Trade  Investment has designated Saudi Arabia one of its 17 High Growth Markets.

Saudi Arabia is planning six privatelydeveloped economic cities. The 26.6 billion King Abdullah Economic City will create one million jobs. The aim, says the Saudi Arabian General Investment Authority, is to boost the economy by creating a probusiness environment. The UK has, since the early 1990s, been one of the top five exporters to Saudi Arabia.

In 2007, Saudi Arabian bank SABB predicts that UK exports to the Kingdom will increase by more than 5.5 per cent to reach 2.8 billion. In the 1980s, three quarters of Saudi exports to Britain were from oil, but today the nonoil sector accounts for 59 percent of exports.

Products being shipped to the UK include machinery, transport equipment, plastics, nonmetallic minerals and, despite the UKs dominance in the sector, chemicals. There are also more than 150 SaudiBritish joint ventures underway with a value of around 15 billion. The biggest deal that will mark their relationship in trade is the purchase of 72 Eurofighter Typhoon Jets that was sealed last week.

This comes less than a year after the UK government decided to call off a Serious Fraud Office investigation into defense contracts with Saudi Arabia. This probe related to the sale of weapons by BAE Systems to Saudi Arabia in the 1980s. BAE has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing and making payments to Saudi royals to win business.

Tens of thousands of Congolese refugees fled camps Tuesday in the Democratic Republic of Congo as rebel troops attacked government forces in the area. U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees said it didnt appear rebels had targeted the camps, but it reported some were looted after camp residents, classified as internally displaced persons, fled.

Roads to Goma, about 10 miles from the camps, were crowded with refugees and local residents fleeing the fighting. Torrential rain made the movement even more difficult. Internally displaced people are moving from site to site, direction Goma.

The Congolese government accused troops under rebel general Laurent Nkunda of staging the attack. A NKunda spokesman denied the allegation, according to a report from the Integrated Regional Information Networks. The spokesman, Bwambale Kakolele, said Rwandan Hutu rebels who also operate in the area were behind the attack, that report said. Now they have nothing but what they can carry.

A spokesman for the U.N. military mission in the Congo said it was uncertain which group attacked the Congo army outpost. The UNHCR said 375,000 Congolese in North Kivu province have been forced from their homes in the past year. In the past two months alone, 160,000 have fled their homes amid the fighting between renegade troops and government forces, the agency said. It said about 28,000 had abandoned the first three camps.

Genarlow Wilson served two years of a 10-year sentence for aggravated child molestation. 21-year-old says prospect of being labeled a sex offender drove him to turn down the deal. North Kivu is in eastern Congo near the borders of Rwanda and Uganda. Congolese President Joseph Kabila has tried to gain a ceasefire with the rebels in the area under Nkunda, but fighting continues.

He had to think about his 9yearold sister and having a family of his own one day, he says. "I wouldnt be able to stay with my mother because I have a little sister. You know, when youre a sex offender you cant be around kids"

In 2005, a jury found Wilson guilty of aggravated child molestation for having oral sex with a 15yearold girl. The conviction carried a 10year mandatory prison sentence and a sex offender designation. Prosecutors in Douglas County, Georgia, offered Wilson a plea deal that would have reduced his sentence.

The state Legislature last year amended the law under which Wilson was convicted, making such sexual encounters misdemeanors. However, the Legislature did not make the law retroactive, so it had no effect on Wilsons sentence. Now 21, Wilson was released Friday after the state Supreme Court ruled 43 that the young mans sentence constitutes cruel and unusual punishment.

The new Genarlow Wilson will be more conservative, more alert and more appreciative of the blessings bestowed upon him. He wants to major in sociology, he said, because I feel like Ive been living my major. I know what it feels like to be without and I dont want to ever feel like that again, he says.

Though he called his sentence absurd, Wilson said he understands that prosecutors were doing their job and they felt they were carrying out the law. Wilson also said he knows what he did was foolish. I did some idiotic things in my teen years, but you know, every average teen does, he said. I dont think any of us made very wise decisions.

Dianne Feinstein and Charles Schumer announced they would support the retired federal judge from New York. The chairman of the Judiciary Committee announced his opposition to the nominee. If all the Republican members of the committee also vote for Mukasey, which is expected, his nomination will go before the full Senate. A leading Democrat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Wednesday that the nomination is likely to be confirmed.

Gonzales gave up the post in September. This is an extremely difficult decision, Schumer said. When an administration so political, so out of touch with the realities of governing and so contemptuous of the rule of law is in charge, we are never left with an ideal choice.

A number of Democratic senators, however, have said they will oppose Mukasey because of questions about his views on the interrogation technique called waterboarding. Waterboarding involves restraining a suspect and using water to produce the sensation of drowning. While saying serious questions have been raised about Mukaseys views on torture and on separation of powers, Feinstein said she would support the nominee because the Justice Department needed fresh leadership.

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Sen. Patrick Leahy, DVermont, announced he would vote against the Mukasey nomination. No American should need a classified briefing to determine whether waterboarding is torture, Leahy said. Watch Sen. Leahy explain why he cant support the Mukasesy nomination on CNN at 10 p.m. ET.

Waterboarding was used at least as long ago as the Spanish Inquisition. We prosecuted Japanese war criminals for waterboarding after World War II. America needs to be certain and confident of the bedrock principle that no one, not even the president, is above the law.

President Bush has equated asking Mukasey about his opinion of waterboarding with asking him about the CIArun interrogation program, whose details are classified. Bush said the program does not violate U.S. bans on torture, but added that MukaseY does not want an uninformed opinion to be taken by our professional interrogators in the field as placing them in legal jeopardy.

Sources say waterboarding was used in the interrogation of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed. He is now facing trial before a military tribunal for planning al Qaedas 2001 attacks on New York and Washington. Sources with knowledge of the CIArun interrogation program have said agents are no longer using waterboarding.

The practice was used by the Spanish Inquisition, Cambodias Khmer Rouge and the World War II Japanese military. It is specifically banned in U.S. law governing the treatment of prisoners by the military. Nine people were killed and 19 injured after a tour bus left a highway and rolled over Sunday night.

At least 50 people were on the Arrow Stage Lines bus when it crashed. The bus was traveling from Telluride, Colorado, to Phoenix, Arizona. It left the right side of the highway and rolled over, Trooper Cameron Roden says.

Police said the bus lost control on a curve, ran off the road and rolled over several times. The roof of the bus split open and multiple occupants of the vehicle were ejected. Rescue crews took the injured people to hospitals in Utah, Colorado and Arizona. The Salt Lake Tribune reported that ambulances from Utah,. Colorado, Arizona and New Mexico responded to the accident.
Four of the dead were male and five were female, the Utah Highway Patrol says. Most of the passengers were returning home from a weekend ski trip to Telluride.

Banksy has been spray painting his stencils around Britain and further afield for over ten years. Last week ten of his original pieces were sold at Bonhams auction house in London for over 1 million. Tower Hamlets council authority has pledged to remove his graffiti from its streets. The artist's art sells for hundreds of thousands of dollars but he continues to use public spaces as his main canvas.

Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie bought three of his prints in 2006. Fans include Hollywood Alisters, including Christina Aguilera. The recent sales of his work put him on a par with JeanMichel Basquiat as the bestselling street artist. He set out to lampoon the establishment, he has now been wholeheartedly embraced by it. His work is now sold now by major art galleries.

Banksy is feted by art dealers and artists, including Damien Hirst. He regularly mocks the art world that is so enthralled by him. Despite the huge popularity and exposure of his work, Banksys identity remains a mystery. It took the British Museum eight days to discover the prehistoric rock painting of a man with a shopping trolley.

Banksy is originally from Bristol, is around 30 years old and called Robert or Robin Banks, but its been reported that even his parents are thought to believe that he makes his living as a painter and decorator. He continues to divide opinion as to whether his work is vandalism or public art. Bristol city council has recognized the popularity and artistic merit of his work by protecting a number of pieces around the city.

Tower Hamlets and Hackney councils in London have pledged to remove his graffiti from their streets. But this latest piece may also have revealed what the artist actually looks like. A passerby took a photo of what is thought to be the artist at work.

A spokesperson for Banksy refused to confirm it was him, but did say it was definitely his work. Naples has had problems in finding sites for municipal dumps now workers have stopped collecting trash. There is a popular saying here that roughly goes like this everybody is competent enough to find a solution but nobody is responsible for actually carrying it out.

Naples dumps reached full capacity more than a decade ago. Since then a state of emergency has been declared every year. Eight different commissioners have been appointed, but they have all failed to solve the problem. The problem is as old and ugly as rotten trash.

State of emergency means government money 1.8 billion more than 2.5 billion in emergency funds have been devolved to deal with the problem. It is still difficult to find out where or how that money has been spent. One Italian newspaper suggested that a good 20 of the money went to pay for the salaries of those in charge of coming up with a solution.

The Naples prosecutor in charge of environmental crimes says city government officials use the state of emergency to quickly award contracts. Once they receive the money, companies linked to the underworld dispose of the waste either in the open or, ironically, at regular city dumps. The mafia clans have now managed to burrow their way so deeply into the system that every attempt to fix the problem has proved futile.

The government wants to reopen a previously shut dump to dispose of 3,700 tons of waste which is laying in the streets of Naples and surrounding areas. The problem is that when the site was closed years ago, locals were promised that a golf course would be built there.

Russian President Vladimir Putin says security threats have forced Russia to revive bomber flights. Putin said 14 strategic bombers had taken off simultaneously from airfields across Russia in the early hours of Friday on longrange missions. "We have decided to restore flights by Russian strategic aviation on a permanent basis," Putin told reporters after inspecting joint military exercises with China and four Central Asian states in Russias Ural mountains.

White House spokesman Gordon Johndroe said he did not believe the flights posed a threat to the United States. The sorties are likely to add to Western concern about Russias growing assertiveness. That trend has prompted some U.S. policymakers to draw parallels with the Cold War.

Putin caused a stir this year by saying Russian missiles would once again be aimed at targets in Europe if Washington persisted with plans to build a missile defense shield in eastern Europe. Russian diplomats have clashed with the United States and European governments on issues such as Kosovo, energy, and Moscows treatment of its exSoviet neighbors.

Flights by other countries strategic aircraft continue, Putin says. That appeared to be a swipe at the U.S. and NATO, whose strategic bombers have continued to fly longrange missions. Four Russian military helicopters appeared and hovered in the background while Russian tanks trundled behind him. During the Cold War, Russian longrange bombers played elaborate games of catandmouse with Western air forces.

The Pentagon said the Russian aircraft had not come close enough to U.S. ships to prompt American aircraft to react. In July, two Russian Tu95 Bear bombers made unusually long sorties over the North Sea, leading Norway and Britain to scramble fighter jets to follow them.

A businessman asked Louis Lassen for something quick that he could eat on the run in 1900. He cooked up a beef patty, put it between some bread, and sent the man on his way. Pretty modest beginnings for arguably the most popular sandwich of alltime. The burger did not come from Louis so ketchup is OK.

If you visit Louis today, youll find that not much has changed. The Lassen family still owns and operates the restaurant. The burgers are still cooked in ancient gas stoves. Just like then, there is absolutely no ketchup allowed.

ChipShop owner Christopher Sell had the brilliant idea to freeze the snack, dip it in batter, and deepfry it. Even The New York Times raved about how something magical happens when you taste the deepfried Twinkies. Sell, who was trained in classical French cuisine, didnt start with the Twinkie, though. In his native England, he fried up everything from MMs to Mars bars.

In August of 1893, a failed goldminerturnedsodacompanyowner named Frank J. Wisner was drinking a bottle of his Myers Avenue Red root beer while looking up at Cow Mountain. Just then, a full moon illuminated the snowcap on the otherwise black mountain, and Wisner had a brilliant idea. The new drink was christened the black cow and became an instant classic.

Cozy Dog Drive In opened alongside old Route 66 in Springfield, Illinois in 1946. Ed Waldmire, Jr. wanted to call his creation the Crusty Cur, but his wife convinced him to change the name to Cozy Dog. Cozy Dogs Drive In has been serving up corn dogs ever since.

Gennaro Lombardi opened up a small grocery store in New York Citys Little Italy. In 1905, the establishment was licensed as a pizzeria, and its stayed that way ever since. The original restaurant closed in 1984 but reopened down the street 10 years later. The Pizzeria  Lombardis is located in the Little Italy neighborhood of New York.

On its 100th anniversary in 2005, Lombardis decided to offer its pizza for the same price itd been sold for in 1905  5 cents a pie. Since 1979, Rutgers University has played host to a collection of mobile food vans collectively known as the Grease Trucks.

Originally, they served a sandwich called the Fat Cat, which contained two cheeseburger patties. A hungry and broke student named Darrell W. Butler convinced one of the vendors to put chicken fingers, mozzarella sticks, French fries, and marinara sauce on a sandwich. The concoction sounded so appetizing that the next 10 people in line ordered it.

Pats King of Steaks is where the Philly cheesesteak was born. A cab driver who ate at Pats daily insisted on trying the new sandwich. With the first bite declared, Hey, forgetbout those hot dogs, you should sell these! Cab drivers know fast food about as well as anyone, so the brothers did just what the cabbie suggested.

In no time, the modest stand turned into the Pats that exists today. Controversy remains, however, over whos responsible for putting the cheese in cheesesteak. Pats claims it was the first to do so in 1951, but acrossthestreet rival Joe Vento of Genos Steaks opened 1966.

Pig Stand was one of the first restaurants to advertise using neon signs. A Kentucky favorite, derby pie is a chocolate and pecan tart with a pastrydough crust. The company also lays claim to opening Americas first drivein and inventing Texas toast.

Melrose Inn manager George Kern created derby pie in the mid1950s with help from his parents, Walter and Leaudra. Mrs. Kern, being the crafty monopolist she was, copyrighted the name, and to this day, you can only get real DerbyPie through Kerns Kitchen, Inc. Not only that, a man from New England once handed Leauda a blank check for the recipe so that his daughter could make the pie at home. She refused.

The terror plot was unraveled after a weekend raid outside Baku that netted several suspected members of the radical group. Britain also shut its embassy in Baku to the public on Monday following security concerns nearby. The Bibi Heybat Mosque, just outside the capital Baku, was the target of the plot, U.S. and Azerbaijans officials said.

U.S. State Department spokesman Sean McCormack stressed that the details are still unfolding. Several days ago, an Azerbaijani army officer who had connections to a radical Islamic group seized four assault rifles, a machine gun and 20 hand grenades. Government security forces tracked down the group and arrested several members during a sweep on Saturday. One suspected member of the militant group resisted arrest and was killed in the sweep, the spokesman said. officials.

Several others are still at large, he added. The U.S. Embassy in Baku issued a warden message warning Americans in Azerbaijan to take precautions. Azerbaijan is a former Soviet republic that borders the Caspian Sea, and lies just north of Iran.

McCormack said U.S. authorities are working closely with their counterparts in Baku. He said he expects the embassy to limit its operations on Tuesday, as well. The crew members of a North Korean freighter regained control of their ship from pirates. The USS James E. Williams ordered pirates to give up their weapons, the Navy says.

Two pirates were killed and five were captured, the Navy said. The captured pirates were being held aboard the North Korean vessel. The bandits had seized the ships bridge, while the crew kept control of the steering gear and engines. Three wounded crew members were being treated aboard the guidedmissile destroyer USS James E. Williams.

When the crew members stormed the bridge, the deadly battle began. After the crew regained control, Navy sailors boarded the Dai Hong Dan to help with the injured. North Korea and the United States have no diplomatic relations.

A second U.S. Navy destroyer is searching waters off Somalia for pirates. Gunmen aboard two skiffs hijacked the Panamanianflagged Golden Nori over the weekend. The guidedmissile destroyer USS Arleigh Burke has been pursuing the pirates. It entered Somali waters with the permission of the troubled transitional government in Mogadishu.

Two military officials familiar with the details confirmed the ongoing operation. When the shots were fired, it was not known the ship was filled with highly flammable benzene. U.S. military officials indicate there is a great deal of concern about the cargo because it is so sensitive.

Benzene is used as a solvent and to make plastics and synthetic fabrics. Four other ships in the region remain in pirate hands, the Navy says. U.S. and NATO warships have been patrolling off the Horn of Africa for years in an effort to crack down on piracy. The head of the transitional government resigned as his administration battled insurgents from the Islamic movement.

Hospital officials reported 30 dead in three days of clashes on the citys south side. In June, the ship USS Carter Hall fired warning shots in an attempt to stop a hijacked Danish cargo ship off Somalia. In May, a U.S. Navy advisory warned merchant ships to stay at least 200 miles off the Somali coast.

The pirates often are armed with automatic rifles and shoulderfired rockets. Vessels that increase speed and take evasive maneuvers avoid boarding. Those that slow down are boarded, taken to the Somali coastline and released after successful ransom payment. The agency issued a new warning to sailors in the Gulf of Aden, between Somalia and Yemen, after Sunday's hijacking. The pirates are often after protracted negotiations of as much as 11 weeks.

Debra Lafave was arrested after talking with a teenager. She is not allowed to have contact with anyone under 18. But the judge did not send Lafave to jail, saying the violation was not willful and substantial.

Lafave pleaded guilty in November 2005 to having sex with a 14-year-old boy. She was sentenced to three years under house arrest and seven years of probation. A tracking device she carries as part of her probation went off in court, prompting the prosecutor to observe, I think shes accounted for.

Lafave acknowledged she was aware that hugs and other forms of physical contact as well as conversations about sex with minors violated terms of her probation. She referred to the sexually explicit conversations at work as just girl talk.

Lafave said she hugged the 17-year-old because it was a small restaurant with a casual atmosphere where coworkers felt like family. She received a verbal reprimand a year ago, according to testimony. The contacts that led to Thursdays probation violation hearing first surfaced during two polygraph tests administered as part of Lafaves courtordered supervision.

When the behavior continued, her probation officer asked a judge to find her in violation. She was ordered to quit the restaurant job and now works as a receptionist in her mothers beauty shop. In the past, Lafave has said she suffers from bipolar disorder and is receiving treatment.

Ralph Lauren has had a greater impact on the way American men and women dress than any other designer. The former tie salesman from the Bronx has his eye on China and Japan. He has also signed a deal to develop boutique spa hotels around the globe in former monasteries. Because, in the end, hes Ralph Lauren, and were not.
Those ties were handmade, by the way, recalls Lauren. Back then, ties, even designer ones, didnt sell for more than 5 apiece. Mine were 12 to 15. Such luxury in something so simple was revolutionary.

Lauren caught something that was in the air before any of his competitors had a chance to grab it. Lauren made it look as easy as Fred Astaire dancing down a staircase. What matters the most to me are clothes that are consistent and accessible, says the designer. It's the desire, not just to be a success but to look like one before youd even achieved your goal.

When I look at the people Ive admired over the years, the ultimate stars, like Frank Sinatra, Cary Grant and Astaire, the ones who last the longest are the ones whose style has a consistency, whose naturalness is part of their excitement. Fashion is about establishing an image that consumers can adapt to their own individuality.

The spotlight is always going to search for the newcomer, Lauren admits. But the key to longevity is to keep doing what you do better than anyone else. Its about getting your message out to the consumer.

Lauren says she relies on people walking into her store saying,I want your clothes. Her clothes  the clothes we make for the runway arent concepts, she says. Thankfully, we have lots of them, says Lauren.

Laurens effortless luxury is all over the red carpet, on ski slopes and boats, at Wimbledon and elsewhere. But far from giving his customary overthehead wave and riding off into his Coloradoranch sunset, the designer is going even more global.

Lauren has stores in Milan, London, Paris and Moscow. More stores planned for China, Japan... oh, everywhere. There arent enough Americans out there, he says. Who better to start with than Ralph? Just as long as he doesnt let on that most of us still cant play a lick of polo.

Suspect in fatal shooting of Philadelphia police officer captured in Miami, Florida. John Lewis, 6 feet, 270 pounds, was easy to spot as he was so tall, police say. Officers went to a homeless shelter where they found Lewis, who was pretty easy to spotted as hes 6 feet,. 270 pounds. He had taken a Miamibound bus from Philadelphia.

He was apprehended unarmed and without incident, the Miami chief said. Miami Police Officer Gil Gonzalez said Lewis had a Bible and was praying when we went to get him. Philadelphia Mayor John F. Street said people at the shelter recognized Lewis from televised photos.

Lewis is suspected in the October 31 shooting of Philadelphia Police Officer Chuck Cassidy. Cassidy was shot in the head when he inadvertently walked into a robbery in progress at a Dunkin Donuts. Investigators said Lewis was spotted on security video boarding a bus to Miami on Saturday night.
Mariano Santiago was shot in the shoulder late last Tuesday as he approached a vehicle. Officer Sandra VanHinkle was shot early last Sunday and is out of the hospital and doing well, police say.

Lewis had been arrested in 2005 on drug charges, which were withdrawn after he completed a treatment program. He was arrested again in June on drugs charges, and that case is still pending, the AP reported.

Tiburon means shark in Spanish, and its not hard to see how Hyundais sporty coupe can stalk the unwary firsttime buyer and snare them quickly. To break from the boring econobox, here are some of the more sculpted and stylish cars available for about 20,000 that will hold their looks for a long time.

Tiburon in its third incarnation is perhaps the purest lowslung sportster that wont bust a firsttime buyers wallet. The startling Hyundaidesigned looks boast a touch of Italian styling uncommon for its bracket. The MazdaSpeed3 will storm from standing to a mile a minute in under six seconds and is said to hit 155 mph. This one isnt overbearingly dripped in trim or wings, but dont let any youngster tell you it doesnt have what it takes to make their peers jealous.

Its secret is torque negation in the low gears and perhaps its 263 horses under the hood. Another hidden gem is its sevenspeaker Bose stereo. Much like the fantastic Chevy Cobalt SS, its younger sister Pontiac G5 GT boasts highly sprung motoring at a price that appeals to the firsttime buyers wallet.

A new grille entirely, like a Phantom, may just be what you need to set it off against the crowd. The GTs inlinefour 2.4liter 173hp engine  drives the front wheels to hit 060 mph in 7.5 seconds. Gas mileage is good and customer satisfaction ratings are off the hook.

The Civic hatch was my second car after a very shortlived VW Rabbit. The coupe tested earlier this year brought back fond memories of the Civics surprisingly roomy front cabin. Standard features include a 350watt premium sound system, a touchscreen satellitenavigation system whose screen flips to reveal the CD player, and a slot for a computer memory card.

The secondgeneration Scion FJ Cruiser is a hipster take on the Toyota FJ. Features include a central console that fits in a DVD player alongside a backlit GPS satnav system that lights up in any one of 10 colors. This one turns heads while allowing you to pack five adults in relative comfort. Its also got a funky dash that spectrally lights at night  what fun.

Energetic, filled with flair and boasting a vertical fold the length of its bonnet. You dont get a third row of seats in there but, with the back row folded flat, it almost lends you to believe it can become a camper. Other great touches include an mp3 input jack and reclining rearseat headrests.

President Bush blasts Congress for having worst record in 20 years. Congress is not getting its work done, Bush says. Bush criticized Congress for not being able to send a single appropriations bill to him. They havent seen a bill they could not solve without shoving a tax hike into it, he said.

President Bush said the Senate was wasting valuable time by taking up the childrens health insurance bill, which he had earlier vetoed. Rep. Rahm Emanuel, DIllinois, issued a statement saying, congressional Republicans remain ready and willing to rubberstamp the Bush agenda. No to children's health care no to a new direction in Iraq and no to investing in Americas future.

House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer calls Bush the biggest obstacle to extending health coverage to 10 million lowincome, workingclass American children. The State Childrens Health Insurance Program measure passed in the House last week would expand the program by nearly 35 billion over five years. Bush had proposed adding 5 billion to the program, and said the version he vetoed would have encouraged families to leave the private insurance market.

Democratic leaders said the new version addresses Republican objections by tightening restrictions on illegal immigrants receiving SCHIP benefits. The program currently covers about 6 million children whose parents earn too much to qualify for Medicaid, the federal health insurance program for the poor. Democrats want to extend the program to another 4 million, paying for it with a 61centperpack increase in the federal tax on cigarettes.

The Senate could vote on the bill as early as Tuesday. There are now reports that Congressional leaders may be considering combining the Veterans and Department of Defense appropriations bills. Congress should pass each bill one at a time in a fiscally responsible manner, he said.

Bush also urged Congress to send him a clean defense appropriations bill and a war supplemental bill. Hoyers release said Bushs comments on appropriations bills and fiscal responsibility ring hollow. Bush also criticized Congress for trying to hold hostage funding for troops.

The fight over 2008 appropriations bills is not a fight over spending, Malvo says. Democrats are the party of fiscal responsibility today, he says. Malvo: This administration has pursued the most fiscally irresponsible policies in American history. He says he is still grappling with shame, guilt, remorse and my own healing.

Malvo, 22, spends 23 hours a day inside his cell at Virginias toughest prison. Social worker who has worked extensively with him said he draws selfportraits that often show him with a tear running down his cheek.

Malvo and John Allen Muhammad terrorized the Washington area five years ago this month. Malvo's greatest fear is that another parental figure would abandon him, social worker Carmeta AlbarusLindo says. She says Muhammad became the teenagers surrogate father, convincing him that violence was the only way to correct perceived injustices to AfricanAmericans. He ordered Malvo to go to bed each night and to memorize passages from The Art of War, an ancient Chinese text on battlefield strategy.

According to AlbarusLindo, Malvo was brainwashed into aiding Muhammad in the murders. However, prosecutors have said Malvo, even at 17, knew what he was doing. And when a Virginia jury spared Malvos life, some investigators said they were horrified.

Some of the victims families said they are content that Malvo did not receive the death penalty. Vicki Buchanan Snyder, whose brother James Sonny Buchanan was shot in the back while mowing a patch of lawn, said she was satisfied with the verdict. As for Malvo, AlbarusLindo said he will never forgive himself for what has happened.

When she first began seeing him, he still called Muhammad Dad. It took months, she said, before he stopped. In the interim, AlbarusLindo said, he took college correspondence courses and began to draw. Muhammad is at a Virginia prison called Sussex One.

Muhammads ex-wife, Mildred, said she believed that she was the real target of the snipers. She runs a Web site called Afterthetrauma.org, devoted to the victims of domestic abuse. He wants to correct, he said, some inaccurate statements made by the news media.

Mildred Muhammad said she feels her exhusband wanted to kill her as revenge. She said she too is convinced that John Allen Muhammad brainwashed the younger man. That boy was a victim before he even knew it, she said. His life was over when he said,Hi.

Lucarelli keeps his place in the Italian squad after scoring twice against South Africa. Donadoni has again left out veteran forwards Filippo Inzaghi and Alessandro Del Piero. Juventus striker and Italy under21 international Raffaele Palladino gets his first callup. Italy go into the clash in Glasgow third in Group B, two points behind leaders France and one point below Scotland.

Italy end their qualifying campaign by taking on bottom side the Faroe Islands in Modena on November 21. Goalkeepers Marco Amelia Livorno, Gianluigi Buffon Juventus, Gianluca Curci Roma. Midfielders Massimo Ambrosini AC Milan, Mauro Camoranesi Juventus, Daniele De Rossi Roma, Gennaro Gattuso AC Milan. Strikers Antonio Di Natale Udinese, Alberto Gilardino AC Milan,. Vincenzo Iaquinta Juventus, Cristiano Lucarelli Shakhtar Donetsk, Raffaele Palladino Juventus, Fabio Quagliarella Udinese. Luca Toni Bayern Munich.

Eric Prince is the chairman and CEO of the Prince Group and Blackwater USA. Blackwater provides an opportunity for military and law enforcement veterans with a record of honorable service to continue their support to the United States. Prince: Words alone cannot express the respect I have for these brave men and women who defend  who volunteer to defend U.S. personnel facilities and diplomatic missions.

I am proud to be there to represent them today. After almost five years in active service as a U.S. Navy SEAL, I founded Blackwater in 1997. Ten years later, Blackwater trains approximately 500 members of the United States military and law enforcement agencies every day.

We are extremely proud of answering that call in supporting our country. Blackwater personnel supporting our overseas missions are all military and law enforcement veterans. No individual ever protected by Blackwater has ever been killed or seriously injured.

Numerous others have been wounded and permanently maimed. Blackwater personnel are subject to regular attacks by terrorists and other nefarious forces within Iraq. Our thoughts and our prayers are with their families.

Any incident where Americans are attacked serves as a reminder of the hostile environment in which our professionals work to keep American officials and dignitaries safe. In doing so, more American service members are available to fight the enemy. Blackwater shares the committees interest in ensuring the accountability and oversight of contract personnel supporting U.S. operations.

Blackwater looks forward to working with Congress and the executive branch to ensure that any necessary improvements to these laws and policies are implemented. The worldwide personnel protection services contract, which has been provided to this committee, was competitively awarded and details almost every aspect of operation and contract performance. In Iraq, Blackwater reports to the embassys regional security officer, or RSO. In conjunction with internal company procedures and controls, the RSO ensures that Blackwater complies with all relevant contractual terms and conditions.

We have approximately 1,000 professionals serving today in Iraq as part of our nations total force. Blackwater does not engage in offensive or military missions but performs only defensive security functions. We at Blackwater welcome the FBI review announced yesterday, and we will cooperate fully.

A recent report from the Department of State stated that in 2007 Blackwater conducted 1,873 security details for diplomatic visits to the red zone, areas outside the Green Zone in Iraq. Weapons were discharged in less than 1 percent of those missions, the report said. "To the extent there is any loss of innocent life, ever, let me be clear that I consider that tragic," he said.

Benfica midfielder Augustin Binya sent off for tackle on Celtic's Scott Brown. Cameroon international was sent off in Benfica's 10-1 defeat in Glasgow. UEFA have punished the midfielder with a six-match European ban. Click here for more UEFA news.

Benfica midfielder Binya banned for two years for tackle on Brown. Referee Martin Hansson described the challenge as one of the worst he had ever seen. Binyas challenge seriously endangered the physical health of the opposing player, according to uefa.com. Benfica can appeal against the ban, which rules the 24-year-old out of their remaining Group D matches against AC Milan and Shakhtar Donetsk.

If unsuccessful, Brown will also miss any matches in the knockout stages of the Champions League or UEFA Cup. It is the second time that UEFA has had to intervene following an incident involving Celtic this season. AC Milan keeper Dida was handed a twomatch ban, subsequently reduced to one on appeal, after collapsing theatrically when a fan of the Scottish club invaded the pitch and lightly slapped the Brazilian in the face.

Sen. Hillary Clinton remains the person to beat, a CNNOpinion Research Corporation poll released Monday suggests. The New York Democrat continues to dominate the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. But Clintons path to the White House is in no way certain. Clinton was criticized for her performance during a debate last week, and her rivals have stepped up attacks that she has equivocated on Iraq, Iran and other major issues.

The Republican presidential candidates have also stepped up their attacks on the Democratic frontrunner. Each suggests that he has the best chance of stopping Clinton. The attacks may be working. The CNNOpinion Research polls suggests that Clintons support has slipped from its height one month ago.

Clinton is the top choice of 44 percent of the likely Democratic voters interviewed for the poll. Her closest rival, Sen. Barack Obama of Illinois, was the top choices of 25 percent. All other Democratic candidates were in single digits. The poll involved 467 interviews conducted on November 24 with Democrats or independents who lean Democratic.

The polls margin of error was plus or minus 4.5 percentage points. In an October CNNOpinion Research poll, Clinton was supported by 51 percent of Democratic voters and had a 30 point lead over Obama. Clinton received heavy criticism from her fellow Democratic presidential rivals.

The American people deserve a president of the United States that they know will tell them the truth, Edwards said. Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

Putins trip to Tehran is a show of Russias independence in global affairs. Putin, who approaches the end of his term, wants to demonstrate that he wouldnt cave in to the U.S. pressure. Putins schedule also includes meetings with Ahmadinejad and Irans supreme leader, Ali Khamenei.

Eighth District Judge Jackie Glass hours earlier doubled Simpsons bail to ensure his appearance at an April 7 trial. Glass said Simpson had violated terms of his previous bail. Galanter did not contest the authenticity of the recording. As part of his bail granted September 19, Simpson was to have no contact whatsoever with victims, witnesses or codefendants in the case. When I tell you, Mr. Simpson, there are conditions and there are rules, let me make sure you understand if you violate those rules... youll be back, locked up in the Clark County Detention

I understand 100 percent, said Simpson, dressed in a navy blue jail jumpsuit. The Air Force is returning F15E Strike Eagle jets to service over Iraq and Afghanistan. The Air Force grounded models of its F15 fleet after the crash of an older model F15C this month. The charges stem from a September 13 incident at a Las Vegas hotel in which he allegedly stole sports memorabilia. The F15E must pass an inspection of critical parts on the airframe before returning to flying missions. The F15s were grounded after a crash earlier this month in Missouri of an older model. All U.S. Air Force 224 Emodel aircraft will undergo a onetime inspection of hydraulic system lines.

Former detainees of Immigration and Customs Enforcement accuse agency of forcibly injecting them with psychotropic drugs. One of the drugs in question is the potent antipsychotic drug Haldol. Doctors say they are required to see patients in person before such drugs are administered. Two immigrants, Raymond Soeoth of Indonesia and Amadou Diouf of Senegal in West Africa, say they were injected with the drugs against their will.

Both are plaintiffs in a classaction lawsuit brought by the American Civil Liberties Union against the government. They are seeking an end to the alleged practice and unspecified damages. Dr. Paul Appelbaum, a professor of psychiatry, law and ethics at Columbia University, reviewed both mens medical records.

Allegations of ICE forcibly drugging deportees were raised last month by Sen. Joe Lieberman. Lieberman intends to follow up with ICE to ensure that detainees are not drugged unless there is a medical reason to do so. ACLU attorney Ahilan Arulanantham, who is representing Soeoth and Diouf, said, It would be torture to give a powerful antipsychotic drug to somebody who isnt even mentally ill.

1,073 immigration detainees had medical escorts for deportation since 2003. 56 received psychotropic medications during the removal process. Of those, 33 detainees received medication because of combative behavior with the imminent risk of danger to others andor self, she said. "I am aware of, and deeply concerned about reports that past practices may not have conformed to ICE detention standards," Myers said.

She added no detainee should be involuntarily medicated without court order, except in emergency situations. Soeoth, a Christian minister from Indonesia, spent 27 months in detention awaiting deportation. Hours before he was to be sent back home on December 7, 2004, he says guards injected him with a mystery drug.

Soeoth says he was taken to Los Angeles International Airport while in a druginduced stupor. He says airline security refused to transport him, so ICE agents returned him to his cell at Terminal Island near Los Angeles. Terminal Island, once a federal prison, is a crowded facility along the ocean where hundreds of illegal immigrants await deportation. Soeoth denies ever making the remark that he would kill himself if deported.

Diouf says he was injected on the plane right before he was to be deported. He said he even had a federal stay of his deportation  and the paperwork to prove it. But his U.S. government escorts wouldnt let him show it to the pilot of the plane preparing to fly him out of the country.
Diouf and Soeoth remain in the U.S. pending a decision in the case. If they lose, they may land back in the hands of ICE, once again facing deportation.
Soeoth says hes traumatized by what happened. I know this country is very generous to immigrants, he says. "What they did to me was very, very bad," he says of the baby sitter.

Barack Obama says Sen. Hillary Clinton has shown flawed judgment. Obama says Clinton helped give President Bush a blank check to take military action against Iran. Jim Webb that would prohibit military operations against Iran without congressional approval.
Clintons 2002 vote shows a clear difference in judgment between the two of them, Obama said. I think her judgment was flawed on this issue. It speaks to how we will make decisions going forward.

He later called his vote a mistake. In a veiled swipe at Clinton, Obama also suggested he could better unite the country and offer something new. Right now, my goal is to make sure I am the nominee, and she is still the senator from New York.

Three Chinese nationals accused of importing thousands of counterfeit luxury handbags. Harris soon will appear in the movie American Gangster, starring Denzel Washington and Russell Crowe. The film is set to open November 2.

Proenza is still employed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Deputy Director Ed Rappaport has been temporarily placed in charge. Proenza says he has contacted his superiors in Washington about ways to move forward. Proenza graduated from Florida State University with a degree in meteorology. More than 1,700 people have died in Bangladesh after a devastating tropical cyclone. Cyclone Sidr made landfall Thursday night along the western coast of Bangladesh near the border with India. Thousands of people have been displaced and many are still missing. Bangladeshi air force, army and navy are working to provide shelter for the many people who have been displaced. Power is still out in much of the country but it is being restored. The government has identified the 12 worst districts all of them located on the southern coast.

High wind speeds of Cyclone Sidr have laid waste to the allimportant rice crop and caused a huge loss of livestock. 280,000 families have been rendered homeless by the cyclone, but many have been able to get shelter from family members. World Vision is deploying 135 staffers and 7,000 volunteers to provide food, shelter and other relief.

Power outages, massive traffic jams and spotty phone service are reported in Dhaka. Red Crescent spokeswoman Nabiha Chowdhury says 15,000 people are injured and 1,000 are missing. The U.N. World Food Programme says it has enough highenergy biscuits to feed 400,000 people for several days. Another humanitarian group, Save The Children, appealed for aid from the public. Many families have lost everything, including their homes and their crops, and they are struggling to survive.

U.S. prepositioned 16 Zodiac boats, water treatment systems, water ambulances and food for a more rapid response. Defense Secretary Robert Gates was expected to approve plans to send up to three Navy amphibious warships, with up to 3,500 Marines, to locations off the coast of Bangladesh. The song Until the Day Is Done also will appear later this month in Planet in Peril. The fourhour CNN documentary looks at environmental crises around the world. Planet in Peril features CNN anchor Anderson Cooper, chief medical correspondent Dr. Sanjay Gupta and Animal Planet host and wildlife biologist Jeff Corwin. The U.S. government wants to build a border fence like this one. About 100 landowners are fighting it. The property is a remnant of a 12,000acre grant from Spain to her family in 1767.

This week, the Justice Department began legal action against landowners who have refused to give government surveyors access to their land. Tamez expects she will be sued sometime soon, but she is not intimidated. Asked how long she will fight, she said, As long as I have to.

Chertoff believes a fence would curb the steady stream of illegal immigrants. He also argues it will increase the safety of Border Patrol agents. The government wants to build 700 miles of fence along the Mexican border.

About 70 miles of fence is to be built in the Rio Grande Valley by years end. The Rio Grande forms a natural barrier along this stretch of the border. But in some places it is narrow enough to swim across.

The Border Patrol has stepped up its efforts in the Rio Grande Valley with more lights, and sensors to pick up movement. A levee built along the river has a muddy road on top used by Border Patrol vehicles to patrol the area. Cortez and other border mayors formed a group called the Texas Border Coalition. The coalition wrote to Chertoff asking for further consultations on the fence. This week the Department of Homeland Security turned them down.

Cortez said his city is contemplating a court test of the law that mandated the construction of the border fence. U.S. Customs and Border Protection wrote in an email that they do not plan to suspend work on the fence. "I have an Americangiven right to protect my property," Eloisa Tamez said.

Some Christian congregations are turning to the Church of Scientology. Scientologists do not worship God, much less Jesus Christ. The church has seen plenty of controversy and critics consider it a cult. So why are observant Christians embracing some of its teachings?

Two pastors say they are not scared off by programs with ties to Scientology. Critics say Scientology has aggressive recruiting, secretive ways and rigid theology. The Rev. James McLaughlin of the Wayman Chapel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Houston, Texas, is one of the pastors who spoke with CNN.

Scientology was founded in the 1950s by L. Ron Hubbard, a science fiction writer. Followers are taught that they are immortal spiritual beings called thetans. Although the church says there is a supreme being, its practices do not include worshipping God.

Scientology has long been in the headlines for practices critics say are little more than cultlike mind control. Critic Rick Ross, a courtcertified Scientology expert, sees something more sinister at work. He warned that mainstream acceptance makes it easier for the Scientologists to achieve their ultimate goal  new recruits.

Scientology has been recently diversifying its outreach to include other religions and ethnic groups. Kennedy, McLaughlin and a handful of other Christian church leaders  no one can say how many are finding answers to their communities needs in Scientologys social programs. It is also known for its stable of devout celebrity followers.

Kennedy found a message he believed could help lift his predominantly lower income AfricanAmerican congregation. He said the books 21 principles help them with their struggle in an urban environment. Kennedy knew that before he could introduce any Scientologyrelated text to his congregation, he would have to prove that it did not contradict his Christian beliefs. And so, he found Scripture to match each of the 21 principles.

He believes it is easier to understand and clearer to follow than ancient Scriptures taken from the Bible. When asked whether Scientologys values contradict the religion of Jesus Christ, Kennedy replies, Sometimes yes. But he says his congregation can relate to The Way to Happiness.

At Kennedys C. L. Kennedy Center, free tutoring based on Hubbards study tech philosophies is provided to dozens of children and some adults. Jimirra Kennedy insists she does not ascribe to the religious side of Scientology, she still considers herself, at least in part, Scientologist.

Critics like Ross are alarmed by such a blurring of the lines. They consider it a marketing win for Scientology. In Houston, McLaughlin says he is not one to argue with success. McLaughlin spent years searching for a solution before he discovered Narconon.

McLaughlin trained at Narconon and brought the techniques back to his community to launch First Step Faith Step. He claims a 70 to 80percent rehabilitation success rate. Kennedy and McLaughlin said they have never lost a member of their congregations to Scientology.

The Church of Scientology would not grant CNN an interview. The attack occurred Tuesday near an office housing judicial police in the city of Thenia. Sens. Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama will duel for Super Tuesday votes. The Democratic presidential hopefuls face off for the first time together. The debate is taking place at the Kodak Theatre in Los Angeles, California. It is sponsored by CNN, the Los Angeles Times and Politico.

The event is the first Democratic debate since Obamas convincing victory Saturday in South Carolina. The forum at the Kodak Theatre in Hollywood comes hours after the Obama campaign revealed it had raised 32 million in January from roughly 170,000 new donors.

The Clinton campaign would not indicate how much money it had raised in the same time period. Mike Gravel, the other Democratic presidential candidate still in the race, was not invited to participate in the debate. In a CNNOpinion Research Corporation poll conducted January 1417, Gravel received less than 1 percent.

Edwards suspended his presidential run Wednesday in New Orleans, Louisiana, but he didnt endorse any candidate despite what aides described as furious lobbying campaigns by Obama and Clinton. Clinton and Obama have split victories in their parties earlyvoting states. Obama has won in Iowa and South Carolina, and Clinton in New Hampshire, Nevada, Michigan and Florida. All major Democratic presidential candidates pledged to avoid campaigning in those states following national party penalties against them for moving up their contests so early.

Superdelegates are party leaders and elected officials who are not obligated to support a particular candidate. They can change their decisions at any time leading up to the Democratic National Convention in August. Obama has won an estimated 63 national convention delegates as a result of primary or caucus votes. Clinton has earned an estimated 48 delegates.

The incident threatens to cast the country into political uncertainty ahead of a key presidential vote. U.S. President George W. Bush, in a written statement, joined other world leaders in condemning the horrific assassination. Since October 2004, there has been a tragic pattern of political assassinations and attempted assassinations, Bush says. The U.S. opposes any attempts to intimidate the Lebanese people as they seek to exercise their democratic right to select a president without foreign interference, he says. A spokesperson for Ban Kimoon says the U.N. secretarygeneral condemns in the strongest terms this terrorist attack. The U.S. Embassy in Beirut issued a statement saying It is not a coincidence that these attacks target those figures who have been working to secure Lebanons independence from renewed Syrian hegemony. Many Lebanese politicians allied with Syria have in fact warned that murder and violence would be the results of any effort to exercise genuine parliamentary democracy, the embassy said. The bombing that claimed these lives was another act in a campaign of terror by those who want to turn back the clock on Lebanons hardwon democratic gains.

The Madrid train bombers and various terrorist cells in Italy were part of the Salafi school of thought, he added. The main suspect in the operation is a Tunisian who was arrested in 2002 during a separate antiterrorism operation, police said.

The main terrorist cell was based in the northern Italian region of Lombardy. Another cell, based in Reggio Emilia, had the goal of creating a grand Islamic empire stretching from Morocco to China. Those arrested are also accused of producing false documents and facilitating illegal immigration.

Mira Nair read The Namesake while in huge grief with the death of a beloved person to me Miras mother in law. Its a tale of millions of us that have left one home for another, and tried to find out who we are through these places. It is also equally a love story between two people who come from a culture who dont send roses and diamonds for love who sit at a kitchen table and look at each other.

Nair's 15-year-old son said, This has to be your Gogol. Penn became an actor because he had seen Mississippi Masala when he was eight years old. He came to my office and auditioned and he was just so appealing, and so much the real thing, that I cast him as Gogol. Its not that different a kind of audience, thats what pleases me. we really made for the children on the streets and the kids who really love that Bollywood stuff.

But no, they dont come to my films for Bollywood fare its a completely alternative thing. In India it is more about orchestrating chaos, and its about sifting the chaos. In America its about paying for the chaos, you know every head has to be placed there and paid for.

CNN The Namesake is about not losing the identity of Indian culture. I am at home in many cultures. I live actively in three continents and Ive done that for most of my life. I just make films as I see the world, and that happens to speak to people.

Michael Mazza, 40, was arrested outside a pawn shop in Hollywood, Florida. Death of Broward County Deputy Paul Rein sparked a massive manhunt. Mazza was being taken to the second day of his trial in connection with the armed robbery of a Coral Springs bank. It was the third shooting of aBroward County sheriffs deputy in four months.
Mazza and Rein left about 805 a.m., Lamberti said. Minutes later, a truck driver who saw all or part of the altercation near Pompano Beach called 911.

The struggle began when Rein apparently pulled the medical transport van over at an intersection. Mazza allegedly took Reins service weapon away from him and shot him. After the shooting, Mazza is believed to have thrown Rein from the van and driven away.

A city public works employee later spotted the bloodspattered van in Fort Lauderdale. Mazza is believed to have hitchhiked his way down to Hollywood. He approached a man at a pawn shop and asked for a ride. The man, who was headed to a second pawn shop, agreed.

As he was talking to the clerk, a television in the shop began broadcasting news about the deputys shooting, and showed a picture of Mazza. Mazza was arrested shortly afterward. Reins gun was found with Mazza in the mans car, the sheriff said.

Mazza faces charges including firstdegree murder and escape. Mazza initially was reluctant to talk to authorities, but later agreed, the sheriff says. He was serving a life sentence for robbing a drugstore in Coconut Creek, Lamberti says. The sheriff says Mazza will be housed at another facility outside of Broward County, Dade County.

Mazza was dressed in civilian clothes  a suit rather than jail scrubs Wednesday. He was on trial for robbery of the Coral Springs bank. Broward County also has a pending case against Mazza for a February drugstore robbery. Police are investigating whether he had planned the escape in advance.

Reins coworkers told reporters he was in outstanding condition physically. Broward County deputies conduct some 400 to 500 inmate court transports a day. Thin staffing and scant resources prevent more than one deputy being involved.

As news of the escape broke, all 273 schools in Broward County went on lockdown. Lamberti said Reins wife spoke to her husband by cell phone just 10 minutes before he was shot. She said you never think its going to happen to you, the sheriff said.

U.S. attorney in San Francisco has opened a federal criminal investigation into the crash of the MV Cosco Busan. The captain and crew were barred by law from leaving the vessel, which is docked for repairs in Oakland, the Coast Guard said. Nearly 400 birds were killed in the crash and oil spill, which prompted a federal investigation. The Coast Guard says human error factors probably were involved in the accident.

The Cosco Busan was departing Oakland for South Korea when it struck a tower supporting the western suspension span of the Bay Bridge. About 58,000 gallons of heavyduty bunker oil poured out of the vessel as it was moored near Treasure Island. Adm. Thad Allen, Coast Guard commandant: "There were probably some human error factors, but we need to determine the facts"

Allen defends the Coast Guard against criticism of its response to the spill. The oil sickened birds and formed globules on more than 20 of the areas beaches. It oozed along the San Francisco city waterfront and out of the bay.

Boxer said the Coast Guard initially reported that the ships owner had said only 140 gallons had spilled from the Cosco Busan. Boxer and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California have called for congressional hearings into the accident and resulting spill. Response was set into play within an hour of the event itself, Allen said Monday.

The NTSB is interviewing the pilot, the ships crew, and other pilots who were on the water at the time of the crash. The crew had been on its inaugural voyage on the ship, which the current owner purchased last month. The NTSB also intends to review the ships voyage data recorder, which should have recorded captain and crew conversations on the bridge.

Angel Island State Park, the Bays largest island, reopened Monday. Schwarzenegger has declared a state of emergency, freeing money to clean up the spill. Seven miles of containment boom stretched across the bay has collected more than 12,271 gallons of oil so far. Nearly 400 dead birds have been recovered from the bay.

In 1989, the oil tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground and fouled Alaskas Prince William Sound with almost 11 million gallons of crude. Thousands of birds and animals died in the disaster. Twenty wildlife teams were scheduled Monday to be the bay, working to find sick birds so they can be rehabilitated.

On Sunday, the states other U.S. senator and a leading Coast Guard official decried the accident. This an incident which, in my view, should not have happened, Sen. Dianne Feinstein, DCalifornia, said. Rear Adm. Craig E. Bone, the Coast Guards director of inspection and compliance, echoed Feinsteins comments.
