Journalist Eric Weiner wanted to explore the relationship between place and happiness. He made it his mission to find the most content places around the globe. He uncovered lots of surprises along the way, including a tropical paradise in South Africa.

A warm climate doesnt necessarily make a happy nation, Weiner said. Money can degrade happiness, he found. Weiner wrote the book, The Geography of Bliss One Grumps Search for the Happiest Places in the World.

Weiner spent 10 years as a foreign correspondent for National Public Radio. His job took him to some of the least happy places in the world. A world map of happiness, based on 100 different studies, listed Denmark as the worlds happiest nation. But for Weiner, the place where he felt the most bliss was a tossup between Bhutan and Iceland.

Weiners list of favorites also included Thailand, India and Switzerland. Bhutan is probably the closest thing on Earth to ShangriLa, Weiner explained. He pointed out that while other countries focus on their gross domestic product, the Himalayan kingdom proudly touts its policy of gross national happiness.

The Bhutanese very much believe that happiness should be part and parcel of every government decision, Weiner said. He visited the country during winter and said he found a certain beauty in the cold and the darkness.

The cold inspires people to cooperate, traditionally. Simple pleasures like trains arriving on time contributed to national happiness, he said. People in cold climates have to cooperate or they die together.
The Swiss eat a lot of chocolate, and lets not forget that, Weiner said. He was also impressed with how the Swiss view money. Their attitude is that if youve got it, hide it.

The United States came in at No. 23 on the University of Leicesters world map of happiness. The relationship between money and happiness took Weiner to the Middle East and Qatar. He went there specifically to examine what happens when the entire country wins the lottery.

He found the wealth made the residents comfortable, but also degraded their level of contentment. There are no income taxes in Qatar, but thats not a cause for contentment, Weiner found. Some taxation is necessary for happiness because its a way of being invested in a place, he argued.

In a country where theres no taxation at all, people dont have vested interests in how well the government performs. You cant say,Hey, those are my tax dollars at work. Weiners book has struck a chord, recently rising to the top 10 of The New York Times nonfiction bestseller list.

Daniel Gilbert is a psychology professor at Harvard University and the author of Stumbling on Happiness. Gilbert said its only recently that a combination of biology, sociology and psychology has been able to answer the wheres and whys of happiness. The quest for happiness is the central preoccupation of human beings and has been for as long as there have been human beings, Gilbert said.

A Saudi Arabian human rights attorney is asking the government to allow him to represent a woman who was gangraped. The woman was sentenced to prison for speaking out about the case. Human rights groups want Saudi Arabias King Abdullah to drop charges against the rape victim.

The attorney, Abdulrahman alLahim, had his license revoked last week by a judge for speaking to the Saudicontrolled media about the case. The judge more than doubled the sentence against his 19-year-old client because she spoke to the media. CNN has been unable to reach Saudi government officials for comment on this report, despite repeated requests.

The case has sparked outrage among human rights groups. AlLahim had petitioned the court to sentence the attackers to the death penalty. Barring the lawyer from representing the victim in court is almost equivalent to the rape crime itself, says Fawzeyah alOyouni, founding member of Saudi Association for the Defense of Womens Rights.

Human Rights Watch calls on King Abdullah to void the verdict and drop all charges against the rape victim. The woman, who is married, and an unrelated man were abducted and she was raped by a group of seven men more than a year ago. The male victim was also given an increased sentence of 200 lashes and six months in prison.

The man and woman were attacked after they met so she could retrieve an old photograph of herself from him. AlLahim said the man was trying to blackmail his client. It is illegal for a woman to meet with an unrelated male under Saudis Islamic law.

AlLahim has been ordered to attend a disciplinary hearing at the Ministry of Justice next month. He faces a possible threeyear suspension and disbarment, according to Human Rights Watch. He said the handling of the case is a direct contradiction of judicial reforms announced by the Saudi king earlier this month. "We will not accept this judgment and Ill do my best to continue representing her because justice needs to take place," he said.

Under Saudi law, women are subject to numerous restrictions, including a strict dress code, a prohibition against driving and a requirement that they get a mans permission to travel or have surgery. Women are also not allowed to testify in court unless it is about a private matter that was not observed by a man. Human Rights Watch points out that a judge in Jeddah threw out a lawyer simply because he was a member of the Ismaili faith, a branch of Shia Islam.

The Saudi government recently has taken some steps toward bettering the situation of women in the kingdom. Christoph Wilcke of Human Rights Watch praised the female rape victim and her attorney for speaking out about the case. State Department spokesman Sean McCormack called the case and the punishment surprising and astonishing. The Saudi government is fully behind punishing a woman whos been raped and punishing the lawyer who tried to help her, he says. And if they hadnt spoken to the media, we wouldnt know about it.

Investigators seize computers and are analyzing information on Web sites. Most people would be quite astonished by the situation,  McCormack says. I cant get involved in specific court cases in Saudi Arabia dealing with its own citizens. But most people here would bequite surprised to learn of the circumstances and then the punishment meted out, says McCormack. The investigation into the deadly mall shooting in Omaha continues.

Robert Hawkins also left a voice mail for his mother before killing eight people. Hawkins visited a friend near the Westroads Mall before the shootings. Police dont yet know why Hawkins chose the mall or the Von Maur department store in particular, police chief says. He chose his victims randomly, police believe, then took his own life.

Hawkins left a suicide note and other correspondence, Warren said. Typically there are hints that something like this may take place, he said. If there is any justification, any explanation, police will find it, police said.

A friend of Hawkins family who was letting him live in her home found the suicide note just minutes before the shootings. He basically said how sorry he was for everything, she told CNNs Anderson Cooper on Wednesday.Apparently he had been experiencing some mental health problems, ideations of suicide.

Security officers flagged Hawkins as suspicious when he entered the mall. He left soon after he entered, then returned with something apparently hidden in a balledup sweatshirt. He went up an elevator to the malls third floor, then immediately began firing, ultimately turning the firearm on himself.
Hawkins fired more than 30 rounds, the police chief said. The shootings sent panicked holiday shoppers fleeing for cover. It was just so loud, and then it was silence, said witness Jennifer Kramer.

A friend of Hawkins said he hadnt thought Hawkins was capable of such violence. "He was the one guy, you know, if people would be getting in a fight hed be trying to break it up," Shawn Saunders said.

U.S. Army recruiters turned Hawkins down last summer when he tried to enlist, a source familiar with the situation said. Hawkins had been a ward of the state for nearly four years, but he did not specify in what capacity.

Heineman ordered that flags throughout the state be lowered to halfstaff through Sunday. The dead include six store employees and two customers, ranging in age from 24 to 66. One store employee was in critical but stable condition Thursday.

Westroads Mall remained closed Thursday, but the facility, including the Von Maur store, could reopen Friday. Jolie has been working to focus attention on problem of refugees in Iraq. There doesnt seem to be a real coherent plan to help them, said Jolie, speaking in an exclusive interview with CNNs Arwa Damon Thursday.

A goodwill ambassador for the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, Jolie wants to help the agency be more active inside wartorn Iraq. SunniShiite sectarian violence in the country has sparked a displacement crisis that is considered the most significant in the Middle East since the 1948 creation of Israel.

More than 4.2 million Iraqis have fled their homes. Many of the internally displaced live precarious lives amid conditions of squalor. How Iraq settles in the years to come is going to affect the entire Middle East, says Jolie. Its in our best interest to address a humanitarian crisis on this scale, she says. "Displaced can lead to a lot of instability and aggression," she adds.

Jolie has been working to help draw attention to the problem. She has called for governments to bolster their support of the U.N. The visit to Iraq is focusing on the problems of the internally displaced, 58 percent of whom are under age 12.

A top issue for the agency is getting better security. Jolie said it was crucial that the government prepare a plan to deal with refugees who return home from Syria and Jordan. She emphasizes the way in which these people are resettled will have broad implications in the region. The Iraqi government needs to empower agencies that deal with migration to address the concerns of the displaced.

Jolie also is talking to people about moving forward the U.S. effort to resettle Iraqi refugees in the United States. Only 375 have been admitted so far. Most of the refugees are in Syria and Jordan, and they reside in big cities like Damascus and Amman. Money is being allocated to Iraq and host countries to help clothe, feed and house people.

UNHCR is trying to help governments in Syria and Jordan to cope with the influx. It is also attempting to help 41,000 nonIraqi refugees in Iraq, such as Palestinians and Iranians. Last month, the UNHCR announced a plan to seek 261 million this year.

Ezequiel Lavezzi scores twice as Napoli beat Udinese 3-1. Argentine also provided the cross that Cristian Zapata put into his own net. Napoli move up to ninth in Serie A, while Udinese remain in fifth place. Both teams had a player sent off in Saturday's match in Naples. The match took place in a country where mixed Shiite and Sunni neighborhoods have turned into Sunni or Shiite enclaves.

Pepe leveled the score on nine minutes, and then Napoli played with 10 men from the 36th minute after Paolo Cannavaro was expelled for a lastman foul. Udinese are still four points behind fourthplaced Fiorentina and the last Champions League berth.

Miccoli struck in the 76th minute with a shot from just outside the area with Livorno goalkeeper Marco Amelia partially unsighted by several players. Palermo keeper Alberto Fontana saved a penalty by Francesco Tavano at the end of the first half. Inter Milan host secondbottom Empoli and secondplaced Roma travel to thirdbottom Siena. Thirdplaced Juventus host bottom club Cagliari, Sampdoria travel to Lazio, Parma play Atalanta and Reggina face fellow strugglers Torino.

As many as 28 in every 1,000 passengers do not arrive at their destination at the same time as their luggage. The trial  run by BAA and airline Emirates is using RFID radiofrequency identification technology to tag baggage. This will allow staff to more accurately track bags passing through the airport.

Barcode tags can be easily damaged in transit and are also at risk of being covered when scanned. BAA estimates that Heathrow can read only 60 per cent of labels that pass through. RFID is reported to offer over 99 percent accuracy.

A duplicate of the Heathrow system has been installed at Dubai Airport. Staff apply tags containing RFID chips to bags with information including the passengers name and route. The chips are then read on entry into the baggage system they are tracked as they move throughout and finally on leaving the system.

Emirates and BAA are sharing the costs of the trial. The main benefits will be for travelers passing through major hubs such as Heathrow and Dubai. RFID could extend services to frequent flyers, and provide the means to added value services such as faster checkin, and even be integrated with secure collection and delivery. The idea will be to send passengers a text informing them what belt and what time their bags will arrive at.

Hong Kong International Airport was one of the first to deploy RFID technology in 2005. RFID is being used in just 6 percent of the airports surveyed. For this system to really take off we need other airports and other airlines to embrace the technology, says Cowlam.

The SITA survey indicated that RFID tags will be used in 45 percent of airports by the end of 2009. There have been giant strides in the technology in aviation in recent years. This is a major step forward.

Hussein sent secret message to President Nixon in 1970 pleading with him to attack Syria. Papers are among about 10,000 documents released by the Nixon Presidential Library. Some of the documents offer harbingers of presentday events, such as concerns about terrorism and Saudi Arabia. Library director Timothy Naftali said the documents describe challenges such as how to get the Saudis more involved in solving the PalestinianIsraeli conflict, how to address the Arab view that the United States always sides with Israel.

Documents detail U.S. efforts to persuade Saudi Arabia to move away from Fatah, the military wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Officials believed the PLO was supporting the terrorist, antiIsrael group Black September, referred to as BSO. The Nixon White House also was adjusting to Israels acquisition of a nuclear weapon. The document release was intended to coincide with Mideast peace summit.

We are declassifying the records that laid the basis for Richard Nixons decision in 1969 to accept the fact, a fact of life, that Israel had a bomb, a nuclear device, said Naftali. Rather than openly declare itself as a nuclear power, Israel still maintains a strategic ambiguity over its nuclear weapons capability.

In 1970, as King Hussein dealt with threats by both Palestinian refugees in his country and Syrian military forces crossing Jordans border, the king asked the United States and Great Britain to intervene. Syria had invaded Jordan and the Jordanian king, facing what he felt was a military rout, said please help us in any way possible. The telegram indicates that Hussein himself called a U.S. official at 3 a.m. to ask for American or British help.

Nixon served as president from January 20, 1969, to August 9, 1974. He resigned under political pressure during the Watergate scandal. He died in 1994 after suffering a stroke at the age of 81. The library has withheld the Nixon documents from public access until Wednesday.

Orange was a native of Birmingham, Alabama. He was arrested and jailed in Perry County, Alabama, in 1965. His jailing sparked a fatal protest that ultimately led to the famed SelmatoMontgomery march and the Voting Rights Act. He died Saturday at Atlantas Crawford Long Hospital, the Southern Christian Leadership Conference says. He lived in southwest Atlanta for four decades while fighting the good fight for equality and social justice for all mankind.

Witnesses said Jackson was trying to get his grandfather to the hospital. Jackson, 26, died eight days later. The anger resulting from Jacksons death led civil rights leaders, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson, to speak out.

The first attempt at that march was broken up by clubwielding state troopers and sheriffs deputies. Jimmies death is the reason that Bloody Sunday took place, Orange said. Had he not died, there would never have been a Bloody Sunday.

In May 2007, a former Alabama state trooper, James B. Fowler, now 74, was indicted in Jacksons shooting. Fowler has claimed he shot Jackson in selfdefense, but two witnesses disputed that claim. President Lyndon Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act into law in August 1965. The case is one of several involving the deaths of civil rights activists that prosecutors have revived in recent years.

Orange was a project coordinator at the SCLC from 1965 to 1970. He later became a regional coordinator with the AFLCIO in Atlanta. Since 1995, he had served as the founder and general coordinator for the M.L. King Jr. March CommitteeAfricaAfrican American Renaissance Committee, Inc.

Voters in Beirut sent progovernment candidate Mohammed alAmin Itani to parliament. Both Eido, a Sunni Muslim, and Itani are members of the bloc led by Saad Hariri. But in Metn, a Maronite Christian suburb east of the capital, antigovernment candidate Camille Khouri upset former President Amin Gemayel by a few hundred votes, Lebanese television network LBC reported.

Khouri is a member of the Free Patriotic Movement, the antigovernment party led by former Lebanese Army Gen. Michel Aoun. Gemayel was seeking the seat held by his son Pierre, who served as industry minister in the government of Prime Minister Fouad Siniora before being gunned down in his car in November 2006.

Eido and Gemayel were among several Lebanese political figures killed since the February 2005 killing of the elder Hariri. All were critical of Syrias influence in Lebanon, and their supporters blamed Damascus for their deaths. Hariris killing triggered a wave of protests against Syria known as the Cedar Revolution, which brought Sinioras government to power.

ExCIA agent John Kiriakou says he underwent waterboarding in training and cracked in a few seconds. He spoke last week after the CIA disclosed that videotapes of certain interrogations were destroyed in 2005. That revelation has prompted new calls for investigations on Capitol Hill. The Bush administration appeared in U.S. District Court on Friday to answer questions about the tapes destruction.

Kiriakou says he was unaware that CIA interrogations were being taped. He says the tapes should have been kept as a matter of historical record. Kiriakou's attorney says the referral of the case to the Justice Department is standard procedure.

A criminal referral from the CIA would be both expected and normal under the circumstances. Zaid added that the question is whether the Justice Department will proceed, and that such a decision must be measured carefully. There would also exist a challenge regarding whether Mr. Kiriakou was being targeted for exercising his First Amendment rights.

CIA officers who leave the agency are required to sign documents promising never to divulge classified information. Written comments are cleared by an agency review board before publication. Unscripted oral comments  such as television interviews are referred to the Justice Department after the fact. An investigation could take months to complete, a source in the intelligence community said.

Kiriakou says he was not present when other agents used the waterboarding technique on Abu Zubayda. Kiriakou said he himself was subjected to the treatment during his training, and lasted about five seconds before having to stop.
Four years ago, Felicia Sullivan whispered in her live-in boyfriend's ear that he was the one for her. Sullivan, 32, who works in marketing, says she's glad to know he's the one.

Aghast at his response, Sullivan quickly broke things off  but she couldnt move until she found a new apartment. She decided to snoop through her exboyfriends email and discovered hed had contact with several other women while they were together.

Ive never been a big fan of the holiday, Sullivan says. But now I typically refer to it as Black Monday. Sullivan isnt alone in dreading Valentines Day. February 14 has gone from a sentimental aside to a pressurefilled gauntlet.

The holidays designed to make you feel bad, says Judy McGuire, author of How Not to Date. I think people should lower Valentines Day expectations to pretty much nil. That way, anything that happens is good.

Brian Wise, a 32-year-old technical writer from Seattle has seen his Valentines Day go sideways repeatedly. Wise talked his way out of an arrest luckily, one of the policemen had eaten at the same place but hes found no release from his unlucky Valentines. He says he met this beautiful woman who took him to dinner at this hot, new restaurant, he says. But then she gets food poisoning and ends up in an alley with major gastrointestinal problems.
Most women will admit they like to celebrate, but a fancy night on the town isnt necessary. Sometimes, hanging out at home can be a lot more fun than going out to some restaurant filled with couples.

Stay home with champagne, caviar and maybe a new toy from a tasteful sex shop. If youre not dating anyone, take some time to indulge yourself a luxurious bar of chocolate, a pedicure, do something relaxing take a yoga class or get a massage. Make sure youre on the same page. And if you do make plans, stick to them.

Galen's boyfriend wanted to go out with his friends on the big night. But his friends talked him into going out with them instead. "I was dressed to the nines," says Galen, who asked that her last name not be used. "He picked up his coat and left"

The two later broke up. To avoid a disconnect with your significant other, McGuire suggests being honest. McGuire recommends not settling for a cliché like a stuffed animal or a hastily purchased bouquet of flowers.
Listen to what the person talks about, says Katie Briggs, 44, of Seattle. She may want the newGodzilla game for her Wii. His underwear may be riddled with holes.
Briggs gave her date homemade cookies and a Starbucks gift card. He gave her a beautifullywrapped box  of Spam. He thought it was the best joke ever, says Briggs.

Attorneys for terror suspect say he was tortured while being held at secret prisons. They want judge to bar CIA from destroying evidence of alleged torture. One of 14 highvalue detainees held at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, alleges he was Tortured.

Majid Khan is a native of Pakistan who attended high school in Baltimore. Khan was held for more than three years at the secret CIA prisons. Khans attorneys say he suffers severe physical and psychological trauma from which he is unlikely ever to recover fully as a result of his ordeal. CIA spokesman Paul Gimigliano told CNN, CIAs terrorist interrogation effort has always been small, carefully run, lawful and highly productive. The motion was filed by the Center for Constitutional Rights attorneys on behalf of Majid Khan.

Khans attorneys claim he was taken into custody in 2003 and forcibly disappeared before his transfer to Guantanamo. He filed a legal challenge to his detention in September 2006 and appeared before a Combatant Status Review Tribunal in April. He was found to have been properly detained as an enemy combatant, but filed a challenge to that on August 14.

The Bush administration contends Khan was an operative working for Khalid Sheikh Mohammed. Khan researched how to blow up gas stations and poison reservoirs in the U.S., the administration has said. He is among 14 highvalue detainees held at Guantanamo. He has been on hunger strikes while in Guantanamo, and suffers from posttraumatic stress disorder.

In detention, he has been able to communicate with Abu Zubayda, the notes say. Zubyda was one of the two al Qaeda suspects whose interrogations were videotaped. Without a court order requiring the preservation of evidence, there is substantial risk that the torture evidence will disappear, attorneys claim. The motion was filed in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

Hayden has said the CIA stopped videotaping in 2002, while Khan was not taken into custody until the following year. City officials in New York have denied Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejads request to visit the site of the destroyed World Trade Center. The information developed by the detention and interrogation program has been irreplaceable, and the program has operated in strict accord with American law.

Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad asked to visit ground zero. But workers are rebuilding the foundations of the site, and it would not be possible for him to go. Iranian officials have not put in any additional requests to visit the public platforms at ground zero, police spokesman Paul Browne says. But, he says, If there were a further request, wed reject it because of security fears.

Ahmadinejads predecessor at the time of the September 11 attacks, Mohammed Khatami, condemned them. Iran is ruled by a Shiite Muslim government hostile to the fundamentalist Sunni al Qaeda. The United States and Iran have not had formal diplomatic relations since 1980 after Iranian militants stormed the United States Embassy in Tehran and held Americans hostage for 444 days.

The United States considers Iran a state sponsor of terrorism. It has accused the country of meddling in Iraq and in Afghanistan. More than 2,700 people died in the attack on the World Trade Center, when al Qaeda terrorists flew hijacked passenger jets into the twin towers. A third jet hit the Pentagon, and a fourth crashed in a Pennsylvania field after passengers resisted their hijackers.

Hillary Clinton, the New York senator and Democratic frontrunner, called the request unacceptable. Mitt Romney, a leading Republican, called it shockingly audacious. Former Mayor Rudy Giuliani said under no circumstances should Ahmadinejad be allowed to visit the World Trade Center site. Zalmay Khalilzad, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said the site should not be used as a photo op.

Lisa Nowak is accused of using pepper spray against a romantic rival. A Florida judge ruled evidence found in her car and statements she made to police after her arrest were inadmissible at trial. Washington accuses Tehran of trying to produce a nuclear bomb. Iran insists it is producing nuclear fuel for civilian power plants.

Lisa Nowak, 44, is accused of stalking Air Force Capt. Colleen Shipman and using pepper spray against her in a parking lot at Orlando International Airport in Florida on February 5. No written consent was obtained to search her car, Lubet wrote in his opinion. "This court must ensure that the constitutional protections afforded by our forefathers are scrupulously honored," he said.

She pleaded not guilty March 22 to charges of attempted kidnapping with intent to inflict bodily harm, battery and burglary of a vehicle using a weapon. If convicted, she would face a sentence of up to life in prison. Her defense attorneys had claimed Nowaks comments to police and her consent to search her car were made under duress.

Lubet said in his ruling that when Nowak asked Becton if she needed an attorney during the interview, he failed to answer her question in a simple and straightforward manner. There was a concerted effort to minimize and downplay the significance of the Miranda rights by referring to these constitutional rights asformalities, Lubet wrote. There is nothing in either the audio recording or the transcript of the interview that demonstrates that defendant understood these two rights and waived them.

Becton used legally impermissible statements and techniques, including threats, to get Nowaks statements and consent, Lubet says. Orlando Police Department spokeswoman says it is inappropriate for the department to comment on the case since it is pending in court. Lubet notes that, although Nowak was given the opportunity to use the restroom and was asked if she wanted something to eat, she was subjected to a barrage of questions.

Defendant had not slept during the preceding 24 hours, the judge said. Nowaks consent to search her car, Lubet wrote, followed illegal police activity. Prosecutors accuse Nowak of driving nearly 900 miles from Houston to Orlando  wearing NASA diapers. Her attorney has strongly denied that she wore the diapers.

Police said Nowak was detained as she was disposing of her disguise in an airport trash bin. Nowak has said she merely went to the airport to talk to Shipman, who had begun dating Nowaks former love interest, Navy Cmdr. Bill Oefelein, who was also an astronaut but has since left the astronaut corps.

He also testified he found used and clean diapers in the car. Police previously said they also found a BB gun, a steel mallet, a 4inch knife and rubber tubing in the vehicle. Nowaks attorneys in August filed a notice of intent to rely on an insanity defense.

Sharon Long is a forensic artist whose job is to help identify the dead, often murder victims. Armed with sculptors clay, glass eyes, wigs and research, Long creates a face from a human skull. When Fort Myers, Florida, police found eight sets of human remains in the woods in March, they turned to her.

She hopes that when the faces of those killed get printed in newspapers or appear on TV or online, a friend or loved one recognizes them and says, Gee, we havent seen soandso for a while, and that kind of looks like him.

Long, 67, has made faces for the unknown victims of grisly homicides and solved historical mysteries. She helped identify the crew of the H.L Hunley, a Confederate submarine sunk during the Civil War. She also created the first picture of the only explorer to have died on the Lewis and Clark expedition.

Eight men were found dead in a wooded area in Fort Myers, Florida, in 2007. There were no witnesses, no leads and little evidence of killings other than the victims bones. If Long could identify the victims of the crime, it might help to catch a serial killer.

Long first creates a mold of the skull and uses it to make a plaster replica. Sculptors clay fills in for skin and muscle. The faded gumline on the skulls teeth helps Long determine how thick the persons lips were.

The victims hair and eye color requires guesswork and research, Long says. Often while working on cases, she talks to people who lived in the same area as the victim or victims to find out the most common eye color. She spent two months on the Fort Myers skulls.
Erik Kohler and John Blevins lived hardscrabble lives and had runins with police. Eventually, publicity about the Fort Myers case would lead people with missing relatives to submit their DNA.

Police hope people with missing relatives will look at every detail of the other six sculptures to see whether they notice any resemblance, no matter how faint. Kohler and Blevins didnt closely mirror Longs sculptures of their faces, but there were some similarities, some facial features that looked like the two dead men. Fort Myers Police Detective Barry Lewis: I am just looking for that one little similarity, that onelittle key that someone could recognize.

Since the news conference, police say, they have received hundreds of leads. Longs work on the case might be done, but she still has nightmares about the eight men killed. I can see somebody dragging a body out there, and here he kept taking them to the same area, she said.
Zookeepers in Nuremberg will bottlefeed a fourweekold polar bear and rear it away from its mother. Six of those killed remain nameless. Police are still trying to find the killer.

The cub, which doesnt yet have a name, was being cared for at Nuremberg City Zoo. Its gaining weight, its very hungry, it drinks a lot of milk, said Alexandra Foghammar, a spokeswoman for the city. Wednesday, the zoo said keepers decided to take the cub away from its mother, Vera.
The cub is thriving in the care of humans, but Vera seems to miss her cub, Foghammar said. The zoo confirmed earlier this week that its other female polar bear, Vilma, had eaten her two offspring.

Zookeepers are pondering whether to bring another adult bear, possibly the cubs father, Felix, to the zoo to help Vera overcome her loss. The zoo said a keeper entered Vilmas enclosure Monday and noticed that her two cubs were nowhere to be found.

The zoo said it assumes Vilma ate her young because she believed the cubs were sick. But Foghammar said the separation of the bears was bad for the principle of wildlife conservation at the zoo. Now the cub will not grow up to act in a natural way, just as the mother lacked the experience to bring up a cub. The plight of the cub follows the case last year of Knut, a cub rejected by its mother at Berlin Zoo.

The four of them met and hugged and cried, said Boyd, the senior pastor at New Life Church in Colorado Springs, Colorado. Boyd was referring to a meeting on January 3 between Ron and Loretta Murray and David and Marie Works, whose daughters were killed in the rampage. David Works also was wounded in the shootings.

The pastor said he invited the Murrays to visit the New Life campus after praying over the holidays. The family was given a guided stepbystep tour of where the rampage took place. At one point, the parents also met with security guard Jeanne Assam, who shot their son in the leg.

The parents thanked Assam for her swift action and for helping save more lives. They told Assam that they were so deeply sorry she had to do what she did, a friend says. There were tears, lots of embraces, prayers, she says. The visit was important in the healing process for the Murrays.

Ive never seen repentance and forgiveness as profound as I did that day. This kid was raised in an upper middleclass home and had every chance to do well, Boyd said. The Murrays met the Works in Boyds office.

The pastor said he didnt tell many people about the meeting before it happened, fearing it could have gotten volatile and hostile. On Sunday, he began his sermon by telling his congregation about what had transpired just a few days earlier.

The Murrays visited the mission center December 12 and met with the families of the slain victims. Matthew Murray began his assault that day at the Youth With a Mission center in Arvada, Colorado. He killed two people  Tiffany Johnson, 26, and Philip Crouse, 24. He wounded two others before he went to the New Life Church, about 80 miles away.

13 wildfires have consumed more than 98,000 acres and destroyed or damaged at least 50 homes and businesses. More than 265,000 people have been evacuated and nearly 4,900 firefighters are battling the blazes. The winds driving the flames are expected to stay strong, coming out of the northeast, at least through Tuesday, says CNN meteorologist Rob Marciano. The fires began over the weekend.

California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger declares state of emergency in seven counties. Schwarzenegger asks U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates to order delivery of all available Modular Airborne Fire Fighting Systems MAFFS to help fight the fires.

Citing the proliferation in the number of fires, Schwarzenegger wrote. The federal Agriculture Department will provide fire crews, air tankers and helicopters. The state will receive assistance grants to help pay firefighting costs. One person was killed and 18 were reported injured in the county, including five firefighters.

Local officials said the fire situation had worsened throughout the day. Five of six homes in Rancho Bernardo burned to the ground, according to a KGTV report. "We have some of the highest temperatures," a county official says. "All the ingredients for a perfect firestorm"

Officials turn Qualcomm Stadium, home of the NFLs San Diego Chargers, into an evacuation center. Residents of four housing areas at the Camp Pendleton Marine base were put on notice for possible evacuations. Fires threatened the San Diego Zoos Wild Animal Park on Monday, causing the park to close. Some of the animals, such as endangered condors, are being moved to a safer location.

The largest of the wildfires is the Buckweed blaze north of Los Angeles. It has consumed 27,500 acres and forced the evacuation of 15,000 residents. Authorities are asking people to hold off on 911 calls unless there is a real emergency. Two fires that erupted Monday morning near Lake Arrowhead have destroyed at least 123 structures and charred 1,800 acres, a spokeswoman says.

Nearly 1,450 firefighters are battling the blaze in Malibu Canyon. The Canyon fire is only 10 percent contained, an official says. The Pacific Coast Highway remains shut down in the area. The fire is still threatening 900 structures, the state forestry department says.

Glasgow derby between Celtic and Rangers has been postponed as a mark of respect following the death of Motherwell captain Phil ODonnell. SPL secretary Iain Blair said: "These are never easy decisions. But we recognise that as a former player, Phil was part of Celtics extended football family"

Motherwells game against Hibernian on the same day was called off on Saturday night in the hours after ODonnell, 35, died following his onfield collapse. Gretnas match against St Mirren was also postponed as it was scheduled to take place at Fir Park which has become a shrine to the memory of ODonnell. The SPL confirmed that the other three fixtures scheduled for Wednesday will go ahead.

Motherwells home game against Celtic next Sunday had already been postponed by the SPL. Long distances over questionable roads stop many Indians from making it into courtrooms. In a nation of more than a billion people and millions of unresolved court cases, how do you take care of the backlog?
Judge Sandeep Singh's courtroom is a desk plopped down in the middle of a dusty schoolyard. It works like any other regular court, Singh said.

The mobile court is bused into rural areas to hear both criminal and civil complaints. With an estimated 300 million unresolved cases languishing in Indian courts, it could take more than 300 years to clear the docket at the current pace. People often have to travel long distances over questionable roads, using slow modes of transportation.

The mobile court claims to be both fast and efficient. Singh said he has been able to clear 1,100 cases in just six months time compared to 500 under the traditional court system. With distance no longer a problem, more villagers and their attorneys are coming to hearings.

Fran Townsend turned in her letter of resignation to President Bush on November 6. Townsend: Im going to just take another job doing 20hour days, but this time in the private sector. Townsend has spent 25 years working in law enforcement and government. Bush praised Townsends work Monday.

Townsend's job involved identifying terrorist groups around the globe and assessing their threat. She said that experience should will be useful in the private sector as well. Townsend said she first will look into public speaking, writing and board work before pursuing opportunities in global risk management for a large multinational corporation or financial institution.

Townsend's name had come up during the presidents recent search for a new attorney general. She said not getting the job had absolutely nothing to do with her decision to leave. Townsend said Bush had wanted her to stay on in his administration.

Townsend is part of the search committee to find a replacement by the beginning of next year. The president appoints the senior staff position, and it needs no Senate confirmation. "I have loved and will cherish my every minute of service," she says.

Lawsuit filed on behalf of nearly 400 Colombian families. Plaintiffs are seeking damages for terrorism, war crimes... and wrongful death. Chiquita, as part of a plea agreement, admitted that what it called protection payments had been given to Autodefensas Unidas de Colombia. The plaintiffs are asking for 10 million in compensatory damages for each of the 393 victims.

AUC was named a terrorist organization by the United States in 2002. The lawsuit alleges Chiquitas interaction with the paramilitary group went further than the payments. It accuses the company of facilitating shipments of arms to the group. They conspired with the AUC, aided and abetted them in a farreaching conspiracy, the suit says. The families filing the suit will remain anonymous because of fear of reprisals.

The principle upon which this lawsuit is brought is that when you put money into the hands of terrorists, then you are legally responsible for the atrocities, the murders and the tortures that those terrorists commit, Reiter said. Chiquita Brands International categorically denies the allegations made by these attorneys. The company said it had been forced to make protection payments to safeguard our workforce. It is absolutely untrue for anyone to suggest that these payments were made for any other purpose.

Mitchell said the company will fight the allegations. Chiquita has already been the victim of extortion in Colombia. We will not allow ourselves to become extortion victims in the United States, he said. In the March plea agreement, the company agreed to pay a 25 million fine for the payments.

Riley Ann Sawyers was beaten with belts, picked up by her hair, thrown across the room and held under water, according to an affidavit from the Galveston County Sheriffs Office. The affidavit says the girls mother, Kimberly Dawn Trenor, described to police how her daughter died and was put in a plastic storage box. The body of the thenunidentified toddler was found on October 29.

A fisherman found Rileys body stuffed inside a blue storage container that washed up on an uninhabited island in Galvestons West Bay. A medical examiner said the childs skull was fractured, and a forensic dentist estimated her age at 2 to 3 years. Police dubbed the child Baby Grace.

Trenor gave a voluntary statement on video with her attorney present in which she describes her involvement, with Royce Zeigler, in the physical abuse, death and disposal of her daughter, Riley Ann Sawyers. Trenors statement said on July 24, she andZeigler both beat the child with leather belts and held her head under water in the bathtub. After her daughter died, Trenor said, they went to WalMart that night and bought the Sterilite container, a shovel, concrete mix, and other supplies.

The box containing the childs body was hidden in a storage shed for one to two months. Then, Trenor said, she and Zeigler carried it to the Galveston Causeway and tossed it in. Riley Anns father, Robert Sawyers, on Monday tearfully remembered her as a funloving girl... with a big imagination.

Authorities are fairly confident that the toddler whose body was found on October 29 is Riley Ann Sawyers. DNA analysis is still in progress to confirm the identification. The family was devastated to learn that police believe Riley is dead. Its hard to think that Ill never see her again, she said, clutching a red Elmo doll she had planned to give Riley for Christmas.

Riley is originally from Mentor, Ohio, a Cleveland suburb. She and her mother came down to Texas earlier this year. The toddler was last seen in Texas three or four months ago, Tuttoilmondo says. The results will be available in two to three weeks, he says.

A new CNNOpinion Research Corp. poll suggests the battle for the Democratic presidential nomination is a statistical dead heat in Texas. 50 percent of likely Democratic primary voters support Clinton as their choice for the partys nominee, with 48 percent backing Obama.

The race is a virtual tie, taking into account the polls sampling error of plus or minus 4½ percentage points for Democratic respondents. One reason the race appears to be tight is that Texas Democrats are having a hard time choosing between two attractive options. Likely Democratic primary voters would be equally happy if either candidate won the nomination.

Roughly a quarter of likely voters say they could change their minds in the next two weeks. Many political strategists and analysts consider Texas and Ohio  which also holds a March 4 primary  mustwin states for Clinton. Obama has won the past eight contests and is now ahead in the overall battle for delegates.

Thirtytwo percent back former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee and 11 percent support homestate congressman and former Libertarian standardbearer Ron Paul. The CNNOpinion Research Corp. poll was conducted by telephone from Friday through Sunday.

McCain is the overwhelming frontrunner in the fight for the Republican presidential nomination. The poll was released on the same day the only living former Republican president George Herbert Walker Bush, the current presidents father  endorsed McCain at an event in Houston.

McCain is picking up a bare majority among conservative likely voters in the GOP primary. A McCain victory in Texas would not be based on the votes of moderates and independents. Texas Democrats and Republicans may not see eye to eye on the issues, but the poll suggests they do agree on whats the most important issue.

Thirty-five percent of Democrats and an equal number of Republicans said the economy was the most important issue in their choice for president. Health care was second, followed by the war in Iraq at 22 percent, illegal immigration at 10 percent and terrorism at 7 percent. Sixty percent of Republicans say theyll definitely support the candidate they are now backing.

Likely Democratic primary voters view Clinton and Obama on roughly equal terms. Seventynine percent say its likely Clinton can win the nomination 82 percent say the same about Obama. The Clinton campaign said the suggestion that her vote caused unrest in Pakistan is baseless. This is a time to focus on the people of Pakistan and not politics, said Obama adviser David Axelrod.
