Obama: This is one of those situations where Washington is putting a spin on it. He in no way was suggesting Hillary Clinton was somehow directly to blame for this situation. The Illinois senator added that its important for us to not look at this in terms of shortterm political points scoring.

Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani talked terrorism, connecting the attack in Pakistan to the September 11, 2001, attacks. McCain, who along with Giuliani scores best on national security, bluntly challenged Giulianis foreign policy experience.

Bill Richardson said he would call on Pakistans President Pervez Musharraf to step down. Former Tennessee Sen. Fred Thompson said calling for Musharraf to resign wouldnt be a good idea. What is in U.S. interest is for there to be a stable, democratic Pakistan that is fighting terrorists.

Former North Carolina Sen. John Edwards said he called Musharraf and urged him to continue this democratization process. Democratic hopeful Joe Biden, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said Bhuttos death was a genuine tragedy.

Former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee seemed to suggest Pakistan was currently under martial law. Huckabee's foreign policy credentials have been under a microscope since he admitted to journalists that he was unaware of a major report on Irans nuclear weapons program. Later Thursday, Huckabee told CNN that it was not that I was unaware it was suspended, two weeks ago, lifted. The point was, would it be reinstated, he said.

All of the aspects of martial law have not been completely lifted even now. Theres still a heavy hand Musharraf has used. If voters see a highstakes drama in Pakistan, that could resonate at the polls. Most of the candidates said they didnt want to turn the assassination into a talking point.
Lebanese civil war was in full flood when I was 14. We ran from school screaming. One afternoon the shells began raining down on our neighborhood.

After more than a decade of relative peace and reconstruction, the bombings and assassinations have returned to Beirut. Every time I hear of a new explosion, I think of a frightened child sitting in darkness. The memory of that terrifying afternoon receded until recently.

In 1988, I watched the last throes of Lebanon's civil war firsthand. Now I watch from another continent, but I find those same emotions resurfacing. The conspiracies, the car bombs, the threatening rhetoric and political deadlock are eerily familiar.

In 1988, the presidents term was coming to an end and the warring factions were unable to agree on a new candidate. Then, as now, a presidential election is the setting, and the struggle where religion and clan play the main roles.
Militias prevented parliament members from reaching the assembly building. Compromise was nowhere in sight. The West had abandoned Lebanon to the manipulation of its neighbors.

In his last act as president, Amin Gemayel named fellow Christian and Army Chief Michel Aoun as prime minister. Muslims refused to serve in the Cabinet and the country ended up with two governments. Aoun famously declared I am prime minister and six ministers in one.

Aoun turned on fellow Christians of the Lebanese Forces in the War of Elimination. When that failed, the Syrians drove Aoun to take refuge at the French Embassy. In August 1990, I came to CNN as a World Report panelist. I had seen people killed in front of me children orphaned in seconds.

So when I was offered the opportunity to stay at CNN, I gratefully accepted the chance to escape the anarchy. But almost as I left, the civil war was being laid to rest. Peace came to Lebanon, but it would be five years before I returned. In 1995, I went back and was stunned.

I kept looking around for checkpoints manned by militants. I couldnt believe that I could go anywhere without being harassed or kidnapped by one faction or another. No longer did identity  Christian, Muslim or Druze define where Lebanese could go.

Downtown Beirut, once rocked by explosions and pitted with bullet holes, was rocking to Lebanese pop music. The dusty sandbags had given way to boutiques carrying the latest European fashions. Lovers had returned to Beiruts Corniche, overlooking the Mediterranean, for romantic strolls at sunset.
On Valentines Day 2005, the Corniche was once again rocked by an explosion. Former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri was killed. On the day of love, Lebanon was thrown back into its most hateful history.

Suspicion fell on Damascus, which vehemently denied involvement. Even after it withdrew its troops, Syria still had allies in Lebanon. One was Hezbollah, accused of the suicide attacks that had killed scores of U.S. Marines in Beirut more than 20 years previously.
Another was Gen. Michel Aoun now back from exile. The spirit of the Cedar Revolution had evaporated. Antigovernment Hezbollah squatters had brought life there to a standstill.

Lebanese political actors now find themselves reenacting scenes from the final act of the civil war 19 years ago. Once again, the term of the president is approaching its end there is no agreement on his successor. Suspicion and fear are the political currency of the day.

Seven Manchester United supporters taken to hospital after violence. Violence flared before the 11 Champions League draw against Roma. Five fans received stab wounds while two others needed treatment for being drunk. Man United supporters were segregated inside the Olympic Stadium for the Champions tie. The match ended in a 1-1 draw between Manchester United and Roma.

Seven Manchester United supporters were taken to hospital after fighting broke out on the Pont Duca dAosta bridge. Five are receiving treatment for stab wounds while two others, one who was a 16-year-old boy, were understood to be drunk. None of the stab victims is understood to have serious injuries.

The situation in the stadium is now fine and everything is running smoothly. The embassy had warned travelling fans beforehand not to use the Pont Duca dAosta bridge because it was habitually used by Romas notorious Ultras. Roma coach Luciano Spalletti condemned the latest violence.

The trouble marked the second consecutive game between Roma and Manchester United in the Italian capital. Eighteen United fans needed hospital treatment in April after clashes on the terraces in Rome and outside the ground. The British Embassy in Rome had warned supporters faced a real danger of attack by the Ultras. The 1,200 British supporters who made the journey were largely shepherded into the stadium two hours before kickoff.

Chester Arthur Stiles, 37, of Nevada is being sought as a suspect in the videotaped rape of a 3yearold girl. Stiles former girlfriend told CNN she believes she put him in contact with the girl. Tina Allen said she is disgusted and mortified at her role in bringing them together.

De Meo addressed Stiles directly Turn yourself in to your local law enforcement agency. Stiles former girlfriend said she is stunned by the allegations. Watch Allen describe her first impression of Stiles.

Allen said she and Stiles had been in an onagain, offagain relationship for 10 years. He said hed been in the Navy and, you know, I was looking for a strong guy to represent to my sons what I thought they needed to be, Allen said.

I regret every, every step I ever took I feel bad for the baby. Todd Allen, Tina Allens son, said he recognized his old apartment from scenes in the video. He said his mother and Stiles spent time together there.
He said he never witnessed Stiles physically assault anyone. Tina Allen said Stiles hit her once but she didnt file a police report. She said she blames herself.
Allen ended her relationship with Stiles a few months ago. She said she believes it will be difficult for police to find him.

He will hide out in mountains if thats what it takes, she said. Allen said Stiles stopped by her house last week for a friendly visit before his name was linked to the videotape. She said his appearance had changed.

Stiles, a resident of Pahrump, Nevada, is a former animal trainer, authorities said. Darren Tuck, a Nevada resident who allegedly showed the tape to others before giving it to police, faces a possible sentence of 10 years to life for exhibiting pornography. Tucks attorney, Harry Kuehn, said last week on CNNs Nancy Grace that his client had been wracked by indecision as to what to do with the tape.

American al Qaeda member Adam Yahiye Gadahn renounces his U.S. citizenship. Gadahn displays his passport to the camera, rips it in half and says, Dont get too excited  I dont need it to travel anyway. The 50minute tape titled An Invitation to Reflection and Repentance was released by As Sahab, al Qaedas video production wing. It was provided to CNN by www.LauraMansfield.com, a Web site that analyzes terrorism.

The video refers to the Annapolis Conference, indicating it was produced after last November 27, when the conference was held. Gadahn speaks mostly in English, he references Bush  who is to travel this week to the Middle East only in Arabic. National Security Council Spokesman Gordon Johndroe said the U.S. president would not be deterred.

President Bush will travel to the region to stand with the mainstream governments. The selfproclaimed American jihadist, also known as Azzam the American, is on the FBIs Most Wanted List. Gadahn was indicted in 2006 on charges of treason and offering material support for terrorism. He is the first American charged with treason since World War II.

Since October 2004 he has appeared in at least eight al Qaeda videos in which he speaks in English and praises the terrorist network. Theodore Sorensen helped write John F. Kennedys 1960 speech on Catholicism. He helped draft a speech addressing the separation between church and state.

Sorensen: Did Kennedys 1960 speech win him the presidency? He obviously didnt lose it, nor did he free the country from the curse of antiCatholicism. The hate mail still poured into his office. The vicious picket signs were still seen out on the campaign trail, and, indeed, on Election Day.

More people voted against Kennedy because of his religion than any other reason. Watch Sorensen discuss why Kennedy gave his speech . Could President Kennedy have delivered the speech Romney gave on Thursday? Mr. Romneys position on many of the issues are very different than JFKs.

JFK believed that no one needed to worry about a Catholic bishop or a cardinal dictating to him as a president. Romney felt compelled for some reason to define his personal views of Jesus Christ. Romney emphasized the role of religion in public life more strongly than JFK did or would have.

Kennedy said, as you noted, his personal views of religion were totally his business and not the business of the American people. Romney made the statement freedom requires religion just as religion requires freedom. Do you think Kennedy would have agreed with that?
As an old speechwriter, I would congratulate Mr. Romney. I think he touched all the bases he wanted to touch. Why did Kennedy avoid discussing his religious views?

Sorensen: I dont think Mr. Romney should be denied the presidency because of his religion. Kennedy began the speech by saying his private religious beliefs  his relationship with God or Jesus Christ or anything else was not a matter of public discussion. He did not think the election should be based on  as he said, its not what kind of church I believe in.

Just as I dont think Senator Barack Obama should be denied because of his race. Or that Mrs. Hillary Clintonshould be denied the presidency because of her gender. This country is in deep, serious trouble, and thoughtful citizens surely are going to make up their minds based on the major issues confronting the country.

The Boeing 777 first entered service on June 7, 1995. The aircraft seats between 301 and 368 passengers in a threeclass configuration. Since its inaugural flight, Boeing has extended the 777 family to five commercial passenger models. On November 9 and 10, 2005, a Boeing 777200LR Worldliner set a new world record for distance traveled nonstop by a commercial jetliner.

The 777200LR set a record distance of 21,601 km on a route traveling eastbound from Hong Kong to London Heathrow. The flight lasted 22 hours and 42 minutes. The achievements was recognized by the U.S. National Aeronautics Association and the Guinness Book of Records. The Federation eéronautique Internationale recognized the Boeing 777 in April 1997 for achieving a speed and distance record.

Boeing prides itself on the 777s landing gear, which it claims is the largest ever incorporated into a commercial aircraft. Each main landing gear is fitted with six wheels, while the nose gear has two. Donors pledge 7.4 billion to help build a Palestinian state.

Palestinian Prime Minister Salam Fayyad called the pledge of money a vote of confidence in the Palestinians. Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair said the support of donors needed to be repaid in the coming months with steps to create a lasting settlement. The Paris conference focuses on shortterm priorities for the Palestinians, and French President Nicolas Sarkozy said those include providing immediate support for the Palestinian people. The International Monetary Fund said it would provide monitoring of the Palestinians promised reforms.

French President Nicolas Sarkozy said France would donate 300 million, and the United States was expected to pledge more than 500 million. Central to the Palestinians request for aid is a threeyear reform plan that the Palestinians prepared for the conference. The plan, which covers 2008 to 2010, centers on economic development and government reform.

The World Bank praised the plan, calling it a promising effort to link policymaking, planning and budgeting. But in a report released Monday, the World Bank pointed out the reforms would succeed in helping Palestinians only if they were accompanied by both donor aid and Israeli actions. Israeli Foreign Minister Tzipi Livni spoke of taking such actions.

Sarkozy repeatedly told the conference he is a friend of Israel. He urged the Israeli government to withdraw troops from the West Bank. The World Banks report detailed the challenges facing attempts to revive the Palestinian economy, which has become almost totally dependent on foreign aid. Abbas earlier had requested 5.6 billion in aid over the next three years.

The Palestinian Authority is the largest employer for its people, as privatesector jobs dry up. The World Bank said wages for public sector employees account for almost half of the governments expenditures. Almost all government funds in the past two years have been used to pay salaries and cover operating costs. Staffing also has gone up in the health and education sectors.

Gaza has been subject to a wideranging crackdown since Hamas took power in June its borders are closed, fuel imports are restricted, and there are strict limits on all imported goods. The continued entry of humanitarian goods has mitigated the impact of the closures on Gazas population, but has not been sufficient to offset the collapse of the private sector there. Unemployment across the Palestinian territories stands at nearly 23 percent, the World Bank said, but in Gaza, 33 percent of the population is out of a job.

Lantos represented his Northern California district for 14 terms. He died at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland. Lantos life was defined by courage, optimism, and unwavering dedication to his principles and to his family, said his wife, Annette, his childhood sweetheart, in a statement the House of Representatives released.

Lantos was diagnosed with esophageal cancer in December. He was serving his 14th term in the House. Rice described Lantos as the embodiment of what it meant to have ones freedom denied and then to find it and to insist that Americans stand for spreading the benefits of freedom to others.

Lantos is the only Holocaust survivor to have served in Congress. He announced last month that he would not seek a new term. "I will never be able to express fully my profoundly felt gratitude to this great country," Lantos said in a statement at the time.

The Hungarianborn Lantos came to the United States in 1947 after surviving a forcedlabor camp in his Naziallied homeland. He escaped and was sheltered in a Budapest safe house set up by Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg. He arrived in the U.S. after being awarded an academic scholarship to study.

Lantos was the latest of more than a dozen members to announce plans to leave the House. His San Franciscoarea district is solidly Democratic, and he won reelection with more than threequarters of the vote in 2006. He supported the 2002 congressional resolution that authorized President Bush to launch the invasion of Iraq but later became an outspoken critic of the conflict. All vehicles were banned from the largely Shiite city of Amara Wednesday after three car bombs ripped through a market district.

The blasts detonated in close succession in a commercial area in the central section of Amara. The city has been the scene of fighting between rival Shiite factions. Baghdad was also hit by violence on Wednesday. A car bomb there killed five Iraqi civilians and wounded 15 others.

Maj. Gen. Abdul Karim Khalaf, head of the Interior Ministrys National Command Center, confirmed the casualty figures in the Amara bombing. He said the ministry fired the citys police chief in the aftermath of the attack.

The first bomb, in a car parked in a commercial area, detonated about 930 a.m. As onlookers gathered, the second one exploded in a nearby garage. It was followed by a third bomb in the garage a few minutes after that.

Prime Minister Nuri alMaliki denounced the attack. Most of the casualties were women and children, an Iraqi TV station reported. Maysan, which borders Iran, has been under Iraqi security control much of this year. It was not immediately known who was responsible for the blasts, but the violence is a reminder of the intense fighting between the Mehdi Army, Muqtada alSadr's militia and the Badr Brigade, an SICI militia.

The two movements are bitter rivals and have been in the middle of local power struggles in Iraqs southern provinces. Britain, which has been in command of the south since the Iraqi war began, has been working to withdraw its troops from the region. Despite this latest violence, the region has always been more stable than Baghdad and other outlying regions.

Kenya has enjoyed a reputation as one of East Africas most stable nations since achieving independence from the UK in 1963. A booming tourism industry, impressive economic growth and decades of peace have served to disguise widespread poverty, violent crime and corruption. Tribal bonds remain stronger than national identity in Kenya, with the countrys 36 million people claiming allegiance to around 40 different tribes.

President Mwai Kibaki is a member of Kenyas largest Kikuyu tribe. He faces off against opposition leader Raila Odinga of the Luo tribe. The Kikuyus make up about 22 percent of the country's population. Jomo Kenyatta, president from 1964 until 1978, was a KikuyU. He was succeeded by Daniel Arap Moi of the Kalenjin tribe.

The Luo make up around 13 percent of the population, mostly in the west of the country. But they also form a sizeable community in some of Nairobis most notorious slums, such as the vast Kibera shantytown. This weeks violence came as election officials declared victory for Kibaki with 51.3 percent to 48.7 percent for Odinga in the closest presidential vote in Kenyan electoral history.

Kibakis first election success in 2002 was hailed at the time as a step forward for Kenyan democracy. However, his term has been dogged by allegations of corruption and graft. Irshad Manji is a controversial Muslim feminist and activist from Toronto, Canada. She is the author of the book, "The Death of Benazir Bhuttos"

While far more liberal and democratic than Gen. Musharraf, Bhutto disappointed moderate, modern Pakistanis with her adherence to feudal politics. American feminists say they are aching over the loss of our dear, sweet, brave Benazir. But brave is not the word used by Pakistani women from whom Ive also heard.

During Bhutto's time in office, Pakistan didnt defy the antifemale rape and adultery laws. Those notorious ordinances, known as Hudood, took their inspiration from tribal politics masquerading as Islam. Imagine the opportunity Bhuttos could have championed a purer faith by tackling corrupt cultural practices.

In so doing, she might have created allies among conservatives, who can be persuaded that although Islam is Godgiven, culture is manmade. But not because of her. And that, say many progressive Pakistanis, amputates Bhuttos legacy.

An exceptional leader can tap into it. There was a time when Pakistans democratic politicians stuck it to the feudal fanatics. Bhuttos father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was once heckled by a religious fundamentalist. His response captured the spirit of Muhammad Ali Jinnah.

In 1947, Jinnah exuded high hopes for his people. You are free to go to your temples, he said. You may belong to any religion or caste or creed. That has nothing to do with the business of the state. You will find that in due course of time, Hindus will cease to be Hindus.

Jinnah meant every word of his unconventional vision because he, himself, lived as a maverick. He adored his nonMuslim wife, and his sister often appeared with him on the campaign trail. Her visibility attested to Islams embrace of women as partners of men.

The United States lapsed into divisiveness following the assassinations of Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy. Many would argue that todays politics of polarization can be traced to the unresolved trauma of the KingKennedy murders. For Pakistan, its high time to transcend both trauma and tribalism.

Saudi King Abdullah has pardoned a rape victim who had been sentenced to 200 lashes and six months in prison. The case cast light on the treatment of women under Saudi Arabias strict Islamic law. King Abdullah issued a royal pardon Monday, the same day that the Hajj, the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca, begins in Saudi Arabia.

The victims husband said he has not received an official letter regarding her pardon. He thanked King Abdullah for the pardon, saying This fatherly care and noble gesture will help in lifting the emotional and psychological stress and suffering that our family has been enduring. Saudi sources told CNN that the kings pardon was not related to the beginning of the Hajj nor the Eid alAdha festival that follows.

Saudi court ruled the 19yearold had an illegitimate relationship with a man who was not her husband. The rape took place in Qatif in March 2006 when the woman was engaged to be married. The White House welcomed King Abdullahs decision, but stressed that this is obviously a matter for the Saudi Arabians and King Abdullah. The decision did not reflect any lack of confidence in the Saudi justice system.

The case has drawn international attention, provoked outrage in the West. The woman was meeting with a man described as a former friend when they were abducted. Seven men, convicted of abducting the pair and raping her, were sentenced from two to nine years in prison. Abdul Rahman alLahim, the lawyer who represented the woman, faced a disciplinary hearing for insulting the Supreme Judicial Council. The hearing has been postponed.

The womans husband has been outspoken in his support for his wife. He called a Lebanese TV show to defend her, when a former Saudi judge claimed on the program that she spoiled their marital bed. AlLahim has said he hopes the case changes the Saudi justice system.

U.S. President George W. Bush said last week that King Abdullah knows our position loud and clear on the case. Under Saudi law, women are subject to numerous restrictions, including a strict dress code. Claims by Dianas former butler that he knew a mysterious secret about the late princess have been trashed by the coroner in her inquest.

Paul Burrell was once described by the princess as her rock. On Monday he told the inquest the letter contained a secret, which he claimed he could not remember. Burrell said the letter was not there, but at his home in Florida. The coroner said the information was already in the public domain and some of it was even mentioned in one of Burrells own books.

Burrell handed the coroner a note that he said contained the supposed secret. The coroner revealed that what Burrell referred to was that Diana was planning to buy property to live in part of the time. The location may have been in the United States or South Africa. The questioning of the former butler is expected to continue Wednesday.

Diana and Dodi Fayed died in a Paris tunnel in the early hours of August 31, 1997. They had driven away from the Ritz Hotel in a black Mercedes with paparazzi chasing behind. There has been speculation that the couple had planned a big announcement the night they died.

Maggie Rae said the claims came at a meeting with her legal team at Kensington Palace in which the princess also made clear her belief that the succession of the English crown should skip a generation to her son, William. The mornings evidence also heard that Britains top police officer had advised the queen against allowing Diana to go on holiday with Mohamed al Fayed, the father of Dodi.

Rae gave an insight into the princesss lifestyle, which she described as odd and lonely. It was during this holiday on the tycoons luxury yacht in the French resort of St. Tropez that she met Dodi Fayed. Diana defied the advice and went on the trip despite being told it was unwise.
She said she did not believe Dianas claims of a conspiracy against her. She had heated her own food in the microwave, Rae told the court. I thought she lived in a very odd environment, she said.

Paul Burrell, Princess Diana's former butler, gives evidence at inquest. Burrell was the first star witness of the London inquest, now in its fourth month. Diana once referred to Burrell as her "rock," he tells inquest. Diana died in a Paris car crash on August 31, 1997, along with her boyfriend Dodi Fayed.

Burrell, whom the late princess once called my rock, cast doubt on whether Diana was ready to marry Fayed. According to Burrell, the princess was still holding a candle for former boyfriend and heart surgeon Hasnat Khan. Burrell told the inquest that Diana asked him to listen in on a conversation in June 1997 with her mother, Frances Shand Kydd, who died in 2004.

The inquest, which began in October and is expected to last another two or three months, aims to uncover the facts surrounding the deaths of the Princess and Dodi. Asked earlier in the day if he believed that Fayed was the one, Burrell said no, I did not have that impression. He also cast doubt on claims they were engaged or on the cusp of engagement.

Dianas 18month relationship with Khan ended around the same time she started seeing Fayed in July 1997. Burrell said Diana had asked him at one point to investigate how a private wedding with Khan might take place, given that Khan is Muslim.

Burrell said he suggested to the princess that she wear it on the fourth finger of her right hand, rather than the left. Burrell also indicated that the ring was not an engagement ring, as the Fayed family has maintained. Last month at the inquest Lady Annabel Goldsmith, a friend of Diana, said the princess had remarked that she needed another marriage like a rash on my face.

Lawyers at the inquest asked Burrell whether he knew whether a special announcement had been planned for the Monday following the fatal car crash. There has been speculation the couple planned to announce special news, such as an engagement. But Burrell said he knew nothing of such a plan.

Mohamed Al Fayed, father of Dodi and the owner of Harrods has long claimed that senior members of the royal family ordered the pair be murdered. He also claims that Diana was pregnant at the time of her death. But Burrell said that he knew Prince Philip very well and that he could not have been behind the deaths.

Some witnesses claimed that he wrote cruel and hurtful letters to Diana. But other correspondence shown to the jury appeared to be friendly and was affectionately signed. Prince Philip could sometimes come across as terse because he says what he thinks.

Burrell worked for the British royals for 21 years and became close to Diana. He has written two books about his time with the princess. In his second book, Burrell told of a letter from Diana which indicated she feared for her life.

The princess wrote that Prince Charles planned an accident in my car, brake failure and serious head injury. One of Dianas close friends, however, testified last month that she believed the letter could have been forged. Lucia Flecha de Lima said Burrell was capable of imitating the princesss handwriting.

Burrell responded that Diana always referred to Charles that way, even after the divorce. The inquest has revealed that Diana was a prolific letterwriter who also received a lot of correspondence. Witnesses, including Burrell, recall that the princess kept the letters in her desk, with the more important ones stored in a special box.

Queen Elizabeth told Burrell there are powers at work in this country about which we have no knowledge. That comment, which has been widely reported, was meant to warn him to be careful, Burrell said. At the same meeting Burrell also told the queen that he had taken some of Dianas belongings to keep safe.

President Bush chatted by phone with Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Two senior Iraq national government figures met with the head of the countrys Kurdish region. Turkish warplanes pounded Kurdish separatist targets in northern Iraq on Saturday and Sunday as well as last week. Bush and Erdogan talked about the dangers of the Kurdish separatist rebels along the TurkishIraqi border.

National Security Council spokesman Gordon Johndroe said they discussed their common efforts to fight terrorism. The PKK has spent two decades fighting for autonomy for Kurds in southeastern Turkey. Some of its attacks have been launched from inside northern Iraq. The U.S. and European Union consider the group a terrorist organization.

Iraqi President Jalal Talabani and Vice President Tariq alHashimi met with Kurdish Regional Government President Massoud Barzani. Iraqi Kurdish officials, while critical of the PKK, have denounced the Turkish bombing campaign. Last week, BarZani snubbed visiting U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice in protest.

Several people were either killed or wounded, Barzani said on Monday at a press conference with the others. They signed a memorandum of understanding to deepen relations further with their three parties Talabanis Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, Barzanis Kurdistan Democratic Party and alHashimis Iraqi Islamic Party. The three Iraqi officials also dealt with national unity.

Andy Roddick beats Kei Nishikori of Japan in straight sets in San Jose. American number one needed just 63 minutes to defeat the 18-year-old Japanese. Nishikoris won his first ATP title on Sunday and was on an eightmatch winning run. The American has won twice in the San Jose tournament in the last two years. Click here for more tennis news.

Roddick barked at the young player as they exchanged shots at the net. Nishikori held his cool, did not respond, and just walked away. But when pressed he acknowledged that he did in fact understand what Roddick had shouted at him.
I told him to stick me with it the next time. I just let him know that he needs to finish it. I had no problem with it. But it was a monologue.

But as Nishikori served at 45 to stay in the tournament he made two crucial errors. He missed an easy slam shot that would have given him the advantage at deuce. Then saw his saw his volley go wide that gave Roddick the match.

Second seed James Blake beats Jesse Levine 64 64 to reach quarterfinals. John Isner beats third seed Tommy Haas 46 76 63 to advance to the last eight. Isner will face Robby Ginepri in the quarterfinals in Delray Beach, Florida. The final was won by Kei Nishikori, who beat Blake in straight sets.

Isner, the ATP Tours secondtallest player at sixfootnine, will next face Spains Guillermo GarciaLopez. Fifthseeded Mardy Fish also advanced, beating Germanys Denis Gremelmayr 67 63 63 to make the quarterfinals for the second week in a row. Taiwans Lu Yenhsun beat American lucky loser Wayne Odesnik 64 64.

Lu will face fourthseeded Czech Radek Stepanek in the quarterfinals. Several Marines who were involved in the November 2004 offensive in Falluja, Iraq, are now the focus of an investigation into allegations that civilians were intentionally killed during the operation.

No one has been charged in the probe, which is based on what one official told CNN were credible allegations. The allegations first surfaced on a Web site, defendourmarines.com. The Web posting includes an account from a Marine who alleges eight captured Iraqis were gunned down following a firefight.

The weeklong antiinsurgent offensive in Falluja began on November 7, 2004. It sparked intense fighting involving airstrikes and housetohouse searches. There were reports of civilians being killed in the crossfire.

One Marine will serve eight years in a plea deal. Another Marine withdrew his guilty plea, saying he acted under orders. Four officers are accused of failing to investigate and report the deaths properly. Haditha was a target of Marine operations to root out insurgents.

At least 10 people have died and thousands have been left homeless in Ecuador. Authorities said the rains, which began a week ago, were the worst in a quarter century. Los Ríos north of Guayaquil was the hardest hit of nine provinces. More than 10,000 families have been affected.

In Los Ríos province, five people died when an ambulance drove into a hole at the side of a street. A newborn boy, his parents, a doctor and a driver were killed. Streets also were flooded in the capital of Quito.

Correa increased by 25 million the 10 million he already had allocated for the emergency efforts. He also directed another 88 million to municipalities. Once the crisis has eased, an emergency fund will give seed and fertilizer to help farmers whose fields were washed away.

Italian tennis players Potito Starace and Daniele Bracciali have been banned by the ATP for betting on matches. Top Italian player Starace has been suspended for six weeks from January 1 and fined 30,000 20,890 euros for making five bets totalling around 90 euros two years ago. The world ranked 258, has been banned for three months and fined 20,000 13,930 euros.

The Italian Tennis Federation FIT confirmed the news on its website, www.federtennis.it. They denounced the penalties as disproportionate, saying the players never bet on their own matches. The federation said the two were not aware of the ATPs betting regulations.

Starace and Bracciali said they were scapegoats for a larger matchfixing scandal. Alessio Di Mauro became the first player sanctioned under the ATPs new anticorruption rules when he received a ninemonth ban in November.

An online betting company reported unusual betting patterns during a match between fourthranked Nikolay Davydenko of Russia and Martin Vassallo Arguello of Argentina. The company, Betfair, voided all bets and the ATP has been investigating.

Trevor Rees, formerly known as Trevor ReesJones, was the frontseat passenger in the Mercedes that carried Diana, her boyfriend, Dodi Fayed, and their driver, Henri Paul. He sustained serious injuries in the August 31, 1997 crash. Rees testified that he received anonymous phone calls and letters after the accident, threatening him to keep quiet.

He said the caller told him to keep quiet, saying, We know who you are. Rees said he didnt take the calls or letters seriously. A lawyer also asked Rees about a supposed encounter with a woman in which he told her, If I remember, theyre going to kill me.

Rees suffered major injuries to his lower jaw, the base of his brain, and his pulmonary system. He testified that he did not support the allegations by Dodi Fayeds father, Mohamed al Fayed, that British security services were behind the crash. He denied the security services paid him to change his story. At the time of the crash, Rees was working for al Fayeds security team and was assigned to guard Dodi Fayed.

He was also protecting the princess because she was Fayeds companion on the trip. He no longer works on al Fayeds security team. Rees has said what was once a good relationship with his former employer has broken down.

In 2000, Rees published a book, The Bodyguards Story Diana, the Crash, and the Sole Survivor. He said al Fayed tried unsuccessfully to stop the books publication in England. Rees testified that he had two flashbacks in the months after the crash, but his psychiatrist told him they were false memories.

In the first, Rees said, he recalled hearing the voice of a woman  apparently Diana calling out, Dodi from the back seat of the car. In the second flashback, he said he recalled seeing a paparazzi motorbike. Lawyer Ian Burnett then read from a letter written by Al Fayed to Lord Stevens.

Rees testified that he was not lying about his memory loss. He said claims the couple visited a jewelers in Monte Carlo to buy an engagement ring were untrue. British authorities hold an inquest whenever someone dies in suspicious circumstances. A judge, who is also called a coroner, holds hearings to determine how the person died.

The inquest does not involve driver Henri Paul because his body remained in France. British authorities had to wait to begin the inquest until after French authorities concluded their investigation. The British police inquiry took almost three years and concluded in December 2006.

Frederick Dominguez and his three children fashioned a Help sign out of twigs on a nearby unpaved road. The four sought shelter from the heavy snow in a culvert and removed their sodden socks in an effort to stay warm and dry. Frederick said that during the threeday ordeal, he and his children slept inside a log for warmth and ripped apart their shirts to wrap their wet, freezing feet.

Christopher Dominguez and his three children were reported missing Monday night. The children's mother reported them missing, police say. Dominguz: "You just go to survival mode. Every parent would do that. You would do anything, sacrifice yourself"

Dominguez said he used branches and sticks to spell out the word Help near the culvert. He said his daughter was the first to hear a California Highway Patrol helicopter overhead. He ran though several feet of snow barefooted to wave it down. The three slept with their feet inside each others shirts to help stave off frostbite.

More than 80 searchers scoured the woods Wednesday until the four were found. Police vehicles equipped with snow chains rumbled up mountain roads to help conduct the search. Officer Steve Ward said he was piloting the helicopter out ahead of bad weather when he spotted Dominguez coming out of the culvert and waving.

The family was found north of where ground crews were searching. The pilots could see the Help sign they had made with twigs on a nearby road. The family got lost Sunday searching for a tree, which they had chopped down but later abandoned. The little girl was in tears.
He said they didnt have food, heavy coats or other provisions to help prepare for the cold nights. After the family failed to locate their vehicle, he said, snow and darkness began to fall.

At that point, Lexi Dominguez said, I started freaking out. I just remember walking and walking and being like, were not going to make it, she said. And as they huddled for warmth, his sister sang songs to help pass the time until help arrived.

I feel good, just happy to be home, said Joshua Dominguez. All four appeared to be in good condition as they were brought by chopper to the command post. The two younger children had some frostbite on their toes and a touch of hypothermia.

The search riveted those in Paradise and beyond. Mayor Alan White, whose son played soccer on the same team as Joshua last year, said he and many others have cut Christmas trees in the same place where the family vanished. When winter weather sours there, he said, people in the woods can get lost quickly.

The inaccessible area is beyond the reach of cell phones, authorities have said. Paradise High principal Mike Lerch said students had volunteered to help in the search. Christopher Dominguez had graduated from the school a few months ago.

No Country for Old Men wins best picture at the 80th Academy Awards. Four acting awards go to Europeans Marion Cotillard, Daniel DayLewis, Javier Bardem and Tilda Swinton. Coens also win best director and best adapted screenplay, and Bardem wins best supporting actor. No Country is about a man pursued by death and the law across the bleak moonscapes of West Texas.

Producer Scott Rudin shared the best picture award with the brothers. Juno was the only best picture nominee to top 100 million at the box office. Star Ellen Page received plaudits for her performance as the title character. Screenwriter Diablo Cody is famously a former stripper  has become one of Hollywood's it scribes.

The best animated feature went to Ratatouille, a computeranimated Pixar film directed and written by Oscar winner Brad Bird The Incredibles. The Counterfeiters from Austria took the best foreignlanguage film. The movie is based on a true story about a counterfeiter who, after being sent to a concentration camp, was employed by the Nazis.

It beat out three songs from Enchanted, the Disney film about an animated princess come to life. No Country picked up four, The Bourne Ultimatum earned three one for its rapidfire editing. There Will Be Blood received two DayLewis acting award and Robert Elswits cinematography honor.

An American Airlines passenger complaining that she was having trouble breathing died on a flight last week. MedAire, Inc. said its physicians last year advised 74 airlines on how to handle more than 17,000 inflight medical events. The death underscores the importance of taking precautions before flying, a travel health industry representative said Monday.

Flight attendants with sick passengers call Good Samaritan Hospital in Phoenix, Arizona. Emergency room physicians and a service able to translate 140 languages are on call to answer questions. Very rarely does the call result in a diversion, a decision made not by the doctor but by the pilot who must consider a number of variables beyond the passengers health.

On average, the company gets about 50 inflight calls from commercial airliners for an entire day. Airlines contracting with MedAire include Continental, Southwest and British Airways. The top categories of inflight illness are fainting, gastrointestinal problems, respiratory issues and heart problems. American has its own inhouse medical team.

By law, U.S. commercial airlines must carry automatic external defibrillators, oxygen and medical kits. Some airlines choose to carry extra, nonmandated medications. If a passenger already has breathing problems, airplane travel will only worsen the condition.

Though flight attendants are trained to handle onboard emergencies, they are not medically trained, she said. Hydration and moderation are key, and passengers should carry water and a snack. Altitude amplifies the buzz, Drake said.

The FAA began demanding that airlines carry certain medications more than 30 years ago. A fresh cast can also prove dangerous. The risk is reduced with older casts, which have typically already expanded to accommodate any swelling, the FAA says. The FAA says the list was tiny.

During the 1990s, overseas airlines began carrying more sophisticated equipment, and pressure increased for U.S. airlines to follow. Congress held hearings and then required airlines carry more robust kits and defibrillators by 2004. American Airlines was among the first to do so, said Dr. David McKenas, who served for 10 years as the airlines corporate medical director until 2002.

American Airlines buys its kits from Banyan International Corp., which describes itself as the nations leading provider of emergency medical kits. Each of the ninepound, 250 kits includes aspirin, alcohol swabs, nitroglycerine tablets, antihistamines, IV tubing, a stethoscope, a bloodpressure gauge, a bronchodilator, syringes, gloves, saline solution.

It could be used if there is a medical emergency on board, but thats not its purpose, he said. More oxygen is stored in the cockpit for the pilots. There is no central repository where these things can be archived and then retrieved.

The bill  raises automotive fuel economy standards for the first time in more than three decades. It also boosts federal support for alternative fuel research and energy conservation efforts. President Bush stresses the role of faithbased groups in the fight against AIDS. He calls the struggle one of conscience and morals on the eve of World AIDS Day.

Bush is asking Congress for an additional 15 billion to continue and expand the Presidents Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief. The White House says the program has treated more than 1.3 million people with AIDS. Increased funding would boost that number to 2.5 million, it says. The program has been criticized for requiring that participating groups emphasize abstinence education.

At the White House, about 40 people carried signs in support of more AIDS funding. Among others, the president met with Martha Chilufya, founder of the Mututa Memorial Center in Zambia. The center works with faithbased and other caregivers to serve more than 150 patients.

Bush says the first lady will join him on his trip next year. A giant red ribbon is hung from the north portico of the White House to represent the continued battle against HIVAIDS. A 12yearold boy should get a say in whether he gets circumcised, the Oregon Supreme Court has ruled.

M is the child at the center of a longrunning custody dispute between James and Lia Boldt, who divorced in 1999. Soon after, the father began studying Judaism and later converted. He also started teaching his son about the faith. By then, James had parental custody and told his exwife the boy would convert as well.

Because the two sides disagreed, and were living in neighboring states, the conflict dissolved into ongoing personal and constitutional dispute. Lia Boldt countered her son does not want to go through with the circumcision.

So rather than offer a definitive ruling, the justices order both sides to go to the actual source of the conflict. Forcing M at age 12 to undergo circumcision against his will could seriously affect the relationship between M and his father, they say. There was no initial reaction to the decision from the parents or their attorneys. The case is James Boldt v. Lia Boldt S054714.  A man who rescued a coworker from the jaws of a crocodile also accidentally shot him.

Two men were collecting crocodile eggs by a river bank in Australias Northern Territory. A crocodile grabbed Jason Grant by the lower right arm. Lopez, White and Champagne were arrested Thursday at a storage facility in Sandy Springs, Georgia, a suburb just north of Atlanta. Spivey was apprehended at Camp Frank D. Merrill, an Army Ranger training center in Dahlonega, Georgia. ATF agents had set up a sting operation at the facility, which is about 60 miles from Atlanta. Armenian President Robert Kocharian declared a state of emergency Saturday night after a day of clashes between police and protesters. Protesters claim last months presidential election was rigged. State of emergency will hopefully bring some order to the capital, Yerevan, says Salpi Ghazarian, assistant to the Armenian foreign minister.

Clashes began when authorities used force to clear Freedom Square of thousands of demonstrators. Authorities moved in because they thought that there were arms there, and it turned out that they were right. The state of emergency could last until March 20, she said, but the government hopes that it will be lifted sooner.

As of early Sunday morning, Freedom Square was empty, Ghazarian said. Protesters were demonstrating in a main square elsewhere in the city. After the president was forced to declare a state of emergency, things have quieted down, she said.

An Armenian woman interviewed by CNN said there was huge chaos when police moved in. She did not elaborate on the number of people injured or the extent of their injuries. Witnesses told CNN that Saturday mornings action by Armenian riot police was bloody.

They just want their freedom. They just want to be heard. They are being beaten up, some people have horrible wounds. As night fell Saturday, the sounds of gunfire could be heard from the direction of the protesters.

The U.S. Embassy has warned the several hundred Americans living in Yerevan to stay at home. Opposition vowed to pursue its claims through legal means. Armenia, population 3 million, is a former Soviet republic east of Turkey, south of Georgia and north of Iran. Nearly 3 million gallons of sewage spilled into San Francisco Bay when a pump failed at a waste treatment facility.

The 2.7 milliongallon spill occurred Thursday night. A pump failed at the South Marin Sanitation Districts waste treatment facility. The waste was released into Richardson Bay, an inlet of the large bay.

Sewage and storm water was partially treated. An alarm that would have alerted workers at the facility to the spill also failed. The state notified local offices in the bay area within an hour of receiving the report, an official says. The accidental release occurred between 530 and 830 p.m. Thursday.

The California Department of Fish and Game has had a boat and personnel on the water since early Friday. The agency has found no sign of sick or distressed wildlife resulting from the spill, a spokesman says. Marin County is just across the Golden Gate Bridge from San Francisco.

Sixtytwo members of Gambino, Genovese and Bonanno families face 80 charges. Charges range from money laundering to illegal gambling and murder. The Gambino family profited from extortion within the New York construction industry and its labor unions, according to the charges. In 1992, John Jackie the Nose DAmico, shown in 1992, is one of 62 people indicted.

Forty-five of those charged are already in custody. Arrests were made in New York City, Long Island, New York and New Jersey. In addition to the arrests in the New York area, police in Italy detained 77 people in connection with organized crime.

Saddam Hussein let the world think he had weapons of mass destruction to intimidate Iran and prevent the country from attacking Iraq. Hispanics are described as the largest minority group in the United States. Yet these descriptions belie the complexity of the 44 million people to whom they refer. Even the terms used to name them  Hispanics, HispanicAmericans, Latinos, LatinoAmericans, the Spanishsurnamed too tightly package the people categorized by those definitions, some observers say.

Many of his films, such as Los Angeles Now and Brown is the New Green George Lopez and the American Dream, explore the experience and identity of Latinos in the United States. From a census standpoint, being of Hispanic or Latino origin means a person identifies himself in one of four listed categories. According to a Pew Hispanic CenterKaiser Family Foundation survey in 2002, that is how most Latinos choose to identify themselves.

When asked which terms they would use first to describe themselves, 54 percent said they primarily identify themselves in terms of their or their parents country of origin. About one quarter choose Latino or Hispanic, and 21 percent chose American. The U.S. government came up with the term Hispanic in the 1970s to generally refer to people who could trace their origin to Spanishspeaking countries.

The terms are often used interchangeably, which is a point of some contention in the wider community. But do the terms carry meaning among the people to whom they refer, or are they merely governmental designations? Thats the way you call our people, Susana Clar, 52, said of the terms.

Manuel Baez, 49, is a native of the Dominican Republic who owns an insurance agency in Tampa, Florida. He never uses Hispanic to identify himself because I am mixed, Baez said. He continued, DominicanAmerican really represents who I am, instead of Dominican or Latino.

Hispanic doesnt go with me because I dont believe that Spain was the best thing for Latin America. For me...there is no such thing as a Latino identity, said Suzanne Oboler, professor of Puerto Rican and Latino studies. Theres certainly a cultural understanding... And a political identity, she said.

Carl J. Kravetz, a longtime veteran of Hispanic marketing, said similarities among the different subsets of Latinos do show a Latino identity. The Association of Hispanic Advertising Agencies embarked on a Latino cultural identity project last year to better understand a group of consumers they felt could not be adequately reached through the traditional Spanishlanguage market.

There are definite cultural ties among Latinos, particularly between those born in the United States. Religion and spirituality have a strong influence on Latino life and perception of the world. Latinos tend to emphasize family individuality is not as important, and perceptions of time and space they have longer time horizons and have a relaxed sense of privacy, a group of advertising and media companies says. It is drawn along parallels in values and ways of thinking and regardless of country of origin, the group tends to cluster in a few areas.

Chitel: Latinos should be reached with culturally nuanced media. Still, some chafe at the labels. "Every time it comes up it just kind of annoys me and makes me mad," one woman says of her background. "It creates very much an identity that is Latino," Chitel says.

The U.S. Navy has moved the guidedmissile destroyer USS Cole and other ships to the eastern Mediterranean Sea off Lebanon. Pentagon officials said Thursday that the move was in response to a threat from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria.

The deployment comes amid a political standoff over Lebanons presidency, but the Navy would not say whether the events are linked. Parts of Cuyahoga county open an extra hour. Clinton held a twotoone advantage over Obama with Hispanic voters. Obama had the overwhelming advantage with black voters in the states Democratic primary. See countybycounty results in Ohio.

Former President Bill Clinton said in February that if his wife won Ohio and Texas, shed go on to win the nomination. The top three Democratic presidential candidates face off in a Monday night debate in South Carolina. The hearts and minds of AfricanAmerican voters on the line.

The debate comes five days before the Democratic primary in South Carolina. Hillary Clinton of New York and Barack Obama of Illinois and former Sen. John Edwards of North Carolina share the stage. The debate was put together by CNN and the Congressional Black Caucus Institute.

A CNNOpinion Research Corp. poll released Friday suggested that nearly 60 percent of black registered Democrats were backing Obama. Both Democratic frontrunners were reaching out to AfricanAmerican voters Sunday. Obama, who often refers to King in his speeches, spoke at Atlanta, Georgias Ebenezer Baptist Church. Obama challenged the audience at the historic black church to take a look at a few lingering prejudices.

The Atlanta JournalConstitution endorsed Barack Obama for president Sunday. The paper cited his appeal across many of the lines that have divided America. Hillary Clinton also visited a historic black church in New York on Sunday. She picked up the endorsement of its pastor, the Rev. The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Clinton is running against Georgia Gov. Nathan Deal for the Democratic presidential nomination.

Butts: A vote for Hillary Clinton is a vote to elect someone who has proven through time to me and to this community and this country that she has the experience to make things happen. Clinton: I have the highest regard and admiration for my friend and colleague Sen. Barack Obama.

Edwards says he hopes what happens in Vegas stays in Vegas. Edwards would like to rebound in South Carolina, his native state. He won the primary there in 2004 when he was making his first bid for the White House. But he is running a distant third in most recent surveys in the state.

Pervez Musharraf says Benazir Bhutto's assassination was her own fault. Bhut to was killed December 27 in Rawalpindi, south of the Pakistani capital Islamabad. Bhutto's head was above the roof and unprotected at the time of the attack. The cause of her death is not clear a bomber blew himself up near Bhuttos limousine. Musharraf, who seized power in a bloodless coup in 1999, rejected criticism that his government did not do enough to provide security.

Riley Ann Sawyers was moved from Ohio to Texas by her mother. Prosecutors said they have not decided whether to seek the death penalty against the girls mother, Kimberly Dawn Trenor, and Trenors husband, Royce Clyde Zeigler II. Rileys body was found October 29 by a fisherman on an uninhabited island in the bay.

Police sketches of the child were widely distributed, and police dubbed her Baby Grace. DNA testing confirmed the childs identity. Trenor, 19, and Zeigler, 24, were initially charged with injury to a child and tampering with evidence. But since the initial charges were filed last month the investigation has continued and police have gathered additional evidence.

The grand jury deliberated for only three minutes Wednesday before upgrading the charges. Trenor told police Riley had been beaten and thrown across a room and that her head was held under water before she died. She said the couple hid the girls body in a storage shed for one to two months before dumping it into the bay.

A medical examiner said Rileys skull was fractured in three places that would have been fatal injuries. Trenor and the girl moved to Texas from Ohio in May to be with Zeigler. Abdul Rahman alLahem says the Justice Ministry has reinstated his license. AlLahem had previously told CNN that the judge revoked his license as punishment for speaking to the media about his clients case. His client, an engaged teenager, was raped by seven men who found her alone with a man unrelated to her.

The seven rapists were sentenced to two to nine years in prison but she also was sentenced to 200 lashes and six months in prison. The womans sentence provoked outrage in the West and cast light on the treatment of women under Saudi Arabian law. Under Saudi law, women are subject to numerous restrictions, including a strict dress code, a prohibition against driving and a requirement that they get a mans permission to travel or have surgery.

The punishment of the lawyer or any lawyer does not come from a reaction it comes from a carefully examined procedure within a special council in the ministry. He said the council charged with deciding law license revocations had not issued any decisions in the case. CNN is taking an indepth look at contemporary Russia as part of the Eye on Russia series.

Anna Glubokina, 27, jumped at the opportunity to send photos of her country. "I think that Russia is like a mountain river fast, dangerous and beautiful," she said. Murray Gillis took this image of an ice sculpture during a trip to Gubkinsky, Russia.

But I love Russia very much. I will never be bored here. I know that tourists like Russia, because of its astonishing churches and palaces. Many of those who sent us photos were originally from other countries.

Arturo Fortun, originally from Bolivia, has lived in Russia for six years. He said he has very vivid memories of what it was like seeing the country on TV as a child. Fortun: I guess its sort of a defining element of who I am is growing up during the Reagan presidency and seeing the end of the Cold War on TV.

Volker Kleensang, of Hamburg, Germany, frequently visits Kaliningrad, Russia. He said the Russian people will take time to become accustomed to democracy. Life is different there, but after a time, your impressions may change.

Many people from Kaliningrad still use the old German name. Craig Dillon of Queenstown, New Zealand, visited the country after winning a contest through a New Zealand vodka company. He said he had a choice of taking an 8,000 prize or a trip to Moscow, and out of curiosity, he took the latter.

FBI and Department of Homeland Security issue a bulletin citing an alleged claim of responsibility by al Qaeda for former Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhuttos assassination.
