Al Qaeda Afghanistan commander and spokesman Mustafa Abu AlYazid telephoned the agency to make the claim. According to AKI, al Qaeda No.2 Ayman alZawahiri began planning Bhuttos killing in October. Such a claim has not appeared on radical Islamist Web sites that regularly post such messages from al Qaeda.

The claim was an unconfirmed open source claim of responsibility. The bulletin was sent out at about 6 p.m. to state and local law enforcement agencies. One Islamist Web site repeated the claim, but that Web site is not considered a reliable source for Islamist messages by experts in the field.

We are not in a position to confirm who may be responsible, Feinstein said. DHS spokesman Russ Knocke said Bhuttos assassination had not prompted any adjustments to our security posture. Of course, we continue to closely monitor events as they unfold overseas, he said.

Democratic senators will hold short pro forma sessions over the holiday break to prevent recess appointments. Nearly all the senators left the Capitol for the Christmas holiday last week. Democrats are keeping the Senate in session to block President Bush from making any recess appointments, a constitutional mechanism that allows the president to fill top government posts for up to one year without Senate confirmation.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, DNevada, announced December 19 that he would keep the Senate open with a series of pro forma sessions through midJanuary. Talks had just broken down with the White House on a deal that would have allowed the president to make dozens of appointments if he agreed not to appoint one controversial official.

Webb also did the duty Friday, but he wont be the only senator tasked with presiding over the shortened sessions. Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts, Byron Dorgan of North Dakota, Jack Reed of Rhode Island, Mary Landrieu of Louisiana, Ben Cardin of Maryland and Chuck Schumer of New York will share the duty.

Bush: Growth package must be big enough to make a difference in an economy as large and dynamic as ours. It should equal about 1 percent of the nations gross domestic product, or roughly 140 billion, he added. Bush: It will help keep economic sectors that are going through adjustments, such as the housing market, from adversely affecting other parts of our economy.

Bush said the economy will continue to grow but at a slower rate. The president offered no specific details of the proposed package, but he did insist that it include tax incentives for business, including small businesses. Bush also said the economic package must include rapid income tax relief for consumers to lift our economy at a time when people otherwise might spend less.

We want to include people who pay taxes, not necessarily income taxes  a lot of lower income people pay payroll taxes, said one aide. Sen. Charles Schumer, DNew York, said he was disappointed that Bush did not include stimulusspending measures aimed at helping the disadvantaged such as extending unemployment benefits.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, DCalifornia, expressed agreement with Bush on the need to provide assistance immediately. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, DNevada, said, I also agree that our focus must be on finding temporary measures that will do the job effectively. Sen. Edward Kennedy, DMassachusetts, agreed that we must act swiftly to boost the economy. Bushs remarks came a day after talks on the subject with Democratic and Republican lawmakers.

Existing income tax cuts due to expire in 2010. Bush calls on Congress to make them permanent. Unless Congress acts, the American people will face massive tax increases in less than three years. This tax increase would put jobs and economic growth at risk, Bush says.

The proposed stimulus package comes as a leading gauge of future economic activity was released Friday. The December report showed a decline for a third straight month for the U.S. leading index. The report cited housing permits for the largest negative contribution to the index.

Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers stressed the importance of whom any relief package would target. Summers: It needs to go to people who are going to spend it. Bernanke told the House Budget Committee on Thursday that he does not believe the economy will enter a recession. He said he expects growth to proceed at a slow pace this year and possibly into early 2009.

He said Congress needs to take decisive action to boost the economy. But he said any package should be explicitly temporary to avoid running up the governments longterm debt. Bernanke stopped short of suggesting that the Bush tax cuts should be made permanent, telling lawmakers he supports the law of arithmetic.

In 2001, Americans received checks from the government designed to stimulate the economy. Twenty to 40 percent of the checks were spent within days. Consumers saved onethird of the money, and twothirds went back into the economy within two quarters.

Passenger ship Explorer reported problems near the South Shetland Islands, south of Argentina. The area is in a sector of Antarctica claimed by the United Kingdom. The ship sent out a distress call at around 10 p.m. local time on Wednesday.

154 people are reported to be on board ship, which carries a Liberian flag. Passengers and crew have been evacuated onto lifeboats. Captain and first officer are said to have stayed on board the ship.

The great majority of people, including all the passengers, have been safely taken off the Explorer and are now being recovered by the first of the vessels. The passengers and crew from the Explorer have not been in lifeboats very long, Dave JardineSmith, head of the Maritime and Coastguard Agencys MCA search and rescue team in England said.

She hit something and is taking on a serious amount of water, that is all we know. The temperature in the area is said to be at around minus 5C, with a sea temperature of around minus 1C. It wouldnt take long for hypothermia to set in at that kind of temperature, forecasters said. The boat is owned by Gap Adventures, based in Toronto, Canada.

Todd Barber was moved from horror to action after witnessing the rapid devastation of a Cayman Island coral reef. Barber gave up a sixfigure salary as a marketing consultant and dedicated his life to restoring the worlds ocean reef ecosystems. "When that one little tiny reef was lost, that sparked something in me," says Barber.

Coral reefs are home to 25 percent of all marine fish species. 500 million people rely on coral reefs for their food and livelihoods. According to the Nature Conservancy, 70 percent of the worlds coral reefs will be destroyed by the year 2050. If we lost one and it took that tens of thousands of years to get here, how fast is this happening?

What started as a basic idea to shape concrete around a beach ball led to three years of research, testing and prototyping with the help of friends and college professors. Our goal was to mimic nature, not dictate nature, says Barber.

Reef Balls are circular structures with a hollow center that serve as a base habitat upon which a natural reef can grow. They are used to mimic and rehabilitate all forms of oceanic reefs, such as mangrove, oyster and coral reefs. They can also help control erosion and stabilize shorelines.

Today, the nonprofit organization works with environmental agencies, universities, community groups and corporations. According to Barber, marine conservation isnt just about Reef Balls, but theyre one important tool. Its about saving natural reefs.

Since its inception, the Reef Ball Foundation has placed Reef Balls in more than 59 countries. For me, personally, the satisfaction comes from diving on a Reef Ball and seeing that the environment has been rehabilitated.

Valerie Gooding is in the top five most powerful businesswomen in Europe. Under her leadership BUPA has grown to over 8 million customers in over 190 countries. She said it goes beyond family issues. Women sometimes dont put themselves forward for things.

Women often lack confidence to go for the next job, the top job. Partly a lack of role models, partly it may be conditioning from a very early age about what the role of women is in society and the family, in work. But also I think there is still an unseen barrier for women, which is that, if you ask most business people, would they like to promote more women, they all say yes.

But often they dont really automatically think of a woman first for a top job. And what advice would you give to women who want to try and make it to the top? Gooding Well, first of all, to learn as much as you can and to make sure youve got the right experience, the right qualifications, and to enjoy each job for its own interest and job satisfaction. But I think another piece of advice I would given to women is not to be afraid to put themselves forward and say what it is they want.

Gooding says good leaders should be judged on their results. He says of a great leader, the people will say we did it ourselves. Gooding says women in general as managers are more inclusive than men. He also says women are more likely to have children.

In fact, I sometimes find these gender differences, when sort of represented in the business environment, are actually just not very useful. Because I have seen women who are more autocratic and more leading from the front and more dictatorial, and Ive equally seen men who are very consultative. So, I dont just think it divides that way.

A fire charred the top of two of three wings of the Monte Carlo Resort and Casino. No major injuries were reported, but visitors and employees were forced to evacuate. Gooding: "I think its the thrill of the chase, basically. Its the constant challenge, theres always something new""I think thats what keeps us all going," Gooding says.

A bit over an hour after it began, the fire was fully contained. Firefighters would remain at the hotel until the fire is completely knocked out. It was mainly an exterior fire, although there might have been slight damage to some rooms.
No one was trapped, and there were no reports of major injuries. The 32floor building was completely evacuated. Welders had been working on the roof.

The blaze was reported about 11 a.m. Black smoke and flames poured from the fire. Most of the damage was to the top floor of the building. Falling debris ignited parts of an exterior ledge four floors below.

As you can see with it being outside, our firefighters actually had to hang out the windows to try and cut the fire off. We directed our fire streams at an angle so we could make contact with the fire.

Earlier, the smoke was visible from more than a mile away, CNN producer Darian Billington says. Four U.S. Air Force HH60 Pave Hawk helicopters with rescue crews were put on standby at Nellis Air Force Base. The hotel has more than 3,000 rooms, including 211 penthouse suites, and conference rooms.
The Monte Carlo, a subsidiary of MGM Mirage, has about 3,000 employees. The hotel was built in 1996 for 344 million. In 1980, a fire across the street at the MGM Grand Hotel, now Ballys, killed 84.

Huckabee said crisis sparked by Bhuttos death should lead to a crackdown on illegal immigrants from Pakistan. Huckabee official told CNN that when he said that, Huckabee was trying to turn attention away from scrutiny of his foreign policy knowledge. Huckabees foreign policy credentials have been under a microscope since he admitted that he was unaware of an intelligence report that Iran had suspended its nuclear weapons program earlier this month. The former Arkansas governor is a Republican presidential candidate.

The immigration issue is not so much about people coming to pick lettuce or make beds, its about people who could come with a shoulderfired missile and could do serious damage and harm to us. The Huckabee official said he told Huckabee that his reaction to the crisis in Pakistan will be the story for the next several days, and until he is briefed and up to speed on Pakistan, a good place for Huckabee to draw the line is on illegal immigration.

Huckabee said 660 Pakistanis entered the country illegally last year. The campaign official admitted that Huckabees tough immigration talk is also aimed at helping him win male GOP voters in Iowa  a bloc the official concedes the campaign has been losing ground with.

The number of illegal immigrants from Pakistan deported or apprehended is not mentioned in the latest report from the Department of Homeland Security. In 2005, the nation did not make the list of the top 10 sources ofillegal immigrants. The Border Patrol told CNN on Friday that it apprehended only a handful of illegal immigrant from Pakistan in 2007.

A Los Angeles TimesBloomberg poll conducted December 2023 and 26 has Huckabee leading former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney 36 percent to 28 percent among likely caucus goers. The previous year, Pakistan was the last country listed, but no specific numbers were given.

Mitt Romney has gone on the attack against Huckabee, particularly focusing on his record on illegal immigration issues while he was Arkansas governor. Huckabees Friday comments on immigration came after he appeared to make another gaffe Thursday, when he seemed to suggest incorrectly that Pakistan was under martial law. While commenting on Bhuttos death during an Orlando, Florida, press conference, Huckabee told reporters that the United States first priority should be to find the responsible parties.

Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf lifted the countrys state of martial law roughly two weeks ago. Huckabee: "The point was, would it be reinstated? Would it be placed back in? All of the aspects of Martial law have not been completely lifted even now"

The slip ought to be really bad news for Huckabee, said the National Reviews Jim Geraghty. CNN senior political analyst Bill Schneider said the debate over whether Huckabee has command of the nuances of the Pakistan crisis would have little impact on his support.

Mike Huckabee is a populist. His comments on Pakistan reflect a populist understanding of the crisis, Schneider says. Sure, the political establishment is snickering, but I doubt that his misstatements bother his supporters much, he says.

President Bush draws parallels between the cost of pulling out of Iraq and the tragedy of Vietnam. Three decades later, there is a legitimate debate about how we got into the Vietnam War and how we left, Bush says. The White House billed the speech, as it did next weeks address to the American Legion, as an effort to provide broader context for the debate over the Iraq progress report. Bush also sought to shore up the perception of his support for Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri alMaliki, after voicing some frustration with him on Tuesday.

Prime Minister Malikis a good guy  good man with a difficult job and I support him, Bush said. Sen. Edward Kennedy, DMassachusetts, said Bush had drawn the wrong lesson from history. America lost the war in Vietnam because our troops were trapped in a distant country we did not understand.

Sen. Joe Biden, Democratic chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, invoked his own Vietnam analogy in a statement released after the speech. Biden said Bush continues to cling to the premise that Iraqis will rally behind a strong central government, but he believes that will not happen. House Republican leader John Boehner of Ohio said more Democrats are bucking their party leaders in acknowledging progress in Iraq.

Many rankandfile Democrats have seen this progress firsthand and are now acknowledging the successes of a strategy theyve repeatedly opposed. But Democratic leaders, deeply invested in losing the war, would rather move the goalposts and claim that a precipitous withdrawal is the right approach. Former presidential adviser David Gergen said Bush ran the risk of doing as much harm as good for his case.

Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri alMaliki calls comments by U.S. senator irresponsible. Sen. Carl Levin said alMalikis government was too beholden to religious and sectarian leaders to reach a political settlement. Levin called on Iraqs parliament to turn the nonfunctioning government out of office when it returns in two weeks. Bush had expressed frustration with the pace of progress toward political reconciliation in Iraq, saying if the Iraqi government doesnt respond to the demands of the people, they will replace the government.

In his speech, Bush said withdrawing from Vietnam emboldened todays terrorists by compromising U.S. credibility. He cited a quote from al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden that the American people would rise against the Iraq war the same way they rose against the war in Vietnam. President Bush has frequently asked lawmakers  and theAmerican people to withhold judgment on his troop surge in Iraq until the report comes out in September.

The White House is trying to reframe the debate over Iraq. A recent CNNOpinion Research Corporation poll found that almost twothirds of Americans now oppose the Iraq war. 72 percent say the Petraeus report will have no effect on their opinion. 53 percent said they do not trust Petraeus to give an accurate assessment of the situation in Iraq, according to the poll.

Militarists of Japan and the Communists in Korea and Vietnam were driven by a merciless vision for the proper ordering of humanity. They killed Americans because we stood in the way of their attempt to force this ideology on others. Bush said history proved skeptics wrong about Japans ability to become a free society.

In defiance of the critics, Japan... stands as one of the worlds great free societies. They prefer the darkness and calm of early morning when their targets are most vulnerable, still sleeping or under the influence. They make sure their prey  suspected killers and other violent fugitives know what theyre up against.

The U.S. Marshals Service is the nations oldest law enforcement agency. It is best known for protecting federal judges, transporting federal prisoners and protecting witnesses. Less known is the cuttingedge work of the agencys six regional task forces in capturing suspects.

In 2007, the investigators from the Southeast task force arrested more than 3,000 suspects. On any given day, Ergas and his force are tracking 10 to 15 suspected killers roaming the Southeast. Already this year, they have been involved in a number of highprofile searches Gary Michael Hilton, the suspect charged in the killing of Meredith Emerson who disappeared while hiking in northern Georgia a fugitive Marine.

Most of the time theyre chasing suspects outside of the glare of the media spotlight. Charles Leon Parker has been on the run since the 1980s after being accused of molesting his stepdaughters. Our mandate is to track violent fugitives  murderers, armed robbers, rapists and fugitives of that caliber, says Keith Booker.

The Marshals were brought in recently, Booker says, after Parker allegedly called one of his victims and said, I wanted you to know I saw you and your daughter, and she sure is beautiful. ODonnell says it takes highly trained, high energy, really special people to do such work day in and day out, especially when theyre up against some of the most dangerous individuals in the country. Its not an exaggeration to say theyre the front of the front line.

In one demonstration, Ergas steps into the simulator and responds to reports of shots fired at a workplace. A woman rushes to a victim on the ground, as Ergas barks out commands. Moments later, a man rounds the corner.
The suspect hits the ground. A split second later, another gunman emerges, and Ergas blasts him too. Think of it as Wii on steroids.

There are 50 different scenarios the simulator can create, with a technician able to change each scenario. A trainee can use a shotgun, rifle, Glock 22 or Glock 23. The guns shoot a laser and each shot is traced.

Each shot is analyzed, because in the real world a law enforcement officer is held accountable for every bullet that comes out of his or her gun. No one wants to shoot anyone, Ergas says. Even officers that may not have pulled the trigger will be affected by shooting and killing someone.
This is a model, he says. We overwhelm them with surprising speed and force. Thats what keeps us safe, and thats what keeps them safe.

The Farm at Cape Kidnappers in New Zealand is the best place for an adrenaline rush. Ojai Valley Inn  Spa in California is a great place for girls to relax and unwind. Check out these seven truly amazing destinations.

A Vietnamese woman caught cooking a tiger carcass was sentenced to two and a half years in jail. There are reportedly only about 100 tigers, prized by socalled medicine men, left living in Vietnam.

A Hanoi court convicted Nguyen Thi Thanh, 41, for violating regulations protecting rare wild animals. She was arrested last September after police raided a house that she rented in the capital city. Officers found Thanh and three accomplices cooking tiger carcasses. The three men received suspended sentences, ranging from 24 to 30 months.

Tigers are universally threatened, with only about 100 still living in Vietnam. The southeast Asian country has banned trafficking in endangered animal parts. Such medicine men think tiger bones and other parts can cure arthritis and other joint ailments. Last year, the Vietnamese government unearthed 38 cases of illegal trafficking.

Heath Ledger was found dead in a New York apartment Tuesday, January 22. CNN.com readers describe meeting Ledger in person, and call him humble and kind. Famous for his roles in the films, The Patriot and Lords of Dogtown, he was widely acclaimed for his portrayal of the homosexual cowboy Ennis del Mar in 2005s Brokeback Mountain.

Donal Logue met Heath eight years ago while working on The Patriot. He became a star while we were sequestered away in a small town in South Carolina. He surrounded himself with his friends from Australia and never forgot any of us he ever worked with.

I last saw him in Australia when he called my name on a Melbourne street and introduced me to Michelle, his then pregnant girlfriend. Heath must have been in a place of great pain and sadness to be split from his wife and child. He was sensitive and unfairly victimized in his native country by the unfortunate Australian custom called the tall poppy syndrome.

He was a sweet person, and less importantly, an unbelievably talented actor. Maybe the best of his generation. Dan Bova of Larchmont, New York once got a flat tire. He helped jack up my car and change the tire.

R. of Perth, Western Australia grew up with Heath around the speedway racing circuit. I remember the night he was a little boy and his Dad was racing speed cars at Claremont Speedway. His dad was coming 3rd then in the final corner, the two lead cars spun out and Heaths dad Kim took the lead and won the State Title race.

He was about as happy as a little boy could be watching his dad become a champion. Later Heath would pit crew for Graham Jones, and I crewed for my dad and brother. Heath and I were both the youngest on our crews so that meant our job was to take the fiberglass bonnets over to the hoses and wash the mud off after each race.
I was staring at him working up the nerve to ask for an autograph. He saw me, started laughing and walked towards me. He said I was white as an egg and asked if he could do anything.
Dena Michnowich of Glen Cove, New York was walking in the lower east side of Manhattan. She noticed a really cute man holding his little daughter on his shoulders.

He told her that they had to make a right and asked her to point them in the right direction, which she did. I soon realized that it was Heath Ledger and I got really excited. He was so handsome I got the chills.
I could also sense that he had a very sweet spirit. It was a very special moment for me. Im so sad to hear that he died. Leanne Scorzoni of Staten Island, New York.

Michael Williams of Perth, Western Australia met Heath Ledger many years ago. He stopped to sign autographs while he waited knowing that to the people asking him he was somewhat of a hero. They were genuinely interested in their child, her development, and treating the rest of us including staff with respect.

Tracy Kimball of Rock Hill, South Carolina met Heath Ledger in 1999 while he was filming The Patriot in South Carolina. I was a reporter for a daily newspaper there and he was at a press conference about the movie at Historic Brattonsville, a Revolutionaryera plantation. He was so very kind and was more than happy to sign my newspaper.

The media was flocking around Mel Gibson, but seeing a new young and dashingly gorgeous guy standing off to himself, I approached him and asked for his autograph. He flashed that smile, grabbed my pen and used my back to sign the newspaper I was holding. We had a conversation, but I dont remember it because I was so enamored.
His death really saddens me. He was such a talented actor and a new dad. Having a child the same age as his daughter, it makes me even sadder to think of her missing her father.

His portrayal of Ennis del Mar was lifechanging for many of my friends. He was a true gentleman and Im sure an amazing father. To make assumptions as to how or why he died is to bring more pain to an already devastated family.

Adrian K. of Perth, Western Australia met Heath one night on the town in Perth. The onedegree of separation rule in Perth made him a friend of a friend. What struck me was his calm in the face of his monstrous burgeoning celebrity. With both of his feet planted firmly on the ground, he seemed

I was an extra in the movie Dark Knight, which filmed in Chicago this past summer. He was rather quiet most of the time between takes, but seemed to be a nice, likeable guy. It was great to watch him work, as he was very committed to his craft.
His death is a great loss. I met Heath Ledger while working in Atlanta. He was silly, smiling all the time and we spoke about horses and riding lessons.
He was down to earth and so very talkative. Just a normal guy, hanging out. His best movie was my favorite movie of 2005, Lords Of Dogtown.

Heath played the somewhat obnoxious Skip Engblom, but thinking of all the other actors who could have taken the roll, I dont think anyone could have done it better. Even two of the original Zephyr shop boys themselves. Tony Alva  Stacy Peralta, said when Heath came in  did the voice he would use in the film, it was like hearing Skip from the past.

There was definitely incoming small arms fire from insurgents in the September 16 incident in Baghdad, founder and CEO Erik Prince told CNNs Wolf Blitzer on Late Edition. There was no deliberate violence, committed by Blackwater employees, he added. Still, when asked whether it is possible someone with Blackwater screwed up in the incident, Prince replied, Certainly its possible.

American officials are also coming up with ways to fill the security gap if Blackwater is forced to leave, AP reported. The Iraqi government accuses Blackwater guards of opening fire without provocation on civilians in a crowded area in Baghdad on September 16. Survivors told FBI investigators Blackwater Guards shot at civilians presenting no threat.

First U.S. soldiers to arrive on the scene found no evidence contractors were fired upon, source says. But Prince says at least three armored vehicles were hit by small arms fire, incoming, and one of them damaged. The soldiers found evidence suggesting the guards fired on cars attempting to leave and found weapon casings matching only those used by the military and contractors.

The traffic circle is very big, so those first soldiers on the scene would have needed almost a battalion to secure that entire area. So the jury is still out. Well see what the FBI report comes up with, but Im confident that the kind of people we have out there are proven military professionals, Prince said.

A Philadelphia law firm has filed suit in federal court against Blackwater. The suit claims Blackwater created and fostered a culture of lawlessness amongst its employees. Prince called the lawsuit politically motivated for media attention, and rejected the depictions of his company. He said when the guys get it right 99 out of 100 times and dont have to use any force or any violence at all, I think they are doing very well, he said.  A mine exploded Monday on a road in southern Somalia, killing four.

Victor Okumu, 51, a Kenyan doctor Damien Lehalle, 27, a French logistician and a Somali driver named Billan were the MSF workers who were killed. Another member of the team was slightly wounded, the group said in a posting on its Web site.

Also killed was journalist Hassan Kafi Hared, 36. The remotecontrolled mine erupted as he was walking to a news conference. He was working for the governmentrun Somali National News Agency and a Somali Web site called gedonet.com. He is survived by a wife and three children.

Hared is the second journalist to be killed this year, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists. The first, 38yearold Norwegian reporter Carsten Thomassen, died Jan. 15 in a suicide bomb attack in Kabul. The medical humanitarian organization said it was evacuating remaining international members of it staff from Kismayu.

U.N. drug control agency warns celebrities are glamorizing drug use. Treating stars leniently undermines faith in the criminal justice system, report says. Report: Celebrities get more lenient responses by the judiciary and law enforcement. Timothy Masters was convicted of the 1999 murder of Peggy Hettrick. On Tuesday a judge threw out Masters 1999 murder conviction, and he was freed also in the interest of justice. Although the motion signals that Abrahamson is dropping the Masters case, he did not rule out future prosecution.

A jury convicted Masters 12 years after the discovery of Hettricks' body. He has insisted he had nothing to do with her death, and no physical evidence ties him directly to the crime. The significance of Fridays motion to dismiss is largely procedural, but Abrahamson indicated earlier this week that it might be unnecessary to try Masters again. Spears, the star of Nickelodeons Zoey 101, told OK! Magazine that shes pregnant and that the father is her 18yearold boyfriend. Consensual sex between the two may well have been legal, depending on where and when it took place.

Critics of the nations statutory rape laws say that laws that are ignored in some cases can be used to put other teens in prison. You have a disturbing disparity in how these laws are enforced, said Jonathan Turley, a law professor at George Washington University. What this case should focus the nation on is having a more evenhanded approach to these cases.

In Louisiana, where Spears lives, it is a misdemeanor for someone age 17 to 19 to have consensual sex with someone age 15 to 17 if the difference between their ages is more than two years. In California, where she sometimes tapes her television show, its a misdemeanor to have sex withSomeone younger than 18 if the offender is less than three years older.

Turley said most states have similar laws but rely on prosecutors to be selective in enforcing them. The issue drew international attention when a Georgia teen was sentenced to 10 years in prison for having consensual oral sex with a 15yearold girl when he was 17. In 2005, Genarlow Wilson was tried for the rape of a 17 year old girl at a hotelroom party. While he was found not guilty of that charge, he was convicted of aggravated child molestation.

Georgia law required a mandatory 10year sentence on the charge of aggravated child molestation. Wilson was released from prison in October after serving more than two years. The state Supreme Court ruled his sentence was grossly disproportionate to his crime. Under the revised Georgia law, the act now would be a misdemeanor.

Spears, who turned 16 on April 4, says she is 12 weeks into her pregnancy. She plans to raise her child in Louisiana, so it can have a normal family life. Her attorney argued throughout his case that Wilson was imprisoned for an act that, while perhaps morally questionable, probably is going on among teens everywhere. He said statutory rape prosecutions of teens are more common in Southern states and small towns than they are elsewhere.

Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama each accused the other of borrowing portions of their presidential campaign speeches Monday.

The Clinton campaign accused Obama of borrowing from a close supporter, and the Illinois senator responded by saying his own words have been used by Clinton. Clinton followed up with a swipe of her own. If your whole candidacy is about words, then they should be your own words, Clinton said.

Ive written two books, wrote most of my speeches. So I think putting aside the question... in terms of whether my words are my own, I think that would be carrying it too far, Obama said. Obama said he also used some of Devals words at a JeffersonJackson dinner in Wisconsin.

Obama campaign officials said Clinton had a pattern of borrowing from some of her rivals signature phrases. They circulated a YouTube video and list of these alleged instances to reporters. Mohammed Sultan Nafeeks teenage daughter moved to Saudi Arabia to work as a housemaid to support her family after they were displaced by the 2004 tsunami. Now she is on death row, and all he can do is pray.

Atlanta Falcons quarterback Michael Vick is expected to plead guilty to federal conspiracy charges. The NFL has not yet decided what football sanctions, if any, it should impose on Vick. Stephanie King of Arlington, Washington: Michael Vick is a disgrace. Stephanie King: Anyone thinking he should be let off easy for admitting his guilt is wrong. "The only reason he did that was because he knew the evidence against him was so great," she says.

What he did was reprehensible. He is in a spotlight where he should be held at a higher standard for a role model. The charges against him are not football related in any way. The NFL needs to step up to the plate and be the man that Michael Vick is not.

Allowing him in their league gives a signal that animal abuse is OK with them. Remember Jeffrey Dahmer started as an animal abuser! Want him as your role model or a spokesman? Kelly Koch of Holland, Michigan

Vick should be allowed to play after a suspension. Until I know the depth of the gambling angle its hard to be certain. Dog fighting is brutal but if its only dog fighting, he should get whatever the feds give him and be able to return to football once his debt is paid.
He wasnt the best QB to begin with. Anyone with such a blatant disregard for life  animal or human is not worthy of the position in life he was given. Playing in the NFL is not a right.
Mr. Vick should be judged of his crime. Not by his fame, nor his race. He should be prosecuted as a person. This is how everyone should be treated in America.
Everyone is equal regardless of popularity, fame, and race. This is not an issue to raise the race card. Even his socalled homies who were all black turned on him.

Vick... committed a felony and now he has to pay for it. As for playing football... he should be banned from the league for at least 2 to 3 years. Leah Perry of Chelmsford, Massachusetts I dont think Vick should be allowed to play football, nor should he get off easy.

I think Michael Vick will play football again, though at what level is anybodys guess. I do not think he should be banned for life. He may have gambled, but not on the game as Pete Rose did. A prison term and suspension would put him out of football for up to three years.

The NFL needs to ban him permanently. He shouldnt be able to use the obscene amount of money he makes to torture innocent animals. Kids looked up to him and how many of them will think that abuse is OK now?

He should be working for the road department, picking up Road Kill off the streets. He was given the Golden key to a life of fame and riches and he blew it away. He needs to be banned from the NFL forever.

These men are role models for the youth of this country. What kind of message would we be sending to them if we were to let him play in the NFL again? Not a good one, I can tell you that much. If Imus is going to return back to the air... then Vick should return to the field.

You violate some people or beings you apologize, let the air clear and go on with business as usual! John Brandon of Old Hickory, Tennessee. From January 1 it will be illegal in France to smoke in cafes as well as clubs, casinos and hotels. In spite of the health dangers, about 13.5 million people smoke out of a population of 60 million. Around 26 percent of 15 year olds estimated to smoke, according to 2002 figures from the World Health Organization. In a country renowned for its fondness for romance, smoking has never quite shaken off its romantic associations with smoky Left Bank cafes.

Smoking ban was first introduced in France in February this year to cover workplaces, schools, airports and hospitals. The new restrictions will only apply to the inside of premises, meaning smokers are still free to light up on the terraces. Authorities have agreed to an amnesty over the New Year holiday and will not fully enforce the new arrangements until Wednesday.

France has lagged behind many of its European neighbors in bringing in legislation to curb smoking in public places. Ireland became the first European country to introduce a comprehensive smoking ban in 2004. Italy, Spain, Belgium and Britain have followed suit with similar bans. The toddler whose body washed ashore in Texas last month has been tentatively identified as a 2yearold girl.

Football will pay its tribute to Busby Babes on the 50th anniversary of the Munich air disaster. Manchester United will hold a minute's silence for the legend at Old Trafford on Wednesday. The club will also hold a memorial service for the late Sir Bobby Charlton.

Flight 609 ZU crashed on the third attempt to take off after refuelling in Germany. Eight players lost their lives on February 6, 1958, when United returned from knocking Red Star Belgrade out of the European Cup. Geoff Bent, aged 25, Roger Byrne28, Eddie Colman 21, Mark Jones 24, David Pegg 22, Tommy Taylor 26, Liam Whelan 22 and 21year-old Duncan Edwards who died in hospital 15 days after the crash. A commemorative service will be held at Old Trafford while a short ceremony will also take place at the memorial site in Kirchtrudering.

In keeping with tradition, United supporters will also gather under the memorial plaque at Old Trafford where the clock is fixed at the exact time of the final fateful takeoff attempt. Later in the day, a minutes silence will take place ahead of Englands friendly with Switzerland at Wembley as a further mark of respect. The presidents of Sudan and Chad signed a nonaggression agreement late Thursday, aiming to halt crossborder hostilities between the two African nations.

The signing came after nearly two full days of talks in Dakar, Senegal. The idea is to get the governments of Sudan and Chad to normalize their relations with each other. Each country accuses the other of supporting armed rebel groups that cross the border to attempt to destabilize the government. U.N. Secretary General Ban Kimoon met with officials from both nations and witnessed the signing of the agreement at about 10 p.m. ET.

The United Nations says refugees and armed groups have been regularly crossing the border between the troubled Darfur region of Sudan and Chad. They allegedly include many of the rebels that attacked NDjamena, the capital of Chad, in early February.

More than 10,000 people from Darfur, in Sudan, have fled into 12 official refugee camps in eastern Chad. They join some 240,000 Darfurians who have lived in Chad since 2004 because of fighting in their homeland. The number of displaced Chadians is growing because of the recent fighting there, Kingsley Amaning says. The United Nations, which has peacekeeping troops in the Darfur region, will work to assure Sudan and Chad carry out the terms of Thursdays deal.

Sen. Larry Craig, RIdaho, initially said he would resign at the end of September but then changed his mind. Craig wants the Minnesota Court of Appeals to overturn a judges decision refusing to let him withdraw a guilty plea. Craig has maintained that he is innocent of any illegal conduct at the Minneapolis airport, his lawyer says.

Craig says he has the constitutional right to make every effort to clear his name. Martin called the judges decision a manifest injustice. Craig said we dont know what the appellate court will say to me. Honestly, the appeals courts tend to defend the courts below them.
It is my right to do what Im doing. Ive already provided for Idaho the certainty that Idaho needed, Im not running for reelection. Im no longer in the way. I am pursuing my constitutional rights.

Craig entered a guilty plea after his arrest in a mens room at the MinneapolisSt. Paul International Airport for allegedly propositioning a plainclothes police officer for sex. Craig originally said he would resign from the Senate on September 30 if he could not get the guilty plea withdrawn.

I am innocent of the charges against me, he said at the time. The Idaho lawmakers decision not to resign has created a political headache for the Senates Republican leadership. When news of the arrest first surfaced, GOP leaders called for an investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee.

Sen. John Ensign of Nevada leads the GOPs Senate campaign committee. In an interview taped Sunday with NBCs Matt Lauer, Craig complained that Mitt Romney threw me under the campaign bus when news of his arrest came out. Craig told Lauer in the interview set to run Tuesday night, according to MSNBC.com.

Romney, former governor of Massachusetts, called Craigs behavior disgraceful and urged the senator to resign when news of the arrest broke in August. Craig was Romneys Senate liaison before resigning from the campaign. Romney spokesman Kevin Madden defended the presidential candidates response.

Also in the Lauer interview, Craig and his wife, Suzanne, denied that their marriage is a cover for his homosexuality. The senator has denied he is gay. I love this woman very, very much, Larry Craig said.

Queen Elizabeth helped launch Heathrow's 8.6 billion new Terminal 5 on Friday. The move is part of the British airports rejuvenation plan to maintain its status as one of the worlds most important transport hubs. Suzanne Craig: I felt like the floor was falling out from under me when I heard the news.

The first flights from the new terminal are scheduled for March 27. It is part of a strategy which could lead to passenger numbers almost doubling to 122 million a year. A sixth terminal and a third runway are in the pipeline despite some vociferous opposition. The British monarch also opened Heathrows first passenger terminal in 1955.

Spanishowned BAA also plans to eventually demolish Terminals 1 and 2 and replace them in a project called Heathrow East. Terminal 5 stands as a monument to the bingeflying culture this Government has done so much to encourage, Greenpeace transport campaigner Anita Goldsmith said. Its part of an obsession with expansion which can only mean more flights, more emissions and more climate change.

Richard Dyer of Friends of the Earth said Heathrow expansion would be environmentally irresponsible. But business groups welcomed the expansion at Heathrow. Thriving, growing airports are vital to help maintain Britains economic competitiveness, Neil Pakey, chairman of the Airport Operators Association, said. Domestic air links to Heathrow are particularly valuable for the regional economies, he said.

18-year-old Khiel Coppin can be heard saying, Ive got a gun, police say. The teen put an object under his shirt and told his mother around the time she phoned 911 that he was going to say he had a gun. He told her, Im prepared to die, New York Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly says.

When authorities arrived at the BedfordStuyvesant apartment, the teenager had something stuffed under his shirt. Coppin ignored repeated commands to stop and get on the ground. Witnesses said the teen appeared to be holding an object underneath his shirt and pointed it at the officers.

Twenty shots were fired Coppin was struck eight times, Kelly said. Kelly said the teens mother reported he had not taken his antidepressant and antipsychotic medication. Police have not recovered a gun and do not believe he was armed.
A reporter asked Kelly if its possible the young man was goading police to shoot him. Thats certainly a possibility, said Kelly. The boy didnt have no gun, he had a brush on him, said Andre Wildman.

Police are investigating whether Coppin had a history of mental illness. The shooting came a year after unarmed groom Sean Bell, 23, was killed hours before his wedding. In 1999, unarmed African immigrant Amadou Diallo, 22, died when police in the Bronx shot him 19 times.

Coppin was seen pacing around the apartment prior to the shooting. He began screaming from the window at his mother and the police, police say. At some point, the male climbed out of the window and began crossing the sidewalk.

The Amazon rainforest is so vast and full of life that even its defenders dont know exactly what it is they are protecting. In the past 40 years, roughly 20 percent of the rainforest has been wiped out.

The Amazon rainforest is considered the worlds richest and most varied natural habitat. Several million species of insects, plants, birds and fish call it home. It also plays an important role in regulating Earths temperature as its dense vegetation absorbs carbon dioxide and releases oxygen into the air. The wealth of biodiversity is so immense, we cannot even estimate the amount we dont know, says Cláudio C. Maretti.

The Amazon has been under pressure from outside forces for decades. In the past 40 years, roughly 20 percent of the rainforest has been wiped out. Maretti says an additional 17 percent has been degraded to varying degrees.

The Amazon rainforest is just one of many habitats around the world threatened by encroaching development or natural resource extraction. The Food and Agriculture Organization FAO of the United Nations estimates that 50,000 square miles of forest are lost each year because of clearing and degradation.

Cambodia lost nearly 30 percent of its primary forests from 2000 to 2005, according to FAO. Vietnam lost close to 55 percent ofIts primary forests, FAO found. Nigeria lost nearly 56 percent of Its primary forests over the same period, the worst rate of forest loss in the world.

Half of the world's forests have been destroyed in the last 30 years, says Greenpeace. The chief driver of forest destruction is the buying and selling of forest products in the international market, says Scott Paul, Forest Campaign Coordinator for Greenpeace. Paul would like to see a certification system so that consumers know the source and conditions under which the product theyre consuming was harvested.

forests lost to logging and agriculture are actually growing back in some areas. This thrills some wildlife advocates who would like to see the restoration of exiled or decimated species. Northern New England is the only place in the eastern United States where you have the potential for largescale wilderness where wolves, lynxes, cougars, woodland caribou and salmon rivers could be restored, says Michael J. Kellett, executive director of RESTORE The North Woods.

Kelletts biggest fear is that real estate development could begin to carve up the vast forests of Maine. His proposed solution create a national park. In Brazil in recent years, the government reportedly has stepped up efforts to slow the Amazons destruction.

Environmental groups say the drop also was caused by the fall of soy prices and the rise of Brazils currency against the dollar. The World Wildlife Funds Maretti is hopeful that Brazil, with international help, will be able to protect even more of the Amazon.
